title: Unconditional full contributors who consistently give maximum amounts regardless of others' behavior

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is an unstable, opportunistic free-rider with intermittent cooperation. They alternate between full contribution and full defection rather than choosing intermediate levels (which are not available here), and they do not settle into a consistent cooperative or non-cooperative regime.

They sometimes contribute fully even when others’ average contributions are relatively low, and sometimes free-ride when others are contributing a lot. This indicates weak conditional cooperation: they do not reliably match the group’s behavior, and their own pattern shows no clear upward or downward trend; instead it is volatile and context-insensitive.

They tolerate substantial inequality in their favor, repeatedly taking high private payoffs while others contribute more. They also occasionally accept very poor personal payoffs when choosing to contribute and punish heavily, suggesting that immediate monetary maximization is not their sole priority.

Fairness norms are weak or inconsistent. They show no clear pattern of “if most others contribute, I will too” or “if most defect, I will defect.” Their contribution choices do not consistently reward cooperators or punish defectors through contribution behavior itself.

Risk tolerance appears moderate to high: they are willing to expose themselves to negative or very low round payoffs (especially in combination with heavy punishment) without an observable adaptive correction toward safer, lower-variance strategies.

Overall, they act as a noisy, self-regarding player who occasionally experiments with cooperation but does not anchor on a stable pro-social or purely selfish strategy.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is an unusually heavy and sometimes extreme punisher, with a pattern consistent with antisocial or spiteful punishment rather than norm-enforcing punishment.

They frequently spend large amounts on punishment, sometimes to the point of driving their own payoff into strongly negative territory. This shows that they are willing to sacrifice considerable personal income purely to reduce others’ payoffs. Such willingness is hard to reconcile with purely instrumental, payoff-maximizing motives; it is more consistent with emotional or expressive motives (e.g., spite, frustration) or with a distorted notion of “justice” that does not track contributions.

Their targeting is not aligned with standard reciprocal fairness norms. They do not focus their punishment selectively on low contributors or consistent free-riders. In several instances, they punish players who are contributing fully or more than they are. This lack of alignment with contribution levels indicates that punishment is not primarily used to enforce cooperation norms.

They also do not display a clear deterrence strategy: there is no observable tightening or relaxing of punishment in line with changes in others’ behavior, nor a consistent focus on repeat low contributors. Instead, the pattern looks erratic and high-intensity, with large punishment bursts directed at specific individuals at different times.

Selectivity is low: when they do decide to punish, they sometimes punish multiple players and at high intensity, rather than carefully choosing minimal-cost interventions. Given the cost-benefit ratio of punishment, their choices often reduce their own payoff without producing obvious strategic benefits.

Taken together, their punishment profile suggests a “spiteful / antisocial punisher” type: willing to incur costs to harm others, not reliably linked to contribution norms, and with little evidence of strategic calibration.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player receives punishment on multiple occasions from various others. Their behavioral response does not indicate compliance or accommodation: after being punished, they do not reliably shift toward the punisher’s apparent norm (for example, they do not consistently move from free-riding to contributing, nor from heavy punishment to restraint).

There is also no clear pattern of targeted retaliation against identifiable punishers. Although punishers are identifiable, the player’s punishment behavior is too broad and erratic to cleanly infer tit-for-tat responses. Sometimes they later punish players who had previously punished them, but they also punish players who did not punish them and fail to punish some past punishers. Because of this inconsistency, any retaliatory motive is at best low-confidence and mixed with other motives.

They show no visible “forgiveness” dynamic: punishment from others does not lead them to stop punishing those individuals, nor to adopt more cooperative contributions toward them. Instead, their own punishment and contribution patterns continue in a similarly volatile manner regardless of who has sanctioned them.

Overall, they appear relatively insensitive to being punished in terms of strategic adjustment. They neither consistently appease punishers with cooperative behavior nor reliably escalate against them; they continue following their own idiosyncratic pattern.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes detailed end-of-round outcomes, including others’ payoffs, punishment expenditures, and received deductions, yet their subsequent behavior does not seem systematically guided by these outcomes.

They do not clearly reward players who sacrifice payoff to enforce cooperation, nor do they consistently ally with, imitate, or avoid heavy punishers. Similarly, they do not preferentially protect high contributors from punishment; they repeatedly allow or participate in environments where cooperators are heavily punished without adjusting their own contribution or punishment strategy to stabilize the group.

They appear largely unconcerned with the efficiency of group outcomes. They sometimes choose actions (especially heavy punishment combined with contribution) that drive total welfare down and harm themselves, even when others are already incurring large costs. There is no sign that they shift toward more restrained behavior when they see others generating very low or negative payoffs through aggressive punishment, nor that they exploit this chaos in a reliably payoff-maximizing way.

Their reaction to others’ extreme punishments is thus best characterized as indifferent or opportunistic rather than coordinated or norm-driven. They do not emulate high-earning strategies consistently, nor do they react to others’ misfortunes with protection or restraint. If anything, they sometimes contribute nothing and avoid punishment, letting others bear the cost of chaotic sanctioning while they collect high free-rider payoffs.

In summary, this player processes others’ outcomes in a way that does not translate into stable reciprocity, coalition-building, or efficiency-seeking. Their type is a volatile, opportunistic free-rider with a strong antisocial punishment streak, low responsiveness to sanctions, and minimal regard for group welfare or coherent norm enforcement.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strongly cooperative, norm-focused contributor who usually gives the full endowment to the public fund. Their default is to maintain very high contributions even as others occasionally lower theirs. They only reduce their own contribution a few times, and those reductions are modest relative to full free-riding, suggesting discomfort with deviating too far from a fairness norm rather than a shift to pure self-interest.

Their cooperation is conditionally tied to perceived group norms rather than to short-term payoff maximization: they continue to contribute fully even when average contributions dip and when they personally suffer substantial punishment. They do not appear to condition contributions strongly on having received rewards or punishments; contribution levels are remarkably stable despite large shocks. This points to a principled, rule-based cooperation style rather than responsive tit-for-tat.

They show mild willingness to shade contributions downward when group averages and some individual contributions fall, but they never exploit very low-contributing peers to take large private gains. Risk tolerance appears moderate: they accept repeated exposure to potential punishment rather than reshaping their contribution behavior to avoid being targeted, implying either confidence that their high contributions are justified or relative indifference to strategic image management via contribution choices alone.

Fairness norms are strict and demanding: they seem to view full or near-full contribution as the proper standard for others, and they keep adhering to that themselves even when others deviate. They appear more willing to use the punishment mechanism to enforce norms than to use their own contributions as leverage.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a classic end-game unraveling in this player. They maintain full contributions through the final rounds, including the last one, showing no systematic cooperation decay. Instead of cutting contributions as the end approaches, they escalate enforcement via punishment. Near the end, they dramatically increase the intensity of sanctions on certain targets while still contributing fully.

This pattern suggests that they treat the final rounds as an opportunity to “settle accounts” or reinforce norms rather than to exploit others. They do not appear to adopt a backward-induction logic that would lead to selfish behavior as the game ends. If anything, they become more aggressive in disciplining those they see as repeated norm violators, using the end game to deliver large, possibly symbolic punishments. Overall, horizon awareness changes their punishment strategy more than their contribution level.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is highly willing to incur substantial personal costs to punish others, especially repeat or extreme under-contributors relative to a high-contribution norm. They frequently target specific individuals who persistently contribute less than what the player seems to regard as acceptable. Targets are not random: they focus on those who deviate downward from an implicit full-contribution standard and who do so repeatedly over time.

They distinguish between moderate and severe norm violations. When another player contributes somewhat below the apparent norm, they often apply mild, repeated punishment, suggesting an attempt at calibrated deterrence. When a peer contributes very little or zero, especially if this happens multiple times, the player escalates to very large punishment expenditures. This escalation shows a strong “strong reciprocator” or altruistic-punisher tendency: they are willing to sacrifice significant payoff to impose very large costs on defectors.

Their punishment is primarily norm-enforcing rather than payoff-optimizing. They continue to punish even when the marginal effectiveness of punishment is uncertain and when punishment is extremely expensive for them. They also maintain high contributions while punishing, which indicates that the motive is not simply to reduce defectors’ relative advantage but to enforce a cooperative standard.

Selectivity is clear: they usually ignore small, one-off deviations and instead concentrate on a few players whose contributions repeatedly fall short or who oscillate between compliance and mild defection. This suggests they track histories and are sensitive to patterns over time. There are a few instances where they punish a player who has not clearly defected recently, indicating either low tolerance for any earlier deviation, a delayed response to past rounds, or possible confusion about recent contribution histories; confidence in this interpretation is low.

They do not appear to punish for personal retaliation against those who punish them: when they themselves are targeted, there is no clear, immediate counter-punishment against the likely punisher. Their punishment behavior therefore looks more like impersonal norm enforcement than vendetta.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When the player is punished, they do not obviously retaliate through counter-punishment, nor do they significantly reduce their own contributions in response. Their behavior after being punished stays highly cooperative and norm-enforcing, and they continue to direct sanctions at third-party under-contributors rather than at whoever targeted them.

Because punishers are identifiable, the absence of clear counter-punishment suggests that they either: (a) interpret punishment of themselves as a possible mistake or as noise; (b) prioritize group-level norm enforcement over personal revenge; or (c) do not track or respond to individual-level hostility in a tit-for-tat manner. They also do not show evidence of “compliance” in the sense of changing their strategy to align with a punisher’s apparent preferences; instead they persist with their own high-contribution, high-punishment strategy.

Overall, they appear relatively forgiving or at least non-retaliatory toward punishers, and they show a strong commitment to their own normative rule-set despite receiving negative feedback. Precise beliefs about why they were punished are unknown.

<REWARD>
The player shows very low usage of the reward mechanism. They reward a high contributor once early in the game but then almost never spend on rewards again, despite frequent observation of others who also cooperate at high levels. They do not systematically reward consistent high contributors or those who increase their contributions after punishment episodes. Rewarding behavior is therefore rare, unsustained, and not clearly part of a stable strategy.

Given that rewarding is institutionally inefficient (costly to the rewarder and relatively weak in effect), their strong preference for punishment over reward suggests they see negative sanctions as the primary tool for shaping behavior, rather than positive reinforcement. They prioritize punishing defectors over supporting cooperators, even when the group is already relatively cooperative. This implies a “stick over carrot” enforcement style, with rewards, when used, serving at most as occasional, perhaps exploratory, signals rather than a core component of their strategy.

Their single clear reward instance targets a high-contributing peer, suggesting they conceptually link reward to exceptional cooperation, but the fact that they do not repeat this pattern later indicates they either deem it too costly or too ineffective, or they focus so heavily on defectors that they choose not to allocate resources to rewarding.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
When the player is rewarded, they maintain or resume high contributions, but since high contributions are already their default, it is unclear whether the reward causally affects their behavior. There is no discernible attempt to reciprocate directly to the rewarder via counter-reward, nor do they appear to form a special “alliance” or favor network in response.

They also do not lower punishment of under-contributors after being rewarded; their norm-enforcement style persists unchanged, and they continue to sanction defectors aggressively. This suggests that, while they may appreciate being recognized (unknown), they do not update their broader enforcement or contribution strategies in a visible way because of rewards. Reciprocity toward rewarders is either absent or too subtle to detect in this data.

Overall, the player behaves as a principled, high-contribution enforcer type: they anchor on a strict cooperation norm, maintain it across the entire game, and rely heavily on costly punishment—rather than reward, retaliation, or end-game defection—to manage the social environment.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a strict, unconditional full contributor. They always allocate their entire endowment to the public fund in every round, with no visible sensitivity to others’ average contributions, to fluctuations in cooperation, or to their own realized payoffs. They behave as if full contribution is a fixed rule or moral standard, not a strategic choice. They do not shift contributions downward in response to repeated free-riding by specific players, nor upward (which is impossible here) to respond to high cooperation; instead, they hold a stable, maximal-cooperation line throughout.

They appear unconcerned with short-run monetary return from the contribution stage itself. Despite seeing the MPCR and the opportunity to gain more by cutting back when others under-contribute, they never exploit that option. This suggests either a strong fairness/cooperation norm that overrides payoff maximization, or a view of the contribution decision as separate from the payoff calculus—possibly because they intend to correct unfairness via punishment rather than via their own contribution choice.

Their risk tolerance in contribution is high: they fully cooperate even when others’ behavior is unstable and when they have already been “burned” in payoff terms by doing so. They do not hedge or partially reduce contributions to insure against low group contributions. Conditional cooperation, if present, does not show up in the contribution level; instead, their conditionality manifests almost entirely in their use of punishment and occasional reward.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the game horizon does not lead them to reduce contributions; they continue full cooperation through the final round. There is no standard end-game decay in the contribution stage.

In the sanctioning stage, their approach in late rounds remains intense and norm-focused rather than exploitative. They continue to spend substantial amounts on punishing perceived defectors even when there is no future round in which deterrence could pay off. They also keep targeting repeat low contributors consistently to the very end. This willingness to incur large, non-recoverable costs at the horizon strongly suggests that they value enforcing norms or expressing disapproval more than they value maximizing cumulative payoff in the final rounds.

They do not appear to “cash in” their position as a high contributor by relaxing norms or free-riding once the end is near. Instead, they maintain the same pattern: maximal cooperation plus heavy, targeted sanctioning. This indicates a stable preference profile rather than a forward-looking, purely strategic adjustment to the approaching end.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is a highly punitive, norm-enforcing type, willing to spend very large portions of their payoff to punish what they interpret as low or inconsistent cooperation. They use punishment frequently, in most rounds, and sometimes at very high intensity. The pattern of targets and magnitudes shows several distinct features:

- Primary targets are chronic or salient under-contributors. One particular peer who repeatedly contributes zero or very low amounts is punished heavily and persistently across many rounds. Another peer who oscillates between moderate and very low contribution is also punished repeatedly, with especially large punishment in rounds where that peer contributes far below the group.
- Occasional under-contributors or those sharply below the emerging high-cooperation norm (for example, contributing noticeably less than the majority but not necessarily zero) also receive punishment, though generally at more moderate levels.
- The player sometimes extends punishment to multiple low contributors in the same round when the overall group cooperation drops, directing sanctions across several peers who are below what looks like their internal standard.

The punishment does not appear to be retaliatory in response to being directly harmed by identifiable individuals, because punishers are anonymous and the player is never directly targeted in a way that could be clearly traced to particular peers. Instead, their pattern is consistent with second-order norm enforcement: they punish deviations from a high-contribution norm regardless of personal retaliation opportunities.

They regularly punish at levels that seriously reduce their own payoff for that round, clearly sacrificing income to impose large deductions on defectors. They sometimes do this even when others are also punishing the same targets, which indicates they are not merely “filling a gap” but are independently motivated to ensure a strong negative consequence for low contribution.

Their punishment is selective rather than random. They rarely, if ever, punish high contributors. When a previously low contributor later matches group norms more closely, the player sometimes reduces or suspends punishment, but if they regress, the player quickly resumes punishing, often strongly. This quasi-contingent pattern fits a type who aims to deter low cooperation and reinforce a target contribution level.

Because the punishment technology is favorable (high impact per unit), their behavior also fits “altruistic punisher” or “moralist” types from experimental literature: they personally incur substantial costs to enforce pro-social norms that benefit the group, even when anonymity prevents any reputational return and even at the end of the game when deterrence value is minimal.

<REWARD>
The player uses rewards sparingly, but in a systematic way. Compared to the frequency and magnitude of punishment, reward is infrequent and modest. When reward occurs, it follows two main patterns:

- Occasional positive reinforcement of previously low or questionable contributors who have clearly shifted to higher contributions, especially one peer who was a major defector earlier but later contributes more. The player twice provides small rewards to this peer in rounds where that peer’s contribution level is high or has improved, suggesting an attempt to encourage and stabilize cooperative behavior rather than simply destroy their payoff.
- Occasional small rewards to consistently high contributors or to several strong cooperators at once in a round where overall contributions are high. In one instance, the player disperses small rewards across several high contributors simultaneously, which looks like a group-wide “thank you” to those adhering to the cooperative norm.

They never reward under-contributors. Reward is strictly conditional on above-average or improving behavior. Given that the reward mechanism is “inefficient” (it costs more than it transfers), their willingness to use it at all indicates that they care about signaling approval and trying to shape future behavior, even at a cost. However, because they use punishment far more often and more heavily than reward, their social control strategy is predominantly negative reinforcement with only occasional positive reinforcement.

The asymmetry suggests they see punishment as the primary tool for norm enforcement, with reward as a secondary, supportive tool used to bolster allies or to encourage turnarounds from prior defectors. They are not a “warm glow” rewarder; reward is purposeful and targeted, not generous or frequent.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player pays close attention to others’ contributions and realized payoffs and adjusts sanctioning patterns accordingly, but without changing their own contribution level. Their decisions in the punishment/reward stage respond in nuanced ways to the observed outcome structure:

- They focus on players whose contributions leave those players with especially high payoffs relative to others because they free-ride on the group effort. When such players end up with high payoffs after contributing little or nothing, the player often responds by imposing heavy punishments, shrinking that payoff advantage. This shows sensitivity to distributive fairness, not just to contribution levels in isolation.
- They sometimes allow a previously heavily punished defector to earn higher payoffs in rounds where that player improves their contribution, supporting the interpretation that the target is behavior correction, not flat hostility. Concurrent small rewards to that player in high-contribution rounds reinforces this.
- When the group overall is cooperating strongly, the player often scales back punishment intensity and may not punish at all, or only lightly sanction marginal under-contributors. Their sanctions escalate during periods when group contributions or the average outcome drop due to a few under-contributors, suggesting they track how individual actions affect collective outcomes.
- They show some willingness to punish moderate under-contributors even when those players are not extreme free-riders, which implies a relatively strict fairness standard: being meaningfully below a de facto norm (rather than only being at zero) can still trigger sanctions. However, the strongest punishments are consistently directed at those whose behavior most clearly undermines group payoffs.
- They do not visibly reward players who spend heavily on punishment; if they are tracking others’ sanctioning behavior, it does not translate into overt support. Their main signals are tied to contribution and resulting payoffs, not to others’ enforcement choices.

Overall, the player reads the outcome screens as a map of who is helping or hurting the group’s welfare and uses that information to calibrate social control: strong punishment to compress unfairly high free-rider payoffs, reduced or suspended punishment when former defectors contribute more, and occasional rewards to acknowledge and reinforce high-cooperation outcomes. They prioritize enforcing an equitable, high-contribution environment over maximizing their own monetary gain, even when outcome information makes clear that this stance is costly.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a conditional, profit-focused free-rider with intermittent cooperative “bursts.” They treat contribution as a tool rather than a norm. Across the game, they spend a meaningful but minority share of their rounds contributing fully, alternating between full contribution and full defection rather than mixing intermediate amounts (here, a binary choice).

Their baseline preference is to keep their endowment and live off others’ contributions. When others’ cooperation remains reasonably high without their help, they comfortably defect and accept the group benefit. They do not systematically match others’ behavior: they sometimes contribute fully in environments where free-riding would be clearly more profitable, and sometimes defect in moderately cooperative environments. This suggests they are not following a simple “contribute if enough others do” rule; instead, they appear to explore and periodically test how much cooperation they can induce or sustain, then revert to self-interest.

They do not display a rigid fairness norm. They are willing to contribute fully even when several peers free-ride, and also willing to free-ride when many peers contribute. This indicates they do not insist on contribution reciprocity before they contribute, nor do they insist on “no one should gain more than me” as a stable rule. Their behavior is better described as opportunistic and adaptive: they are sensitive to the payoff structure and willing to accept payoff inequality if it advantages them.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. They sometimes choose the payoff-dominated cooperative action in environments where cooperation is fragile, which is risky if others defect, yet they never push this to an extreme sustained costly-cooperator pattern. They are not an unconditional cooperator or unconditional defector; instead, they oscillate, suggesting active learning and occasional risk-taking within an overall payoff-oriented frame.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the horizon and gradually shifts toward more consistent free-riding as the game progresses, but does not switch to pure defection. In the final stretch, contributions become rarer and are interspersed with defection even when cooperation by others is still present. The last round itself is played as a free-rider, consistent with standard end-game unraveling logic.

However, they do not exhibit a sharp, one-time end-game collapse. Rather, they move in and out of cooperative choices in late rounds, including at least one late cooperative burst despite the short remaining horizon. This suggests they understand that the game is finite and lean more toward self-interest near the end, but they also keep open the possibility of maintaining or exploiting a cooperative environment even late if it seems profitable or strategically interesting.

There is no clear evidence they are trying to build a reputation for future interactions beyond this game; with punishers being identifiable but no future interaction guaranteed after the final round, they do not make extra cooperative “gestures” at the end. Overall, they show partial end-game decay of cooperation, but not a strict backward-induction style collapse.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is willing to punish and at times punishes quite heavily relative to their own payoff, but only in a subset of cooperative rounds. They never punish when they themselves defect; all observed punishment occurs when they are cooperating. This is consistent with a norm-enforcing or frustration-driven pattern: they are more likely to punish when they perceive themselves as “doing their part” and others not following suit.

Their punishment is not continuous or automatic. They sometimes cooperate in the presence of clear free-riders and do not punish at all, and at other times, in similarly mixed environments, they invest substantial resources into punishment. This inconsistency suggests that punishment is not governed by a strict threshold rule (e.g., “punish all defectors”); instead, it may be driven by situational emotion, salience of low contributors, or occasional attempts to reset group norms.

Punishment episodes are sizable relative to their own income in those rounds, indicating they are at least temporarily willing to trade off personal payoff to sanction others. Because we do not observe the distribution of their punishment across specific peers, their selectivity toward particular individuals is unknown. However, the fact that they never punish while defecting themselves argues against “pure spite” or random aggression; they appear to reserve costly sanctions for situations in which they see themselves as justified enforcers rather than simultaneous free-riders.

Given that punishment is identifiable, they must anticipate possible retaliation, yet they still engage in it on multiple occasions. This implies either a taste for norm-enforcement or a belief that the deterrence/teaching effect outweighs the risk of being punished back. Whether their punishment actually changes others’ contributions is unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
The player is punished multiple times across the game, including in some rounds where they cooperate and some where they defect. Their response to being punished does not show clear compliance or clear retaliation.

They do not reliably increase contributions after being punished; in some cases, they subsequently defect, and in others they later cooperate again under different conditions. Thus, punishment does not lock them into cooperation. At the same time, they do not exhibit obvious counter-punishment patterns: they never punish in rounds where they are defecting, and they do not increase their use of punishment immediately after receiving deductions in a way that would clearly signal revenge. Because the identity of their punishers is not provided in the transcript, whether they specifically target those individuals is unknown and confidence in any retaliation inference is low.

More broadly, the player appears relatively thick-skinned regarding punishment. They continue to free-ride in later rounds despite having been sanctioned earlier, indicating they are not easily cowed into permanent cooperative compliance. Nor do they abandon cooperation entirely after being punished while cooperating; they still choose full contribution in later rounds. This suggests a pragmatic stance: punishment is treated as one data point in a noisy environment rather than a binding signal to change strategy.

Overall, their response to punishers mixes partial disregard (they keep defecting when profitable) with occasional cooperative choices that are not tightly coupled to prior sanctions. They neither strongly appease nor systematically retaliate; instead, they maintain their opportunistic, mixed strategy largely independent of who has punished them before.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a conditional, oscillating contributor who mixes full cooperation with full free-riding rather than using intermediate levels. They alternate between contributing everything and nothing, and this pattern persists across the game rather than converging to a stable single mode. They are willing to contribute fully even when the group average is low, suggesting either an experimental or hopeful stance toward cooperation, but they are also comfortable exploiting situations where many others contribute while they do not. Their behavior shows no simple “tit-for-tat” rule; instead, they shift modes repeatedly even when the surrounding contribution pattern looks similar across episodes. They appear sensitive to payoff incentives: when non-contribution yields much higher payoffs, they are willing to free-ride, and when the environment is noisy or low-contributing, they sometimes still invest fully, perhaps to test whether cooperation can be sustained or to hedge between moral and monetary motives. Fairness norms are mixed: they sometimes act like a high contributor in a low-contributing group (accepting disadvantage), and at other times they act like a pure free-rider in a high-contributing environment (accepting advantage), so any stable equity preference is unknown. Risk tolerance is moderate to high: they repeatedly choose the dominated cooperative action in an environment where others often contribute little, but they also repeatedly take the safe selfish option when that is clearly profitable.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no clear last-round “grab everything” pivot, because they already alternate between full giving and full keeping earlier in the game. They continue to use the same binary pattern of full contribution or none in the final phase, with no obvious monotonic decay of cooperation. They remain willing to fully cooperate in late rounds even after experiencing punishment as a free-rider, and they also still free-ride in some late rounds, so horizon effects on their behavior are muted or masked by their pre-existing oscillation. They seem aware of the game length (by design), but there is no sharp strategic shift tied to the approaching end; instead, they keep experimenting with both cooperative and selfish actions until the very last round. Their forward-looking reasoning style and beliefs about end-game unraveling are therefore unknown or at best low-confidence: behavior is consistent with a player who either does not fully apply backward induction or chooses to ignore it.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use the punishment mechanism at any point, despite repeated exposure to low contributors and despite themselves being punished multiple times. They thus appear highly reluctant to spend resources on sanctioning, whether for deterrence, norm enforcement, or retaliation. This is not due to lack of opportunity: they encounter clear defections and also face situations where others punish them, yet still refrain from punishing. This suggests either that they view punishment as too costly, ineffective, or not worth the effort, or that they place little value on enforcing cooperative norms relative to preserving their own payoff. Their motives—whether purely self-interested cost avoidance, aversion to hurting others, or skepticism about punishment’s effectiveness—are unknown, but their revealed strategy is consistent: ignore the sanctioning tool and adjust only their own contribution decisions.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When punished, they do not retaliate; they consistently continue to spend nothing on punishment after being targeted. Their later actions mix cooperation and free-riding, so it is unclear whether they interpret punishment as a normative signal or merely as noise. Sometimes after being punished as a free-rider they later choose to contribute fully; at other times they resume or maintain free-riding, so there is no clear compliance pattern strictly tied to sanctions. They also never appear to single out any identifiable punisher for counter-punishment (or any punishment at all), indicating a non-confrontational stance and a high degree of forgiveness or indifference toward being sanctioned. Whether this reflects genuine tolerance, strategic avoidance of costly feuds, or simple inertia is unknown, but their type is best characterized as “non-retaliatory and sanction-insensitive.”

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional high contributor. They always contribute their full endowment, never deviating even when others free ride or partially defect. Their cooperation does not appear contingent on others’ behavior: they continue to contribute fully when some players give nothing, and also when everyone cooperates. They show no visible attempt to fine-tune contributions in response to individual defectors, instead treating contribution as a fixed norm. This suggests a strong intrinsic or norm-based preference for full cooperation rather than payoff-maximizing calculus. Risk tolerance appears high regarding potential exploitation: they persist with full contributions despite repeated evidence that at least one player is free riding and sometimes being rewarded overall. Fairness norms are present but are not expressed through adjusting their own contribution level; instead, fairness concerns show up in their initial punishment choice (see below) rather than in withholding contributions.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player never sends any chat messages. They neither initiate coordination nor respond verbally to others’ attempts at persuasion, humor, or social bonding. They are completely silent despite an active, social, and sometimes playful group chat environment. This is consistent with a highly task-focused or low-engagement communication style. They may be strategically “quiet cooperative”: participating through actions only, letting contribution and sanctioning speak for itself. There is no evidence of explicit norm signaling, emotional expression, or alliance-building through chat. Their non-participation in jokes and meta-discussion suggests either disinterest, deliberate neutrality, or a preference to avoid social influence or conflict in communication channels. Overall, they are behaviorally engaged but socially silent.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player’s cooperative strategy shows no end-game decay. They maintain full contributions through the final rounds, even when it is common-knowledge that the game is about to end. They do not appear to shift into selfish extraction near the end, and they also do not suddenly intensify use of punishment or reward as the horizon approaches. Their pattern of not using sanctions after the first period continues unchanged into the last period. This indicates that their cooperation is not driven primarily by long-term reciprocity or future-oriented incentives; instead, they behave as if full contribution is the appropriate action regardless of remaining rounds. Awareness of the horizon is given in the interface, but there is no behavioral sign that they strategically respond to it.

<PUNISHMENT>
They punish only once and very heavily, targeting a player who contributed fully but was already being massively punished by others. They spend a substantial amount of their own payoff to further increase that player’s deductions. After this, they never punish again, even though several players later contribute nothing in multiple rounds. This single, early, high-intensity punishment is not obviously efficiency-oriented: the target is not a low contributor in that round, and the marginal deterrent value of further punishment is arguably low given the already extreme level imposed by others. The behavior fits a “bandwagon” or “pile-on” pattern: joining a collective punishment episode rather than independently evaluating contribution behavior that round. There is no evidence of targeted, proportional sanctioning tied strictly to current free riding; instead, the one observed punishment is extreme, socially aligned with others’ hostility to the same player, and then discontinued entirely. After this event, they seem to refrain from all further punitive action, even when future behavior (e.g., zero contributions by several players) would provide clear justifications under standard conditional-cooperation norms. Their punishment style is thus: highly willing to spend a lot in an initial social-punishment cascade, but not systematically enforcing norms thereafter. Motivation is ambiguous; it could be driven by early affect/identity cues from chat (others labeling someone negatively) rather than strictly by current contribution levels. Confidence on the exact motive is low.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They are never punished in the transcript. Consequently, their response to being punished is unknown. There is no evidence on whether they would retaliate, comply by changing contributions, or ignore sanctions if they occurred.

<REWARD>
They never allocate rewards to anyone, despite many players contributing fully and some others using reward as positive reinforcement. They forgo low-cost opportunities to strengthen cooperation or reciprocate kindness through the reward channel, even when they themselves receive rewards. This consistent non-use of rewards suggests they either do not value the reward mechanism, prefer to conserve coins once the initial punishment burst is over, or treat contributions as self-sufficient signals that do not require extra reinforcement. There is no selective rewarding of high contributors, no alliance-like reward patterns, and no final-round “thank you” rewarding. The absence of any reward behavior contrasts with their early willingness to spend heavily on punishment, pointing toward a sanctioning style that is skewed (when active) toward negative rather than positive incentives.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive small rewards in at least some rounds from several others, but they never reciprocate via rewards. They also do not shift their sanction behavior in favor of those who rewarded them, nor do they start rewarding cooperators more generally. Their contribution behavior remains unchanged (always full), and their punishment/reward behavior remains minimal after the first round. This indicates that they do not use the reward channel for reciprocity or alliance building, at least within the observed game. Their response to being rewarded is essentially behavioral inertia: they keep cooperating but do not “pay back” through the same mechanism. Whether they feel gratitude privately is unknown; observable reciprocity in rewards is absent.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They see detailed information about others’ payoffs, punishment, and reward flows. Their one major behavioral response to others’ outcomes is joining an early, extreme collective punishment episode against a single player who ends with a large negative payoff due to group sanctions. They contribute to that outcome by adding significant punishment of their own. After that, they do not visibly react to later variations in others’ outcomes: they do not step in to punish later free riders or to support cooperators with rewards, even when others clearly spend on such actions. They also do not alter their own contributions in response to any pattern of outcomes; they keep contributing fully regardless of who is being rewarded or punished and how payoffs are distributed. This suggests that they attend to others’ outcomes enough to join a salient early punishment cascade but then settle into a “cooperate and ignore” stance where payoff heterogeneity and sanction patterns no longer drive their behavior. Their sensitivity to social information seems front-loaded and not dynamically updated across later rounds, or at least does not manifest in further strategic changes.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional high contributor. They always contribute the full endowment, never deviating even when some others contribute nothing or when free-riding is repeatedly visible. Their behavior aligns with a strong efficiency and cooperation norm: they appear to prioritize maximizing the group return over exploiting others. They show no evidence of conditional cooperation (they do not scale contributions down in response to defectors, nor up relative to others); instead they follow a simple “always all-in” rule. They seem comfortable bearing the risk of being exploited by low contributors and do not attempt to hedge against defection. Fairness concerns, if present, do not translate into adjusting contributions; they rely on other mechanisms (chiefly social norms and possibly punishment by others) to handle unfairness rather than altering their own cooperative stance.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is sparse, light, and affiliative rather than strategic. They greet others implicitly by joining in with the group’s “all in” norm and later explicitly endorse that norm with a brief statement supporting full contributions every time. They also participate in the playful “we are robots” banter with a humorous remark, signaling sociability and a desire to fit into the group mood rather than to lead or criticize. They do not directly confront low contributors or direct others to punish or reward; instead they echo the cooperative consensus that has already formed. They do not initiate substantive coordination about punishment or rewards, and they avoid moralistic or aggressive language. Overall, they engage enough to be seen as part of the cooperative in-group, but they do not attempt to shape group strategy in a forceful or detailed way.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show no end-game decay in cooperation. Their contribution level remains at the maximum right through the final round, even as the horizon becomes short and others continue to free-ride intermittently. They do not switch to opportunistic behavior despite having no future rounds in which to rebuild reputation or benefit from reciprocity. There is no evidence that they try to exploit last-round anonymity or to recoup earlier losses. This suggests either a rule-based or principled commitment to cooperation that is insensitive to the finite horizon, or at least a choice not to condition on it in practice. Their use of punishment and rewards does not intensify or strategically change at the end; after an early punishment they remain inactive in the sanctioning stage through the remainder of the game, including in the final round.

<PUNISHMENT>
They punish exactly once, targeting a player who contributes fully in that period and has not clearly deviated in that round. The amount is minimal in the context of the game and is extremely small relative to the much larger punishment this target receives from others. The trigger for this punishment is ambiguous: it does not clearly correspond to immediate free-riding or to a contemporaneous breach of a cooperation norm. This makes the motive uncertain: it could be a mistaken click, a playful or bandwagon response to emerging hostility toward that player, or a weak expression of disapproval for prior noncooperative behavior. After this single act, they refrain from using punishment altogether, even when standard free-riding targets reappear and other players continue to punish them. They never engage in retaliatory punishment; they themselves are never punished, so their tolerance for personal provocation is unknown. Overall, they are best described as a very low-intensity, non-escalating punisher whose willingness to spend on punishment is limited and not clearly strategic.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They are never punished by any other player in the observed game, so their direct response to being punished is unknown. There is no evidence of preemptive appeasement or of retaliatory tendencies because they do not face any deductions. Their steady high contributions and non-use of late punishment suggest they are not trying to signal toughness or a readiness to retaliate, but this is inference with low confidence because no direct provocation occurs.

<REWARD>
They never spend any resources on rewards. Even when others cooperate fully and some players reward them or other cooperators, they provide no positive reinforcement through the costly reward mechanism. This could reflect a preference to conserve payoff, skepticism about the efficacy of rewards, cognitive load/neglect of the reward option, or a belief that cooperation should be its own norm without needing side payments. Given that their contributions remain maximally cooperative, their lack of rewarding is not driven by selfish exploitation of others’ efforts, but rather by an apparent choice to rely on contribution behavior (and possibly group punishment) as the main cooperative device rather than spending additional coins on positive incentives.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive a small reward from another player once. After that, they do not reciprocate with rewards to that player or to anyone else in subsequent rounds, nor do they change their contribution pattern (which was already fully cooperative). Their polite and humorous chat style suggests they are not hostile to the rewarder, but behaviorally they show no observable payoff-based reciprocity in the reward stage. They also do not publicly acknowledge or comment on having been rewarded, so any private feeling of gratitude is unobserved. In terms of observable strategy, they treat being rewarded as non-diagnostic: it does not alter their sanctioning decisions or their cooperative rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They appear relatively indifferent, behaviorally, to the detailed payoff and punishment/reward distributions of others. They see several cycles where specific low contributors are heavily punished by many players, and where some cooperators reward each other, yet they almost never join in sanctioning and never adjust their own contribution level. They do not speak up in chat to endorse or condemn the severity of punishment or the generosity of rewards, focusing instead on general cooperation slogans and light banter. They show no sign of targeting high earners, low earners, or heavy punishers/rewarders with any systematic pattern. The one early punishment they impose does not clearly track contemporaneous deviations, and they do not follow up on that target later even when that player’s outcomes remain salient. Overall, they attend enough to know that “all in” is good for the group and to participate in group identity talk, but they do not appear to engage in fine-grained tracking or management of others’ outcomes.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits a “strategic free-rider with intermittent reciprocity” type. They understand that the group return on contributions is high, and they are clearly *willing* to contribute fully, but only in selected moments and not as a stable norm.

Their contributions are highly volatile rather than consistent. They alternate between:
- full contributions,
- complete free-riding,
- and occasional intermediate amounts.

They reliably contribute more when there is a current or recent norm of high contributions from others, and they frequently drop to zero when others are also contributing substantially. This pattern suggests conditional cooperation in *timing* (joining or sustaining cooperative phases) mixed with opportunistic exploitation once a cooperative environment is in place.

They do not display a simple “tit-for-tat” response to any single individual; instead, their behavior appears keyed to the *overall* contribution climate. They sometimes rejoin high cooperation even after having just exploited others, indicating they value group efficiency or fairness at least intermittently, but they are willing to accept being the main beneficiary of the public good when they see that others continue to contribute.

There is no evidence they are strongly fairness-driven in a strict, consistent sense; they tolerate repeatedly earning more than cooperative peers. At the same time, they are not a pure low-contributor type: they repeatedly take on personally costly, high contributions even when free-riding is available. This points to mixed motives: some concern for group welfare or norm-following, combined with strong payoff-seeking.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to be the high contributor even when some group members are clearly free-riding, which risks ending up exploited, but they also periodically hedge by keeping all their own endowment. The pattern looks more like strategic cycling than random noise.

Overall, they are best modeled as a sophisticated conditional cooperator who opportunistically times free-riding rather than adhering to a principled cooperative rule.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is sparse, direct, and cooperative at the outset. They immediately endorse a full-contribution plan proposed by another player and do so without hedging or negotiation. This shows readiness to coordinate around an efficient, pro-social norm when prompted by others, but they do not take a leadership role in proposing norms themselves.

After that brief agreement, they remain silent for the rest of the game. They do not defend, justify, or explain their later free-riding, nor do they confront others about low contributions. This suggests a low-engagement or low-disclosure style: they prefer to adapt silently rather than manage social impressions or argue about fairness.

They are clearly reading the chat (since they respond once early), but there is no evidence they try to persuade, shame, or rally people in later phases. Socially, they come across as understated and pragmatic rather than expressive. Their willingness to initially endorse “everyone contributes everything” alongside later quiet free-riding indicates they do not strongly internalize the social commitments expressed in chat, or they are comfortable deviating without explanation once conditions change.

In terms of tone, their single message is neutral and cooperative. There is no observable hostility, sarcasm, or moralizing; beyond the initial assent to a cooperative norm, their communication gives little signal about their personality or emotional state. Motivation and reasoning must be inferred primarily from their contribution behavior rather than their words.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show awareness of the finite horizon in a behavioral sense: near the end, they do not shift into a pure “endgame free-ride everything” strategy. Instead, they continue to use mixed contributions, including both low and high amounts, right up to the final decision.

In the closing phase, they at times free-ride while many others contribute heavily, and at other times they themselves contribute fully when others also do so. This indicates that their behavior is not driven solely by backwards induction logic or simple endgame unraveling. They do not display a clear monotonic decay of cooperation toward the end; if anything, they sustain or even revive high contributions in the last decision.

This pattern suggests:
- They may not be strategically optimizing specifically for the very last round.
- They may still care about maintaining or re-establishing a cooperative environment even when no future interaction is left.
- Alternatively, they may simply be following the same conditional/mixed rule throughout, without giving special weight to the horizon.

Because they do not comment on the number of rounds or on upcoming termination, their explicit beliefs about the end-game are unknown. Behaviorally, though, they are not a classic “end-game defector”: they continue to cooperate substantially in the final decisions despite knowing the game is about to end.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They appear to closely observe others’ contributions and resulting payoffs, but they never verbalize any reaction to individual outcomes. They neither praise high contributors nor complain about free-riders. There is no direct social sanctioning or reward through words, and no mechanism exists in this game for monetary punishment or reward, so all their responses must be inferred from their own subsequent contribution choices.

Behaviorally, they are comfortable allowing others to earn less while they profit from free-riding. When many others contribute high amounts and accept lower private payoffs, they do not move immediately to “correct” this inequality; instead, they often maintain or adopt zero contributions and enjoy the payoff advantage. This tolerance for asymmetric outcomes suggests that envy or guilt, if present, are not strong enough to override their opportunistic play.

However, they also sometimes take on the role of high contributor when others are also investing heavily, even though they have previously seen that such generosity can lead to them earning less than free-riders. This indicates that they are not purely outcome-maximizing in a myopic sense; they are willing to join the cooperative set even after having observed its vulnerability to exploitation. They may believe that re-creating or sustaining a high-contribution environment is still worthwhile for overall group returns, or they may place some intrinsic value on “doing their part” under the right conditions.

There is no sign that they adjust contributions in a targeted way in response to any particular player’s payoff; their responses track the *aggregate* pattern of contributions and payoffs rather than focusing on specific individuals. Emotional reactions such as resentment, sympathy, or moral approval are not expressed in chat, so their inner attitudes toward others’ outcomes remain unknown. The safest inference is that they primarily treat others’ outcomes as information about how cooperative the environment is and whether it is currently profitable or safe for them to either contribute or free-ride.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a flexible, opportunistic contributor who frequently alternates between full contribution and full free-riding. They do not lock into a stable pattern: they sometimes join high-contribution environments and sometimes defect even when others contribute heavily. Their decisions are not purely selfish; they occasionally contribute when many others defect and also defect when others cooperate, suggesting that matching or fairness is not their primary rule. Instead, they appear to treat contribution as one tool among several for influencing group dynamics, not as a moral commitment.

They show no simple conditional rule like “I contribute if most others do” or “I contribute if I was punished.” They contribute in both cooperative and defect-heavy contexts, and they also free-ride in both. This indicates low adherence to a straightforward fairness norm such as strict conditional cooperation. Risk tolerance for social sanctions is moderate: they continue to alternate between contributing and defecting even when they are repeatedly punished, implying they accept or discount the risk of further sanctions rather than strictly complying.

Overall, their contribution behavior fits an “experimenting enforcer” type: they treat their own contribution as secondary to their influence via punishment and reward, and they are willing to bear being seen as a defector at times.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not lead to a simple end-game collapse or pure exploitation. In the final segment of the game they still mix contributions and defections and continue to use both costly punishment and reward, including in the very last round. They do not switch to purely selfish play or stop investing in social control when no future rounds remain, indicating that immediate material payoff is not their sole driver.

There is no visible trend toward systematically increasing or decreasing cooperation as the end approaches; instead, their pattern of alternating between contribution and free-riding persists. The continued willingness to spend on sanctions in the final rounds suggests they value expressing norms or “finishing the game right” over maximizing final-round income. This points to a stable preference for norm enforcement and signaling, rather than a strategy tightly optimized to the horizon.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a very heavy and frequent user of punishment. They impose sanctions in most rounds where the mechanism is available and often spend substantial amounts to do so. Their punishment is not narrowly focused on classic free-riders; they sometimes punish high contributors and sometimes punish defectors, and they target both frequent cooperators and frequent low contributors. This indicates that their criteria for punishment go beyond simple “punish non-contributors.”

Their targeting suggests several intertwined motives:

- **Norm enforcement with a personal twist:** They regularly punish clear non-contributors who benefit from others’ cooperation, which is consistent with enforcing a contribution norm. At the same time, they also punish some cooperators and some players who appear neutral, which implies their norm is idiosyncratic, possibly based on a richer mental record of who has been “good” or “bad” earlier, including past punishment or reward decisions.

- **Retaliation and score-settling:** They are themselves punished by multiple others, yet they persist in sanctioning those same players or their perceived allies. Because punishers are identifiable, the repetition of punishment against certain names, including some who have already been punished heavily by others, points to retaliatory or vindictive elements rather than purely forward-looking deterrence.

- **Willingness to bear large costs:** They repeatedly spend on punishment even when it significantly reduces their own payoff in that round, and they do not stop doing so after experiencing large deductions from others. This shows a strong willingness to incur personal cost to impose harm, consistent with strong negative reciprocity and/or spite toward perceived norm violators.

Selectivity is present but loose: they do not punish everyone, and they frequently pick out specific subsets of players each round. The pattern suggests they track reputations and use punishment both as a tool to express disapproval and as a way to “balance accounts,” rather than following a simple mechanical rule based only on current-round contributions.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When punished, this player does not show clear compliance by aligning their behavior with punishers’ apparent preferences. Instead, they continue to alternate between contribution and free-riding and to use heavy punishment themselves. There is no consistent move toward safer, more conformist behavior after being targeted. This indicates low responsiveness to punishment as a deterrent and low deference to others’ attempts at control.

They also do not clearly stop punishing those who punish them; some of their punishment choices are consistent with retaliating against players who had previously imposed costs on them, but the mapping is not one-to-one and cannot be asserted with high confidence. Overall, however, their persistent and sometimes escalating sanctioning despite being hit themselves suggests they are not easily cowed and may even regard being punished as part of a conflict they are willing to continue.

Forgiveness versus grudges remains ambiguous. Because they both punish and reward many of the same players across time, it is unclear whether they actively forgive past punishers or simply follow a complex internal ledger that sometimes results in positive and sometimes in negative actions toward the same counterpart. Confidence in attributing a stable forgiving or unforgiving stance is low; the safest description is that they are not punishment-averse and do not visibly “back down” in response to being sanctioned.

<REWARD>
This player is also a frequent and substantial user of reward, although less single-mindedly than punishment. They spend notable amounts to reward others across many rounds. Their rewards are directed both to high contributors and to some low contributors, and sometimes to players who are themselves frequent punishers or rewarders. This shows that their rewards are not purely based on current-round contribution levels.

The pattern suggests multiple motives:

- **Positive reinforcement of perceived allies or behaviors:** They often reward players who appear cooperative or who may have treated them well (e.g., by rewarding them or refraining from punishing them). This points to conditional kindness: they use rewards to encourage or maintain alliances and to reinforce behaviors they like.

- **Balancing and signaling:** They sometimes reward players who are simultaneously being heavily punished by others, and they occasionally reward players they themselves have punished in other rounds. This indicates that they use reward to fine-tune their stance toward individuals, signaling nuance (“I disapprove of some things, but I still credit you for others”) rather than treating punishment and reward as mutually exclusive.

- **Low efficiency concern:** Given that here reward has much weaker leverage than punishment, a payoff-maximizer would use punishment for deterrence and rarely reward. This player nevertheless invests substantially in rewards, suggesting that they are motivated by expressive or relational concerns (gratitude, alliance-building, or fairness adjustments) more than by strict cost-benefit efficiency.

Overall, their reward behavior is generous but strategic: they seem to maintain a mental map of who is “on their side” or promoting the kind of group they prefer and use rewards to support those players, even when the mechanism is relatively weak.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
When rewarded, this player does not exhibit a simple, consistent reciprocity rule, but there are hints of gratitude or alliance-building. They often reward players who themselves are active in the reward system, and they include frequent rewarders among their positive targets in later decisions. However, the evidence is not strong enough to claim a strict “I reward those who reward me” strategy; many of their reward and punishment choices do not map cleanly onto who has helped or hurt them most recently.

They do not clearly shift their contribution behavior upward in response to being rewarded, nor do they consistently protect rewarders from future punishment. This suggests that, while they may feel and express some gratitude, their internal ledger blends many factors (contribution history, punishment history, others’ treatment by the group) rather than simple direct reciprocity. Their response to being rewarded is therefore best described as partially reciprocal and relational, but noisy: they are open to alliances, yet they do not subordinate their broader norm-enforcement agenda to any one relationship.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player appears highly attentive to others’ contributions, payoffs, and sanctioning patterns. They adjust their punishment and reward targets in ways that reflect an active reading of who is currently being hurt, who is benefiting, and who is spending on sanctions. They sometimes support players who are otherwise being heavily punished by others, and they sometimes pile additional punishment onto players already under group pressure. This indicates that they track not only raw contributions but also social standing and recent treatment.

They often reward players whose outcomes suggest cooperation or costly generosity and punish those whose outcomes suggest repeated free-riding or aggressive sanctioning. However, because they sometimes sanction cooperators and reward low contributors, they are evidently using a more complex evaluation than “cooperation good, defection bad.” They may weigh perceived fairness across multiple rounds, viewing certain highly successful players as deserving of correction if their success is seen as coming at the group’s expense or through overuse of punishment.

Overall, their reaction to others’ outcomes is that of an active, opinionated social accountant: they use the detailed feedback on contributions, sanctions, and payoffs to maintain a mental reputation system and to continually adjust who they punish or reward. They accept substantial personal cost to act on these judgments, prioritizing the expression and enforcement of their idiosyncratic norms over maximizing their own monetary outcome.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, near-unconditional cooperator. They almost always contribute the full endowment despite many free riders being present and despite frequent personal punishment. Defection is extremely rare and appears only in two isolated rounds, not as part of a trend. Their cooperation is only weakly conditional on others’ behavior: they continue to contribute when low contributors and zero contributors persist in the group, and when they themselves are targeted. They seem to follow a strong norm that “one should cooperate with the group” even when it is not payoff-maximizing. They tolerate substantial exploitation and do not attempt to protect themselves by systematically reducing contributions when others free ride. This pattern suggests a fairness or efficiency norm that prioritizes the public good over short-run personal gain, combined with high risk tolerance regarding being the “sucker” who contributes when others do not. They do not appear to be experimenting with contributions; their behavior is stable and rule-like rather than exploratory.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player remains cooperative through the final round. There is no clear contribution decay as the horizon approaches; instead, they continue to provide full contributions even when many others visibly defect late in the game and when they receive strong end-game punishment for defecting once. Their rare defections do not cluster strictly at the end; the last round returns to full cooperation. On the sanctioning side, they continue to use punishment and reward mechanisms late into the game, including targeted punishment in the final round, indicating they remain engaged in norm enforcement rather than “cashing out” or ceasing to invest in costly social control. This suggests they either discount the end-game structure or deliberately ignore backward-induction logic in favor of maintaining norms until the very end.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is a frequent and targeted punisher. They consistently punish a persistent low contributor (PINGUIN) across many rounds, even when that player is heavily punished by others, indicating a strong anti-free-rider stance rather than a one-off reaction. They also punish another low-contributing player (CROCODILE) on selected occasions, particularly when that player combines low contributions with complex punishment/reward behavior toward others. Their punishment of high free riders is more systematic than their punishment of medium contributors; they do not punish cooperators, and they almost never punish ambiguous or borderline cases. This selectivity points to norm-enforcement and deterrence motives: they target those who repeatedly contribute nothing while benefiting from the group. They are willing to absorb sizable personal costs to continue this punishment stream, showing low sensitivity to the personal cost effectiveness of punishment and high commitment to enforcing a cooperative standard. In one notable exception, they punish a previously cooperative player (SLOTH) in the final round after that player has been zero-contributing intermittently and also engaging in heavy sanctioning. This end-game punishment appears consistent with punishing defectors rather than random retaliation: they do not appear to use punishment against those who punished them, and there is no clear pattern of counter-punishment toward their own punishers. Overall, they use punishment as a consistent, morally driven tool against chronic free riders, not as an emotional response to being targeted.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They are repeatedly punished by several others, including for both cooperative and defective rounds, and sometimes quite harshly. Their behavioral response is strikingly non-retaliatory: they never clearly punish someone simply because that party punished them earlier, and they do not switch to targeting those who sanction them. Instead, they keep punishing the same norm-violating free riders and keep cooperating in contributions. There is no strong evidence that punishment toward them causes sustained contribution reductions; they defect once after having been a persistent cooperator, are heavily punished, and then return to high contributions. When they are punished in rounds where they cooperate, they neither respond with counter-punishment nor with social withdrawal (e.g., serial defection). This indicates high forgiveness or at least a strong separation in their mind between “who punished me” and “who is violating the contribution norm.” They appear to interpret punishment directed at themselves as part of the general noisy sanctioning environment rather than as a signal to change targets or form vendettas. Compliance-wise, they do not clearly adjust their target selection in favor of their punishers or away from them; they stay focused on chronic low contributors.

<REWARD>
The player is a regular and selective rewarder, but much less intense in rewarding than in punishing. They spend on rewards for clear high contributors and for especially prosocial players, often reinforcing those who repeatedly contribute fully and sometimes also engage in prosocial sanctioning. Reward targets include consistently cooperative players and those who have rewarded or supported cooperation in others, indicating a mix of gratitude and reinforcement motives. They almost never reward low contributors, and when a previous free rider begins contributing or stops misbehaving, the player sometimes withholds further punishment but does not immediately move into rewarding them; their rewards are more clearly tied to ongoing, visible cooperation than to one-off improvements. They accept the poor cost-effectiveness of the reward technology and still use it, suggesting a preference for norm reinforcement and positive signaling over simple earnings maximization. Over time, they refine reward targets somewhat, tending to reward a small subset of the most dependable cooperators rather than distributing rewards widely.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards in various rounds from multiple others, yet their reward behavior does not obviously track who has previously rewarded them. They do not build explicit bilateral “alliances” of mutual rewarding; instead, they reward based on perceived overall contribution and cooperativeness. There is no clear tit-for-tat reciprocation of reward to any specific individual that can be tied to a prior incoming reward from that same individual. This suggests that gratitude, while possibly present, is filtered through their underlying norm-based criteria: they appear to value sustained cooperative conduct more than personal kindness toward themselves. Being rewarded does not shift their punishment targets away from free riders nor does it induce them to preferentially protect or defend their rewarders; their sanctioning decisions remain focused on contribution behavior. Overall, their response to being rewarded is to maintain their cooperative and norm-enforcing strategy rather than to shift into alliance-based reciprocity.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They pay close attention to who is contributing and who is not, and they appear to track how others use the punishment and reward mechanisms. Their persistent focus on the same chronic free rider shows that they extrapolate from repeated low contributions to a stable “type” and act accordingly. They seem unperturbed by others’ high payoffs when those payoffs come from cooperation; they even reinforce such players with rewards. Conversely, when free riders maintain relatively high payoffs despite frequent punishment, the player continues to sanction them rather than disengaging, suggesting they are monitoring outcomes and concluding that more enforcement is warranted. They do not appear jealous of high-earning cooperators; instead, they treat them as partners in maintaining a cooperative environment. When observing complex sanctioning by others (for example, other players heavily punishing multiple targets), they do not automatically join those sanctioning campaigns; their response remains anchored in observed contribution patterns rather than in how much someone is spending on punishment or reward. In late game, when others escalate punishment intensity and some players incur severe losses through sanctioning, this player does not mirror that escalation; they keep costs moderate and targets stable. This restraint supports a personality profile of a principled norm enforcer who is attentive to patterns in others’ behavior but resists being drawn into cycles of escalating hostility.

title: Moderate contributors who adjust giving based on group behavior and personal incentives

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a primarily cooperative, mildly opportunistic contributor who generally follows the group norm of full contribution but occasionally free-rides when it seems unlikely to be noticed or sanctioned.

They overwhelmingly choose the maximal contribution option and maintain this across most of the game, even when others sometimes deviate. This suggests they accept the cooperative norm and are comfortable giving up the private endowment when they expect the group to do the same. Their contributions do not collapse over time; they repeatedly return to full contribution after deviations by others, so they do not display strong conditional cooperation in the sense of punishing defectors by systematically lowering their own contributions.

At a few points they contribute nothing despite high or near-unanimous contributions from others. These choices are infrequent and not followed by any explanation in chat, but they coincide with periods when overall cooperation is already strong and when the player is not being singled out in discussion. This pattern is consistent with occasional strategic free-riding: taking advantage of others’ contributions once a high-cooperation norm is established, while relying on the fact that no explicit sanction or tracking mechanism exists.

They do not verbally advocate for any contribution rule, do not try to enforce fairness norms, and do not publicly criticize low contributors. Their behavior suggests they internally value the higher payoffs from mutual cooperation but are also attentive to personal payoff maximization and willing to defect quietly when the social or reputational cost appears low. Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to continue contributing even when some others defect, implying they are not highly loss-averse about “wasted” contributions, yet they also hedge with a few free-riding moves rather than naively contributing every time.
