They are moderately chatty and clearly engaged with the group, but not the dominant voice. Tone is warm, humorous, and prosocial. They align themselves with the cooperative majority, support emerging norms, and occasionally inject light jokes about the game’s length and “living here now,” which shows comfort and social ease rather than detachment or hostility.

They respond to others’ points (e.g., acknowledging correction about player count, agreeing that some behavior “makes sense,” echoing “sus” judgments about potentially problematic avatars) rather than driving their own agenda. They rarely initiate new strategic norms, but they reinforce existing ones and lend social support to those enforcing cooperation.

They participate in the shared narrative about the “angry bird/parrot” and researchers, appear to enjoy the collective theorizing, and use that narrative as a frame for behavior (“kill the bird,” “very sus”). They are not confrontational; even when advocating retaliation against the disruptive avatar, their style remains playful and collective (“have a little boost; kill the bird”) rather than aggressive or moralizing.

Overall, they show a cooperative, affiliative, and group-oriented communication style: they help maintain cohesion, validate others, and keep the mood light, while staying aligned with cooperative norms.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are willing to punish, but only selectively and under strong social consensus. For most of the game they refrain from using punishment at all despite repeated calls from others to “ding” under-contributors and the disruptive bird. This indicates an underlying reluctance to spend on punishment or a preference to let others take that role when it is already being filled.

They eventually do punish, and their target choice is tightly norm-based: they punish the clearly non-compliant “angry bird/parrot,” and much later again target the same avatar in a mixed punishment/reward move. They do not punish borderline contributors, slight deviations, or human cooperators who make small mistakes. There is no evidence of spite, personal vendetta, or punishment directed at group members who question the experiment or pay rates.

Their punishment seems motivated by collective justice and norm enforcement rather than personal gain: they punish when the bird is viewed as an unfair, possibly non-human exploiter, and they frame it in chat as something that “has to change” and that “they’ll feel.” They join the coordinated “hit the bird” moments but do not escalate beyond what others are doing, and they do not continue punishing once the bird is heavily sanctioned and group attention drifts.

Deterrence and moral signaling appear more important than maximizing their own payoff. However, they do not turn into a “perma police”; they remain a mostly cooperative, low-punishment type who intervenes episodically when the group norm and their own sense of fairness are strongly violated.

<REWARD>
They are distinctly more inclined to use reward than punishment, especially early on. They reward only a few times, which makes those choices informative. Recipients of their rewards are consistently high contributors and/or victims/allies in the bird drama: players who cooperate fully and either suffer from unjust deductions or invest heavily in group justice. They use reward to top up allies and to reinforce prosocial behavior.

They never reward low contributors or the bird. They are not using reward to manipulate future play (no evidence of “reward to make defectors cooperate”); instead, they behave like a conditional altruist who uses reward to recognize and bolster existing cooperators and justice enforcers. At the same time, they show sympathy for fellow participants who are harmed or targeted unfairly, and they explicitly point out when game pay and bonus conversion rates seem low, indicating they map in-game coins to real money and care about distributive fairness beyond simple in-game scores. They appear to update their beliefs about the deviant from “maybe researcher/bot” to “high earner exploiting a glitch or mechanism” and adjust their punishment stance accordingly. When others begin to feel punished or exploited by the platform (e.g., comments about underpayment, long duration), the player voices agreement but does not pivot to self-serving behavior; instead they maintain full contributions and only modest, targeted punishment. Overall, their responses to others’ outcomes show they are fairness-oriented, attentive to relative payoffs, and willing to adapt enforcement behavior when outcome patterns reveal persistent exploitation, while still preserving a cooperative baseline.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable high contributor. They give the maximum in essentially all rounds, with a single deliberate low-contribution “test” when the whole group temporarily deviates from full cooperation. They appear to adopt a norm of “everyone should give max” and largely stick to it regardless of others’ occasional shortfalls. The brief low contribution happens exactly when many others drop their contributions and collective norms wobble; after that, the player immediately returns to maximum giving and stays there. They do not visibly condition their contribution on individual others’ behavior; instead, they behave as if contributing fully is the right thing to do for the group, even when some individuals (e.g., the anomalous bird) undercontribute or free-ride. This suggests a principled cooperator or “moral cooperator” type whose own giving is not easily undermined by noise or unfairness. Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to risk being exploited by a persistent low contributor rather than spiral into mutual defection. There is no evidence of opportunistic self-maximization via undercontribution.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is relatively quiet but not completely silent. When they do speak, it is informational and cooperative rather than emotional or aggressive. They volunteer useful experimental knowledge about the payment conversion, clarifying payoff structure for others. This shows attention to instructions and a desire to ground group expectations. They do not join in the more heated or mocking chat about punishing the “angry bird” or other players, nor do they try to steer norms via strong moral language. They refrain from theatrics, jokes, or social bonding chatter, and do not signal alliances or participate in the “mob” dynamics. Their tone is calm, factual, and helpful; they participate selectively when they have something concrete to add, then withdraw. They also do not publicly discuss their own coin totals or emotional state about fairness, indicating a reserved, low-drama communication style focused on task-relevant information.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player almost never punishes. Across many opportunities, they repeatedly choose to spend nothing on punishment, even when there are clear undercontributors or widely condemned targets. The single instance where they do punish is directed at the persistent low-contributing, reward-gaming “bird” avatar, and it aligns with a strong, widely shared social norm in the group at that time. They spend the minimum nonzero amount, consistent with “doing their part” in a collective sanction rather than trying to lead or escalate punishment. They never punish ordinary low-contributors in early coordination phases and never retaliate against anyone who affects their own payoff directly. There is no evidence of spite or revenge; their one punishment move is consistent with norm enforcement against extreme deviation plus strategic concern that the bird is distorting outcomes. Overall, they fit a “reluctant punisher” type: willing to punish once when the group strongly converges on a target and the deviation is glaring, but with a strong default of avoiding punitive spending to preserve their own payoff.

<REWARD>
The player never uses rewards, despite frequent opportunities and visible examples of others rewarding. They do not even use small symbolic rewards toward high contributors or “justice enforcers.” This suggests that, given the unfavorable reward technology (costly to give, low impact), they regard rewarding as inefficient or unnecessary. They appear to believe that maintaining high contributions themselves and possibly supporting occasional group punishment is sufficient to sustain cooperation, without needing to pay extra to thank or incentivize others. There is no sign of using rewards to curry favor, form alliances, or compensate punished players. Their stance is consistent with a payoff-conscious cooperator who sees punishment (rarely) as more cost-effective than reward, and who otherwise prefers to keep coins rather than redistribute them voluntarily.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player pays attention to the payoff structure and conversion into real money, and they share this information once, helping others calibrate expectations. They notice and comment on the coin-to-cash rate, indicating that they track their earnings in real terms, yet they do not dramatically change behavior in response; they still keep contributing max and mostly avoid costly sanctions. They do not publicly react to specific individuals’ gains or losses, despite dramatic swings caused by the punishment campaign against the bird. They abstain from praising “police” players or condemning free-riders in chat, and they do not seem emotionally reactive to seeing others overspend on justice or be heavily penalized. Their single punitive action aligns with broad consensus against a particularly abnormal outcome pattern (the bird accumulating large payoffs while undercontributing and manipulating rewards), showing that they update on extreme inequities but remain disciplined and selective. Overall, they process others’ outcomes cognitively—understanding conversion rates and strategic implications—yet keep their own behavior stable, cooperative, and low-intervention, intervening with punishment only once when a clear, group-endorsed target emerges.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is predominantly a high contributor who publicly commits to maximal contributions and usually follows through, but occasionally and quietly deviates to free‑ride. Their baseline is to treat full contribution as the “default” and they explicitly state an intention to always contribute the maximum. For much of the game they behave consistently with this declared norm, even when others under‑contribute and even when the interaction becomes long and tedious. They do not condition their contributions strongly on others’ behavior in a fine‑grained way; they continue to give the maximum through stretches where some players repeatedly give zero, suggesting they prioritize maintaining the cooperative norm over short‑term payoff optimization.

However, they intermittently switch to contributing nothing on a small subset of rounds, without announcing any change of intention. These free‑ride episodes do not map clearly onto a single trigger like being punished, a sudden collapse of contributions, or a clear end‑game signal; instead, they appear sporadic. This pattern looks less like a systematic conditional cooperator and more like a primarily cooperative type who occasionally tests or exploits the group while trying not to become the obvious villain. They experience punishment for low contributions but do not openly react or adjust their stated stance; instead they quietly return to high contributions afterwards.

Overall, they show relatively low risk aversion regarding group outcomes: they keep contributing maximally even when the group is visibly frustrated and some defectors persist, implying they either accept the lower earnings as the cost of fairness/cooperation or place weight on maintaining an image (to themselves or the “group”) of being a team player. Their norm of fairness seems to be “everyone should contribute the maximum,” but they tolerate their own rare deviations without self‑justification or explanation, suggesting some internal conflict or opportunism rather than a rigid moral rule.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is low‑frequency and low‑intensity in communication. They speak rarely, and when they do, it is short and socially aligned with the majority. Early on, they affirm cooperation by briefly reporting that they are contributing the maximum and later explicitly pledge to do so every time. They do not take a leadership role in explaining the game, organizing punishment, or diagnosing under‑contributors. Instead, they allow others (especially more vocal cooperators) to handle coordination and norm enforcement, while they signal agreement from the sidelines.

Their tone is friendly and lightly humorous. They do not confront defectors, complain about others, or participate in calling out specific low contributors. When the study drags on and others express boredom and frustration, they do not join the complaints in a hostile way; instead, at one point they make a pop‑culture joke comparing the drawn‑out nature of the task to a high‑stakes survival scenario, indicating mild frustration but wrapped in humor rather than anger. Near the end, they offer a brief hopeful remark, signaling engagement and shared desire for the task to finish, but again without directing blame.

They appear responsive to the overall group mood rather than to specific individuals. When others are enthusiastic about cooperation, they publicly align with that sentiment; when the chat shifts to complaining about length and payment, they join that topic lightly, not to organize resistance but to express that they share the experience. They never argue, never defend themselves against punishment, and never challenge accusations that could in principle apply to them; instead they remain socially “smooth,” avoiding conflict and minimizing their visibility. Their style is cooperative, affiliative, and slightly detached: they want to be seen as part of the cooperative in‑group but are not invested in steering the group’s behavior.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never spends any coins on punishment, despite persistent under‑contribution by some others and despite a norm of sanctioning zero contributors that several players adopt and discuss. Even when free‑riding increases and punishment of defectors is openly coordinated in the chat, they abstain from participating. This holds both when they are contributing fully (and would have standard altruistic‑punisher motives available) and when they themselves are low‑contributing (in which case strategic or retaliatory punishment might be expected). Their consistent non‑use suggests either a principled aversion to costly sanctions, a strong focus on maximizing their own payoff, or simple inertia and low engagement with the punishment stage.

When they themselves are punished after free‑riding, they do not comment, complain, or signal any resentment. They neither retaliate nor attempt to negotiate or justify their behavior. Instead, they quietly adjust their contribution back toward the cooperative norm in subsequent play, but still without enforcing that norm on others. This behavior is more consistent with someone who accepts punishment as “part of the game” or not worth engaging over, rather than someone who is concerned with fairness in the sense of “wrongdoing must be sanctioned.”

Functionally, their stance is: contribute a lot, rarely defect, but almost never invest in enforcement. They rely on others to bear the cost of punishing free‑riders and benefit from that enforcement when it increases group contributions, yet they do not reciprocate by punishing themselves. There is no evidence of deterrence‑oriented or norm‑expressive punishment on their part, and no observable retaliatory impulse. Their punishment type is best described as a non‑punishing, norm‑conforming opportunist: they enjoy cooperative gains, occasionally exploit the group, accept being sanctioned, and avoid the costs—material and social—of active enforcement.

title: Moderate contributors who maintain fixed levels while occasionally responding to group norms and behaviors

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a perfectly stable, moderate contributor. They always contribute exactly half of their endowment and never adjust this level despite substantial variation in others’ behavior, total contributions, and final payoffs. Their strategy is simple and rule-like: “I put in a fair, middle amount every time,” with no detectable experimentation or trend over the game. They do not try to match the group’s average, do not escalate to full cooperation when others are highly cooperative, and do not drop toward free-riding when others’ contributions fall. This indicates a strong internal fairness norm anchored at “half,” combined with low reactivity to social or payoff signals. They appear risk-averse with respect to strategy change: once they find a behavior that yields solid payoffs, they stick to it, even though higher contributions would raise group and personal returns given the multiplier. They prioritize steadiness and simplicity over payoff maximization and do not appear to condition their contributions on any specific peer’s behavior.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never uses punishment, despite repeated opportunities and clear variation in others’ contribution levels, including occasional low contributions by peers and visible use of punishment by others. Their inaction persists regardless of whether some players contribute less than the group norm or whether punishment might have been effective at disciplining a specific target. This suggests a strong reluctance to incur personal costs to harm others, even for potential norm enforcement. They do not appear motivated by retaliation, do not mimic others’ punitive strategies, and do not engage in second-order punishment (punishing non-punishers). The pattern is consistent with a non-punitive, harm-averse type that prefers to let the contribution structure “speak for itself” rather than enforcing norms through costly sanctions. Whether this is due to moral discomfort with harming others, skepticism about the effectiveness of punishment, or simple self-interest in avoiding costs remains unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player is never punished during the game, so their direct behavioral response to identifiable punishers is unknown. There is no evidence of pre-emptive adaptation to avoid punishment; their contribution level is unchanging from the start and does not react to others’ sanctioning patterns. Given their stable, moderate contributions and non-punitive stance, if they were punished in a future setting, one might expect low propensity for counter-punishment and a tendency to maintain their own norm-following behavior; however, this is speculative and confidence in this extrapolation is low.

<REWARD>
This player never uses rewards, even when others contribute more than they do and when prosocial reward behavior is clearly present in the group. They do not invest to encourage high contributors, nor do they attempt to strategically reinforce allies or cultivate reciprocity. Their stance appears efficiency- and cost-focused at the individual level: they avoid spending coins on mechanisms that transfer payoff away from themselves, even when such transfers could plausibly improve future cooperation. They also show no sign of imitating others’ rewarding behavior. The absence of rewards, combined with steady moderate contributions, fits a “self-contained cooperator” profile: willing to contribute reliably to the public good but not willing to pay extra to manage others’ behavior through positive incentives.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
This player is never rewarded, so their direct reactions to identifiable rewarders are unknown. They do not adjust their contributions in response to the general presence of rewards in the environment; their behavior remains unchanged while others use rewards multiple times. There is no observable attempt to signal for future rewards by increasing contributions, nor any sign of forming implicit alliances with known rewarders. Whether they would reciprocate rewards via higher contributions or via counter-reward in another setting is unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes substantial information each round: others’ contributions, payoffs, and costs spent on punishment and reward. Yet they display no behavioral adjustment in response. They do not increase contributions when others contribute very high amounts and group payoffs rise, and they do not decrease when others free-ride more or when punitive conflict escalates among others. They ignore both negative and positive incentive signals directed at other players and do not seem to take advantage of apparent “safe” opportunities to free-ride when cooperation stays high. This indicates low sensitivity to social comparison and low engagement with the strategic social dynamics. Their primary focus appears to be on maintaining a personally acceptable, predictable payoff stream rather than tailoring their behavior in response to others’ gains, losses, or enforcement activity. Overall, they behave as a stable, internally guided cooperator who treats others’ outcomes as background information rather than as cues for adaptation.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a flexible, opportunistic contributor who mixes medium cooperation with episodes of near-complete free-riding. They alternate between contributing roughly half of their endowment and contributing almost nothing, with occasional token amounts. Their behavior suggests they want to benefit from the public good without being the worst contributor, and they sometimes match or slightly undercut the prevailing contribution norm rather than either leading cooperation or fully exploiting it.

They show moderate responsiveness to group behavior: when they are heavily targeted by punishment after low contributions, they reliably jump back up to mid-level contributions in subsequent rounds. When punishment pressure eases, they are willing to return to low or minimal giving, indicating conditional cooperation driven by sanctions more than by an internal fairness norm. They do not insist on perfectly equal contributions; instead, they appear comfortable contributing less than many others as long as punishment risk remains manageable.

Their risk tolerance is moderate: they do at times take the risk of very low contributions even after previous costly sanctions, but they do not escalate to extreme, consistent defection once they see that sanctions can be severe. Instead they oscillate, suggesting a willingness to “test” how much free-riding is tolerable, then retreat toward the group norm when sanctions become intense.

Overall, this is a sanction-sensitive, strategic free-rider: not a pure defector, but someone who prefers contributing less than cooperative peers and adjusts upward primarily in response to observed costs rather than intrinsic commitment to fairness.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a simple monotonic decay in cooperation. Instead, the player continues their pattern of alternating between mid-range contributions and very low contributions through the later part of the game. Even very late, they sometimes cooperate at moderate levels and sometimes free-ride, rather than converging on full defection.

Severe punishment episodes near the end are followed immediately by higher, more cooperative contributions, indicating that direct payoff feedback matters more to them than abstract end-game logic. They do not appear to adopt a final-round “grab everything” policy; they are still willing to contribute almost nothing in some late rounds but also still return to medium contributions after that. This suggests that, although they can see how many rounds remain, their horizon awareness is weaker than their short-run response to sanctions.

In summary, their end-game behavior is best described as continuing sanction-driven conditional cooperation with opportunistic dips, rather than a deliberate backward-induction collapse of contributions.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never uses the punishment mechanism, despite multiple opportunities and despite being a repeated target of costly sanctions themselves. They absorb substantial deductions without retaliating or attempting to discipline low contributors, suggesting a strong reluctance to spend their own resources on norm enforcement.

Their non-use of punishment persists across cooperative and non-cooperative phases, indicating a stable trait rather than a situational oversight. This aligns with a payoff-maximizing stance toward the second-order public good: they treat punishment as an unnecessary cost, even when it might deter future sanctions against themselves or stabilize cooperation. There is no evidence of anger-driven retaliation, moralistic punishment, or targeted norm enforcement; their motives appear purely first-order (own payoff from contributions and redistributions), not second-order (shaping others’ behavior via punishment).

Their type is therefore “non-punishing, sanction-sensitive free-rider”: they respond to being punished by adjusting contributions but never themselves invest in punishing others.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly cooperative, mildly opportunistic contributor who appears sensitive to the surrounding norm. They generally align with a high-contribution standard, joining the majority in providing the full endowment to the public good when they see that many others do so. Their pattern suggests a baseline preference to contribute rather than free-ride, but this is not absolute: they are willing to withhold contributions when defection is visibly common and/or when they have recently been treated negatively by others.

They show conditional cooperation: their decision to contribute seems linked to what they infer about the group’s behavior and attitude toward them. When they feel aligned with the group and not targeted, they cooperate fully. When they feel misaligned—e.g., after being singled out for negative treatment despite not behaving worse than others—they are willing to deviate and keep their endowment. This indicates concern for fairness and reciprocity rather than pure profit maximization or unconditional altruism.

Stability is moderate: they do not oscillate randomly, but they do adjust behavior in response to the social environment. They seem willing to bear personal cost to maintain a cooperative norm as long as they perceive the group as fair and non-hostile. Risk tolerance appears moderate as well: they accept exposure to exploitation (by free-riders or punishers) but will test a more self-interested response once that exploitation is salient. They do not, however, escalate into sustained defection; instead, they return to cooperation, implying a default leaning toward prosociality with some guardedness.

Overall, they fit a “conditional cooperator with fairness sensitivity” type: they prefer high contributions, but that preference is contingent on being treated reasonably by others.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player entirely abstains from using costly punishment, even when clear free-riders or surprising punishers are present. They do not target low contributors, nor do they respond punitively to those who harmed them. This absence of punishment is consistent and not obviously driven by a lack of opportunity.

Their non-use of punishment suggests several tendencies:
- Low inclination toward retaliation, even when directly harmed.
- Reluctance to invest resources in norm enforcement, despite having visible free-riders.
- A likely perception that punishment is either too costly, too aggressive, or not worth the effort in this environment.

They do not engage in selective “moralistic punishment” of defectors, nor in revenge toward whoever imposed costs on them. This hints at either a more tolerant or conflict-avoidant style, or a strategic calculation that punishing under uncertainty (not knowing how many rounds remain, nor seeing others’ payoffs) is inefficient.

Regarding motives, there is no evidence of either deterrence- or retaliation-based punishment: they never use the tool, even when both could be justified from a self- or group-protective perspective. This aligns them with a “non-punishing cooperator” profile—willing to contribute, but not to bear additional cost to sanction others.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They experience a substantial deduction at one point, clearly attributable to someone using the punishment mechanism against them, but they do not respond with direct retaliation via punishment. Instead, their next observed response is a temporary shift toward non-contribution. This reveals several things:

- They register punishment and adjust behavior, but the adjustment targets their own contribution rather than the punisher.
- Their reaction mixes emotional or fairness-related response with strategic adaptation: when punished despite not behaving worse than many peers, they briefly withhold cooperation, as if to withdraw goodwill from a group that appears hostile or unfair.
- They do not appear vengeful against specific individuals, despite punishers being identifiable. This suggests either self-control, reluctance to escalate conflict, or a focus on their own behavior rather than targeting others.

Forgiveness is partial: they do not retaliate, and they ultimately resume cooperative contributions, indicating they do not hold a lasting grudge strong enough to cement long-term defection. However, the temporary defection shows they are not fully compliant either; they are willing to “push back” against perceived unfair treatment by lowering their own contributions.

In sum, their response to being punished is non-retaliatory but not submissive: they briefly reduce cooperation to signal or act on their discontent, then revert to their cooperative baseline.

<REWARD>
The player has access to a reward mechanism and receives rewards themselves, yet never uses rewards on others. This consistent inaction suggests a reluctance to spend personal resources to positively reinforce even clear high contributors.

Possible interpretations, all somewhat speculative:
- They may see reward as too inefficient or costly, given the conversion rate.
- They may believe that cooperation is already sufficiently established and doesn’t need additional reinforcement.
- They may be more self-focused in the use of side mechanisms, reserving resources rather than investing in others’ payoffs.

What is clearer is that they are not a “rewarding cooperator” type: they contribute to the public good but do not supplement that with positive incentives. This differentiates them from “strong reciprocators” who both cooperate and actively reward cooperators. Their stance is more minimal: they cooperate directly but do not pay extra for social engineering.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They are rewarded at least twice and can clearly see that someone chose to benefit them, yet they offer no return reward. They also do not change their use of the reward mechanism after being rewarded; it remains inactive. Their contribution behavior following rewards is cooperative, but this was already characteristic of them except during the period following punishment.

This indicates:
- They do not engage in explicit reciprocity via reward tools, even when a clear opportunity for alliance-building or gratitude signaling exists.
- Their gratitude, if present, is not expressed through costly reward; instead, their cooperative contribution pattern continues more or less as before.
- They do not appear to adopt a targeted “you rewarded me, I’ll reward you” exchange strategy in this environment.

Thus, their response to being rewarded is passive: they accept the benefit, maintain or resume cooperative contributions, but do not invest in reinforcing or reciprocating toward the rewarder specifically. This places them in a type that values cooperation and is somewhat responsive to group treatment in their own contribution decisions, but that largely ignores the second-order tools of interpersonal sanctioning and rewarding.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player consistently chooses the fully cooperative option even when others sometimes withhold. There is no evidence of conditional cooperation or adjustments in response to marginal changes in group behavior; contributions remain maximally pro-social throughout. The player appears to follow a strong norm of full contribution rather than a tit-for-tat or proportional strategy. They accept the individual risk that others may free-ride and do not show observable attempts to hedge against exploitation. Their behavior is compatible with a “principled cooperator” type who values the public good and/or adherence to a cooperative rule more than short-term payoff optimization. Whether this is driven by fairness, morality, or experiment-mindedness is unknown.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is generally reluctant to use punishment and does so only once, and not against those who most clearly under-contribute. The target they select is a peer who is contributing fully at the time, while several others are free-riding. This indicates that their punishment is not straightforwardly aimed at deterring low contribution or enforcing a simple fairness norm. The motive behind this isolated punishment is ambiguous: it could be a mistaken click, confusion about the interface, an attempt to test the mechanism, or a delayed/opaque response to earlier behavior; all of these interpretations are low confidence. They never escalate into systematic sanctioning and do not punish multiple low contributors despite repeated opportunities, suggesting no strong inclination toward consistent norm enforcement or retaliation. Overall, they are best characterized as an inconsistent or experimental punisher rather than a dedicated enforcer.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
The player is punished once by another identifiable participant and does not respond with any observable retaliation. After being punished, they maintain full contributions and do not punish the punisher or expand punishment to others. There is no sign that being targeted reduces their willingness to cooperate or induces a counter-punishment cycle. This suggests a relatively non-reactive or forgiving stance toward sanctions, or at least a decision not to use punishment as a response tool. Whether they internally update their beliefs about others’ intentions or feel wronged is unknown; outwardly, they remain cooperative and restraint-oriented in the face of negative treatment.

<REWARD>
The player uses rewards multiple times and never abandons this option entirely. They direct rewards toward individuals who contribute nothing in the public good stage, not toward clear cooperators. This pattern is inconsistent with standard positive reciprocity or straightforward reinforcement of high contributions. Possible, low-confidence interpretations include: attempting to encourage or “pull in” low contributors via positive incentives; experimenting with the reward technology; or misinterpreting the payoff structure. They keep rewarding even when the same target continues to free-ride, indicating either persistence in a “convert the defector” approach or indifference to immediate effectiveness. Later, they shift reward to a different low contributor rather than to reliable cooperators, reinforcing the pattern of favoring laggards over contributors. Overall, they appear willing to incur personal cost to transfer resources to others, with an unusual focus on under-contributors rather than allies.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
The player is positively rewarded by others at least once but does not reciprocate directly to those apparent allies. They do not create a mutual-reward loop with their benefactor; their own reward allocations remain focused on different targets. Receiving reward does not change their all-in cooperative contribution pattern, which is already maximally cooperative, nor does it redirect their social transfers toward reciprocation. This suggests that, behaviorally, they are relatively insensitive to positive incentives in terms of alliance-building or targeted reciprocity. They seem to maintain their own idiosyncratic reward strategy regardless of who supports them. Whether they feel gratitude internally or update trust toward rewarders is unknown; their observable strategy remains principled and self-directed rather than reciprocally oriented.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a volatile, strategically experimental contributor rather than a stable cooperator or pure free‑rider. They never fix on a single norm: their contributions range from zero to the maximum, with many intermediate values. Early on they undercontribute relative to a strong “all max” norm, then sometimes match the group’s high contributions, sometimes contribute clearly less, and occasionally almost nothing while still benefiting from others’ cooperation.

Their behavior suggests:
- They understand that others are mostly contributing the maximum and that this yields high payoffs, but they do not feel bound to that norm.
- They are willing to free‑ride in some rounds even when everyone else is at maximum, and they tolerate being punished for this.
- They are not purely money‑maximizing either: they sometimes contribute close to the maximum even after being heavily punished, and later in the game they continue to sacrifice payoff heavily via rewards and occasional punishment.

They do not make explicit fairness claims, but their pattern shows little regard for “equal treatment for equal contribution.” They repeatedly put themselves in a position where they are the unique or clear outlier and accept that this draws collective punishment. Their risk tolerance is high: they knowingly choose contribution levels that are likely to provoke sanctions, and they continue to do so even after extremely costly deductions.

Overall, this looks like a “playful, high‑variance strategist” who treats contribution choices as part of a broader experiment (including punishment/reward use), not as a fixed moral or efficiency rule.

<COMMUNICATION>
They communicate sparingly but purposefully. Early on they agree briefly with the group’s “all contribute max” coordination line, using a short affirmative response. They do not try to lead or persuade; they mostly observe the rich ongoing conversation among others (especially the very talkative players) and occasionally interject.

Their tone is light and somewhat detached. They never complain about being punished or about low earnings, and they never protest when they are targeted. When they speak later in the game, their messages are short, often reacting with humor (e.g., responding with “lol” to the discussion about region and the game’s length, or confirming the long duration at the end). They do not justify their own unusual behavior, do not explain their reward choices, and do not defend themselves when others discuss them as a “bot” or as suspicious; they simply remain silent.

They are clearly reading chat carefully—later, other players notice detailed aspects of their behavior (rewards, deductions), and the focal player adjusts some behaviors in ways that suggest awareness—but they choose not to use chat to coordinate or to manage their own reputation. This is an engagement style of “quiet observer/experimenter”: highly attentive, minimally expressive, and not seeking social approval.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are willing to punish, but they do so selectively and with a distinctive profile:

- Early on, they punish clear low contributors and non‑compliers, aligning with the group’s justice norm. This includes punishing two obvious deviators in the first round.
- They also join group campaigns against a recurrent norm‑breaker: they punish the chronic zero‑contributor once, adding to the pile‑on.
- Later, they punish an otherwise highly cooperative player who has just been randomly punished by the group’s “angry bird” narrative target, even though that player’s contributions have been consistently maximal. This choice is not driven by contribution levels or by direct harm from that player.

Punishment is relatively infrequent compared to how often they use rewards, but when they do punish it is not purely deterrent: they sometimes side with group justice against norm violators, and other times they appear to “twist the knife” on a high contributor who has just been victimized, making that player worse off while the group is framing them as innocent. This indicates a willingness to exploit ambiguity in social narratives.

They never use punishment to retaliate for punishment they themselves receive, despite being heavily and repeatedly sanctioned. They do not try to deter others from punishing them. That suggests they treat punishment more as an experimental tool and a lever on the group’s emotional dynamics than as self‑protective retaliation.

In a new environment, expect them to punish occasionally, especially clear defectors or salient targets singled out by group talk, but not to be a consistent norm enforcer. They can also direct punishment in ways that seem arbitrary or strategically opaque from others’ perspective.

<REWARD>
Reward is their main “signature.” They spend a very large amount of coins over the game on rewards, far more than most players, and they accept substantial personal losses to do it—even to the point of negative or near‑zero payoffs in several rounds. This is not payoff‑maximizing under the given reward technology.

Their reward pattern reveals several traits:

- They frequently reward full cooperators who stay aligned with the group norm, especially players who are active in chat or central to coordination.
- They repeatedly reward a few specific players across many rounds (for example, one consistently high‑contributing player gets rewarded multiple times), suggesting long‑term “pet” relationships or intentional signaling.
- They also reward players who have just been punished or are socially salient in the discussion, sometimes right after the group focuses on them, as if to counterbalance or to shape perceptions.
- There is no simple “reward only high contributors and punish low contributors” rule. They reward a mix of central talkers, norm enforcers, and occasionally quiet high contributors, but not systematically all of them.

Given that rewards are inefficient (costlier than the benefit they give), their heavy use of them shows that they are not simply maximizing their own final bonus. Instead, they are exploring how rewards shape others’ beliefs: other players openly speculate about who the “angry bird” is rewarding, and some infer that they are being rewarded for having “figured out” the bird’s identity. This indicates the focal player is comfortable using rewards as opaque signals, not necessarily to reinforce contribution norms but to create intrigue and uncertainty.

In a new PGG, this type tends to be a “mysterious benefactor”: willing to burn resources to grant small rewards, with criteria that mix contribution, social engagement, and narrative interest rather than pure efficiency.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The focal player shows a striking indifference to their own monetary outcomes and to punitive attacks on them, while being acutely aware of others’ outcomes:

- They repeatedly accept extremely large net negative or near‑zero round payoffs due to others’ punishment of them and their own reward spending, but never express frustration or attempt to correct others’ perceptions in chat.
- They do, however, track who is gaining and losing: they recognize which players are being punished or rewarded by others and often respond by rewarding those same players, exacerbating or offsetting social signals.
- When an otherwise cooperative player is hit by arbitrary group punishment, they sometimes join in punishing that player further rather than defending them, which suggests they are more interested in the dynamics of sanction cascades than in restoring fairness.

Over time, the group develops a strong narrative that the focal player is a bot or a researcher avatar. The focal player notices this (they’re explicitly named and discussed), but their behavior remains consistent: heavy reward use, variable contributions, and no verbal defense. They do not adjust to restore trust; instead, they continue to generate patterns that others will find puzzling.

They do respond weakly to meta‑information: after the group clarifies the monetary conversion and expresses concern about wasting coins, their contributions and reward intensity sometimes shift toward more moderate or maximal contributions, but they still choose some highly costly reward bursts afterward. This suggests their primary objective is not strictly to maximize money, even once the value of coins is known.

In a new PGG, this player type:
- Tracks the social consequences of outcomes keenly but is not personally deterred by losses.
- Uses others’ outcomes (especially being punished or discussed) as cues for where to direct rewards or occasional punishment.
- Treats the game as an experiment in social signaling and group psychology rather than primarily as a payoff‑maximization task.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, near-unconditional contributor for most of the game. They usually give the full endowment and appear to treat full contribution as the “default” cooperative norm, even when others’ average contributions fluctuate and sometimes fall well below their own. Their behavior suggests they value sustaining group cooperation and are willing to accept personal payoff risk to do so. 

They do not perfectly follow a “simple conditional cooperator” pattern; they continue contributing fully through periods when average contributions drop and when some group members repeatedly free-ride. However, they are not completely rigid. Mid- and late-game, they introduce a few lower contributions, including one sharp reduction, which indicates some sensitivity to the emerging norm and to the diminishing horizon. These deviations are limited and do not escalate into systematic defection; instead, they look like occasional payoff-protecting moves rather than a full abandonment of cooperation.

Overall, they hold a strong fairness/cooperation norm, tolerate substantial exploitation for many rounds, and only modestly adjust downward when group contributions and the end-game timing make full cooperation less attractive.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly aware of the finite horizon and allows it to influence contribution decisions, but only in a restrained way. Near the end, they reduce contributions in some rounds while still maintaining at least moderate giving and even returning to full contribution in the penultimate round. In the final round, they contribute minimally, consistent with standard end-game defection logic. 

This pattern suggests they balance two motives: maximizing final earnings and maintaining a cooperative identity. They do not “unravel” cooperation early; instead, they hold high contributions until late and then selectively defect at the very end, when future reciprocity is impossible. The presence of occasional earlier reductions indicates that they also react to accumulating evidence of others’ opportunism and to decaying overall cooperation, but they do not drive that decay.

<REWARD>
The player never pays to reward anyone, despite having repeated opportunities and clearly observable cooperative peers. This is stable across early, middle, and late rounds. Their restraint is not driven by lack of cooperative partners: several group members contribute highly and are actively rewarding others, yet the player still refrains from spending.

Given that each reward unit is payoff-neutral by design, their refusal to reward indicates a strong cost-avoidance or frugality norm regarding “extra” prosocial expenditures, rather than a misunderstanding of the mechanism. They appear to treat contribution as their main cooperative lever and are unwilling to incur additional direct costs, even to support high contributors or to solidify alliances.

They therefore exhibit a “cooperative but non-rewarding” type: they provide the public good generously but do not invest in formal positive reciprocity mechanisms.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
The player receives rewards in many rounds, often from consistent high-contribution rewarders, but they never reciprocate with reward. There is no evidence of targeted payback to those who reward them, nor of strategic alliance-building via mutual reward exchange. Their contributions remain high regardless of who rewarded them, indicating that they do not condition their giving on being personally recognized or favored.

This pattern points to weak or absent gratitude signaling through the available reward channel. If gratitude or appreciation exists, it does not translate into costly reciprocation. Instead, they maintain a largely one-dimensional cooperative strategy: contribute a lot, ignore the reward system as an active tool, and continue cooperating independently of whether specific others treat them well. This is consistent with a principled or norm-based cooperator who is behaviorally stubborn and not very relationally strategic.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player observes wide variation in others’ contributions, reward spending, and payoffs. They see some players spend heavily on rewards, some systematically reward high contributors, and others free-ride or sharply reduce contributions. Despite this, they show minimal behavioral reactivity in either direction. High reward expenditures by peers do not inspire them to start rewarding, and persistent low contributions by certain members only gradually and mildly reduce their own contributions, mostly later in the game.

They also witness others burning considerable payoff on rewarding, sometimes inefficiently, yet they do not imitate this pattern. This suggests they infer that such spending is not necessary for their own objectives. They appear payoff-conscious with respect to side-payments: they let others bear the extra cost of “policing” or reinforcing cooperation while they stick to contribution decisions alone.

Taken together, the player seems to interpret others’ outcomes and choices mainly as a loose signal about the group’s cooperative climate—adjusting contributions slightly when overall cooperation erodes and the end approaches—but does not engage in fine-grained, actor-specific responses. Their type is that of a robust, norm-driven high contributor who is strategically cautious about additional costs, relatively indifferent to the social signaling and alliance benefits of rewards, and only modestly adaptive to others’ evolving behavior.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor who leans cooperative even when others free‑ride. They often give close to or at the full endowment, with only occasional reductions. These lower contributions appear more like mild shading in response to deteriorating group cooperation or end‑game position than a switch to full free‑riding. They do not match others’ low contributions closely; instead, they maintain contributions above the group’s minimum tendency, suggesting an internal norm of “should contribute fairly a lot” rather than strict payoff maximization. Their behavior indicates moderate risk tolerance: they keep contributing substantially despite weak assurance that others will do the same. Conditionality is present but soft—when the public contribution level drops or becomes erratic, they reduce somewhat, yet they never exploit very high group contributions by sharply under‑contributing. Fairness norms seem pro‑social: they appear more willing to risk being the sucker than to risk dragging the public good down.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not trigger a collapse to zero cooperation. In later rounds, they do trim contributions relative to their own earlier highs, but they remain a positive contributor even when others start dropping. This pattern suggests that the player understands that payoffs are declining and cooperation is becoming less reliable, yet they continue to treat the interaction as worth sustaining. There is no strong last‑round defection spike; instead they end with a moderate contribution when many others severely cut back or drop to near zero. This implies that they either discount backward‑induction logic or prioritize norm consistency and “how I play” over strict end‑game payoff optimization. Their behavior is consistent with someone who values maintaining a cooperative identity through to the end more than squeezing out maximal final‑round earnings.

<REWARD>
This player is a very heavy and persistent rewarder. They spend substantial portions of their payoff on rewarding others across many rounds, often at levels that noticeably erode their own earnings. They continue to reward even when returns to doing so are weak or one‑sided from the standpoint of their own payoffs. The triggers for reward are primarily prosocial behavior: they direct rewards most strongly toward high or reliable contributors and seldom, if ever, toward very low contributors. They appear to target players who either consistently support the public good or who step up in otherwise low‑contribution environments. The pattern indicates that they use reward as a normative signal rather than as a tightly optimized investment. They seem willing to “overpay” to support or encourage cooperators, and they maintain this generosity through both good and bad contribution climates. There is no evidence of them withdrawing rewards in systematic retaliation for low contributions; instead, they tend to simply omit reward for weak contributors rather than spending strategically to reshape them.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
When others reward them, they do not strongly pivot their strategy toward direct reciprocity. Though they do receive rewards from several peers, there is no clear pattern of them selectively increasing reward back to those same individuals relative to similarly cooperative others. Their reward behavior remains broad‑based and anchored more on contribution patterns than on who has personally transferred coins to them. This points to low emphasis on personalized alliances or tit‑for‑tat relationships and higher emphasis on group‑level norms. Being rewarded does not induce extreme shifts in their own contribution levels, suggesting that they see rewards more as confirmation that cooperation is valued than as contingent bargains that must be immediately repaid. If they ever do reciprocate specific rewarders more than others, it is subtle and not systematic enough to infer confidently. Overall, they behave more like a principled prosocial rewarder than a coalition‑builder or reputation trader.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They track others’ contributions and outcomes and respond in ways that prioritize supporting high contributors and visible cooperators. Players whose payoffs are high because they both contribute and are rewarded by others often also receive this player’s reward, indicating a tendency to align with perceived “good citizens” of the group. They show little inclination to target players who already earn very high payoffs through low contributions plus others’ generosity; instead, they generally avoid rewarding clear free‑riders, even when those free‑riders’ outcomes are strong. When the overall group payoff environment deteriorates, they pull back slightly on contributions but often continue spending substantially on rewarding the remaining cooperators, implying that they are sensitive to others’ costs and are willing to shore up those who continue to bear a burden for the public good. They appear to accept personally lower payoffs as a consequence of this stance. There is no evidence of spite or envy toward high earners; their adjustments are about contribution behavior, not simply relative income. Consequently, their type is best described as a norm‑driven, inequality‑tolerant cooperator who uses reward as a costly signal of approval and encouragement rather than as a strict instrument of personal gain.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits a “hyper-cooperative but erratic reciprocator with occasional free-riding” profile. They are generally willing to contribute fully to the public good and appear to treat full contribution as their default choice. Across the game, they alternate between full cooperation and full defection rather than using intermediate or mixed patterns, suggesting a simple, binary heuristic rather than fine-tuned optimization.

Their cooperation is not unconditional. They sometimes free-ride even when most others contribute fully, showing that they do not rigidly follow a fairness or equality norm. They appear comfortable benefiting from others’ contributions without always matching them, especially after periods of intense rewarding, which indicates some sensitivity to their own payoff or fatigue with bearing multiple costs at once.

At the same time, they repeatedly return to full contribution after free-riding episodes, even when the group includes some consistent non-contributors. This tendency indicates a strong underlying cooperative inclination and relatively high tolerance for being exploited. They are not strongly deterrable by the presence of defectors; they seem oriented toward sustaining group cooperation rather than strictly protecting themselves.

Their behavior suggests limited conditionality: they do not finely track who is cooperative versus not, and they do not sharply reduce contributions in direct proportion to defection. Instead, they seem to use coarse adjustments: periods of sustained full cooperation, occasional switches to full free-riding, then reversion to cooperation. This pattern is consistent with a player who values cooperation and the public good but is also somewhat impulsive or experimental, occasionally testing free-riding or taking payoff relief after high-cost rewarding episodes.

Risk-wise, they exhibit a moderate willingness to accept potential exploitation: they often contribute fully in groups with visible defectors and without any punishment mechanism, implying that they either expect enough others to cooperate to make contribution attractive or that they intrinsically prefer the cooperative action even under uncertainty. However, free-riding intervals show they are not purely idealistic; they are aware of and sometimes act on the individual incentive to keep their endowment.

Overall, they are a high-cooperation, somewhat volatile contributor who oscillates between pro-social commitment and opportunistic relief, but without a strong, precise contingent strategy.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no clear evidence of classic end-game defection. They continue to employ full contributions through the final stretch of the game and do not shift into a systematic “last-round” free-riding mode. In the final rounds, they remain willing to contribute fully even when others are not all cooperating, suggesting that horizon effects do not strongly undermine their cooperative tendency.

There is some fluctuation near the end, but it does not follow a simple “cooperation collapses as the end approaches” pattern. Instead, they mix both contributing and free-riding late in the game while still returning to full cooperation in the very last round. This indicates that they either do not rely on backward-induction style reasoning, do not prioritize it, or prioritize other motives such as maintaining a cooperative identity or reinforcing norms independently of future payoffs.

They appear aware that the game has a finite horizon (the interface reveals remaining rounds), but their actions imply that this awareness does not dominate their behavior. Rather than conserving resources or exploiting the final stage, they remain willing to incur cooperative costs at the end. This is consistent with a type who values cooperation as a default stance and is less driven by strictly forward-looking payoff maximization as the game concludes.

<REWARD>
This player is an extremely heavy and sometimes extreme user of the reward mechanism. They are clearly willing to spend substantial personal resources to provide rewards to peers, even at the cost of very low or negative round payoffs. This behavior signals strong pro-social or norm-enforcement motives that can override short-term self-interest.

Their rewarding is broadly directed toward cooperators rather than defectors. They do not appear to systematically reward non-contributors; instead, they seem to reward those who contribute to the public good, attempting to reinforce and encourage cooperative behavior. The amounts they spend on rewards vary widely: in some rounds they give nothing, while in others they invest heavily. This variation suggests a reactive or emotional component—when they perceive cooperative patterns they particularly like, they may respond with bursts of generous rewarding.

They do not appear to use rewards in a narrowly strategic, profit-maximizing way. Given the reward technology, modest levels of rewarding could already provide positive externalities at reasonable cost, but the player sometimes overshoots, spending far more than is necessary to send a cooperative signal or secure a marginal gain. This behavior is consistent with a “pro-social enthusiast” or “over-committed rewarder” type, who prioritizes supporting cooperators and promoting group welfare over their own monetary outcomes.

The player also appears somewhat responsive to receiving rewards themselves: after rounds in which they are rewarded, they frequently maintain or resume full cooperation and sometimes also engage in more rewarding. This pattern suggests that they internalize reward as affirmation and may participate in a cycle of mutual reinforcement—cooperation plus reward leading to more cooperation and more reward. However, because they also reward heavily even when their own payoff is harmed, their rewarding is not purely reciprocal; it is partially unconditional and driven by a desire to foster a cooperative environment in general.

In summary, they are a strong and at times excessive positive reciprocator: they use rewards primarily as a tool to support and encourage cooperative behavior, are willing to incur large personal costs to do so, and do not finely optimize the deployment of rewards for personal gain.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly cooperative, near-unconditional full contributor. They overwhelmingly choose to contribute their entire endowment rather than free-ride, with only a single observed deviation where they keep their endowment. That lone deviation does not launch a new pattern; they immediately revert to full contributions thereafter. This suggests their primary “default” is to cooperate rather than to exploit.

Their behavior shows only weak conditionality: contributions remain high whether the group’s average is slightly lower or higher, and whether some peers free-ride or not. They do not visibly track or mirror specific peers; instead they appear to anchor on a personal norm of contributing fully to the public good. This implies a fairness or efficiency norm that values maximizing group returns even when others are uneven contributors.

They accept the strategic risk that others might exploit their generosity. The payoff structure makes free-riding individually attractive, yet they rarely do so, which indicates a willingness to sacrifice some personal security for cooperative outcomes. The isolated non-contribution can be interpreted as a brief test of the payoffs or a momentary experiment, not as evidence of a shift to self-interest, since it is not repeated.

Overall, this player fits a “principled cooperator with high tolerance for imperfect group behavior”: they keep contributing even when some free-riding is visible, and they do not seem to react strongly to minor fluctuations in group cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no pronounced end-game collapse in their cooperation. They maintain full contributions through the final rounds instead of switching to systematic free-riding as the horizon approaches. The single non-contribution occurs in the late game but is immediately followed by a return to full cooperation; thus it does not function as a classic “last-period” defection pattern.

This suggests that they either (a) do not rely on backward induction to justify defecting near the end, (b) deliberately reject end-game logic in favor of a stable cooperative identity, or (c) attend more to their own norm than to the finite horizon. The fact that they fully cooperate in the very last round indicates that horizon awareness does not dominate their behavior; if they are aware of the remaining rounds, they still choose to act as a cooperator rather than to exploit the lack of future consequences.

The end-game pattern therefore points to a type who is norm-driven or habit-driven rather than purely outcome-driven. They do not strategically unwind their cooperation even when, from a narrow monetary standpoint, that would be individually optimal.

<REWARD>
This player never spends resources on rewarding others, despite having many opportunities and often sitting in cooperative groups where reward could further reinforce prosocial behavior. At the same time, they repeatedly receive reward units from others, sometimes in substantial amounts. They accept these benefits but do not reciprocate through the mechanism provided.

From this pattern, it appears they separate cooperation from social reinforcement: they are willing to incur the cost of contributing to the public good itself but are unwilling to incur the additional cost of meta-cooperation via reward. They might see direct contribution as the “proper” channel for helping the group and view reward as unnecessary, inefficient, or strategically opaque—especially given that rewarders and recipients are anonymous and they cannot target specific individuals based on behavior.

Their lack of rewarding does not change even when they are the target of generous rewards, suggesting that gratitude, if present, does not translate into costly reciprocal reward-giving. They also do not use the reward mechanism as a tool to shape others’ contributions; there is no observed attempt at strategic reinforcement. Overall, they are a pure contributor rather than a “social enforcer”: they invest in the public good itself but abstain from second-order cooperation via rewards.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a steadfast, unconditional cooperator. They always contribute their full endowment and never deviate, regardless of how much others give or how cooperation fluctuates in the group. Their contribution pattern is extremely stable and shows no evidence of conditionality on others’ behavior; they do not reduce their own giving even when free-riding is present or when overall group contributions drop. They appear to follow a strong internal norm that “one should contribute,” rather than responding to short-term payoff incentives, which would favor keeping the endowment. This suggests a high valuation of group efficiency and public-good provision, along with either low sensitivity to exploitation or a willingness to tolerate it. They accept the risk of being the consistent contributor in a mixed group, prioritizing the social optimum over personal earnings. Fairness, in their behavior, is not enforced by matching others but by persistently doing what they treat as the cooperative baseline, independent of what others do.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not reduce their cooperation; they maintain full contributions until the very last round, with no sign of end-game decay. Instead of “unraveling” as the end approaches, they continue to behave as they have all game. If anything, they become more active with the reward tool toward the end, suggesting that they think about the closing rounds as opportunities to reinforce or recognize cooperation rather than to exploit others. There is no observable shift toward self-serving behavior in the final rounds. This indicates that they either do not reason in a backward-induction, payoff-maximizing way, or they deliberately reject that logic in favor of consistent cooperative principles. Their horizon awareness seems to increase their use of social tools (reward) rather than change their core contribution strategy.

<REWARD>
This player is an active, sometimes heavy, rewarder who uses reward as a cooperative reinforcement tool rather than as a precise, efficiency-focused investment. They repeatedly spend substantial portions of their available payoff on rewarding others, including in situations where group cooperation is already high and where the personal cost of rewarding is significant. Their willingness to pay for others to benefit is strong and persists even when the direct financial return from doing so is uncertain or low. They do not appear to use reward in a tightly calibrated, strategic way aimed at maximizing their own future earnings; instead, their pattern fits a prosocial or norm-enforcing style, aiming to support or encourage contributors. They do not systematically withhold reward when others free-ride, but the available data do not reveal how they target specific players, so the exact trigger rules and recipient selection are unknown. Late in the game, they are willing to increase reward spending rather than conserve resources, implying that they treat reward as an expression of cooperative commitment or appreciation rather than a long-run investment tool. Overall, they behave like a principled cooperator who is prepared to incur personal costs to sustain or recognize contributions by others.

title: Volatile conditional cooperators who frequently switch between full cooperation and free-riding strategies

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately prosocial but self-oriented conditional cooperator with high volatility. They do not anchor on a single contribution level; instead, they frequently shift between very low and very high contributions. They clearly understand that contributing can be profitable when others also contribute, because they repeatedly choose high contributions in environments where group contributions appear strong. At the same time, they are comfortable free-riding and sometimes take the full endowment while still benefiting from others’ cooperation.

Their contributions track the perceived cooperativeness of the group in a broad, qualitative way: when others as a whole appear generous, the player is generally willing to join in, though rarely as the most altruistic member. When the group seems more mixed or deteriorating, they reduce their own contribution sharply, sometimes down to zero, even if cooperation has not completely collapsed. They do not insist on strict equality or fairness; they tolerate contributing more than many low contributors around them at times, and at other times they themselves are among the least generous while others are still contributing substantially. This suggests weak or flexible fairness norms: they care about payoff-relevant conditions (is it lucrative to contribute now?) more than about matching others exactly.

Risk-wise, the player shows a willingness to “gamble” on high contributions when the environment looks cooperative, accepting the immediate personal sacrifice for the expectation of a good group return. However, they do not sustain high contributions unconditionally. Their pattern indicates a payoff-sensitive, opportunistic stance rather than a principled commitment to cooperation or a strict free-riding strategy.

Overall, they are a payoff-oriented conditional cooperator: willing to support the public good when it seems profitable and somewhat socially supported, but quick to scale back and free-ride when they sense fragility or unevenness in group contributions. Their strategy is adaptive rather than rigid, but also noisy and inconsistent, suggesting that they update heuristically rather than following a clear, stable rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player appears aware that the game has a finite horizon, but they do not exhibit a simple linear decay or a pure “end-spurt” of defection. In the final portion of the game, they continue to vary their contributions, sometimes contributing very little and sometimes at moderate-to-high levels. They do not switch into a pure defector mode in the last few rounds, nor do they escalate to full cooperation as a final gesture.

Instead, their late-game behavior remains conditional and opportunistic: they adjust contributions up when the group as a whole still looks reasonably cooperative, and they reduce them when the environment seems more mixed or deteriorating, even very close to the final round. This implies that, even when the end is near, their primary reference remains the current cooperative climate and expected payoff, not a strict backward-induction logic or a moral norm about “finishing strong.”

In short, their end-game strategy continues the same pattern as earlier: flexible conditional cooperation with intermittent free-riding, rather than a clear terminal collapse or a final cooperative surge.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed, conditionally cooperative free-rider with moderate volatility. They use only the extreme options (all or nothing) and switch multiple times rather than locking into a stable pattern. They are willing to contribute fully when they perceive a cooperative or mostly cooperative environment, especially when others’ behavior appears predictable or when full contribution seems likely to be matched by most peers. They also exploit highly cooperative phases by free-riding, taking the entire endowment while others continue to contribute, indicating a readiness to prioritize personal payoff over strict fairness.

Their contributions are clearly conditional on recent group behavior: they tend to increase or maintain high contributions when they see widespread or unanimous cooperation, and they are more likely to drop to zero when cooperation looks spotty, uneven, or declining. However, they do not strictly punish defectors by defecting in every mixed situation; they sometimes continue to contribute despite seeing non-cooperation from at least one peer, suggesting some tolerance for partial free-riding or a hope that ongoing cooperation will stabilize or resume.

Fairness norms appear flexible. The player sometimes accepts an outcome where they pay more than at least one other group member and keeps contributing, which points to either a weak inequality aversion or a belief that maintaining group returns is more important than immediate payoff parity. At other times, they opportunistically free-ride when others are fully cooperative, implying they are comfortable benefiting from others’ contributions when the opportunity is salient.

They demonstrate some risk tolerance around cooperation: they are willing to invest everything into the public fund even when it is not guaranteed that everyone else will do the same, but they also hedge by reverting to defection after disappointing returns or low group contributions. Across the game, this produces a persona that is neither a pure cooperator nor a pure defector, but a payoff-sensitive, adaptive contributor who oscillates between full cooperation and full defection in response to perceived group norms and recent payoffs.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a high-volatility, profit-oriented conditional cooperator who mixes full free-riding with substantial and sometimes full contributions. They do not follow a simple monotone trend; instead, they alternate between contributing nothing, half, or all of their endowment, in patterns that appear responsive to the general cooperation climate rather than random.

When the group’s overall contribution level appears strong and stable, the player is willing to contribute heavily, including full contributions. They also sometimes add medium contributions, suggesting they are not locked into “all or nothing” but treat contribution as a tunable lever. However, they repeatedly exploit cooperative phases by dropping to zero while others keep contributing, capturing high payoffs. This shows a willingness to free-ride opportunistically when they expect others to maintain contributions.

They appear to track the general level of group cooperation: they increase contributions after seeing high and widespread giving, and reduce them when they perceive weaker or more fragmented cooperation. Their behavior is consistent with a player who values efficiency and group returns, but only as long as it does not require them to sacrifice too much relative payoff for too long. They are unlikely to be a pure altruist; their repeated zero contributions during cooperative periods suggest they prioritize personal gain over strict fairness.

They do not exhibit stable fairness norms. Sometimes they match the cooperative mood with generous participation, but they repeatedly accept being a clear beneficiary of others’ generosity with no apparent attempt to “pay back” in a balanced way. This points toward a flexible, payoff-sensitive strategy rather than a strong inequity-averse or reciprocity-driven norm.

Risk tolerance appears moderate to high. They are willing to contribute fully when they believe others will also contribute, which is risky if others suddenly defect. At the same time, they also hedge by periodically dropping to zero even in good climates, securing guaranteed private payoffs. Overall, they behave like a sophisticated conditional free-rider who uses the group’s cooperative energy but contributes enough to keep the system productive.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is aware of the finite horizon (they can see remaining rounds) and shows a mild but not extreme end-game effect. In the later part of the game, they continue to mix full contributions with full free-riding, rather than sliding monotonically to zero. This indicates they do not follow a strict backward-induction logic of fully defecting as the end approaches.

They remain willing to make large contributions very near the end, which suggests either a preference for maintaining group efficiency or a belief that others will keep cooperating despite the short horizon. However, they also show opportunistic zero contributions interspersed in the final segment, including in the very last round, which is consistent with exploiting the absence of future punishment or reputation concerns. The last-round zero contribution, after previously showing willingness to give, is a clear sign that when there is no shadow of the future left, they default to self-interested free-riding.

Overall, toward the end-game, the player maintains a mixed, strategic pattern: still cooperating substantially when they expect high returns from others’ contributions, but seizing clear end-of-game opportunities to defect without fear of reprisal. This combination suggests they are forward-looking and horizon-aware, but not purely theoretically backward-inductive; they keep using conditional cooperation while it seems profitable, then switch to free-riding when the marginal strategic value of cooperation disappears.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strategic, payoff-focused conditional cooperator with frequent free-riding and no strong fairness norm.
