They show a wide contribution range, from full free-riding to full provision. Contributions span the entire action space, and they shift frequently rather than locking into a stable level. This indicates high volatility and experimentation, not a fixed rule like “always give X” or “always match the average.”

Their behavior tracks the group’s cooperation level: when others appear to contribute generously and consistently, the player often joins with medium to high contributions, sometimes fully contributing. When perceived cooperation drops or looks mixed, they readily switch back to very low or zero contributions. This pattern supports a conditional strategy grounded in “cooperate when it seems safe and profitable, defect when it does not.”

They clearly understand the payoff structure. At times they exploit high cooperation by contributing nothing or very little while receiving substantial returns, which is consistent with payoff-oriented free-riding. At other times, they invest heavily when others are also contributing a lot, suggesting awareness that high joint contributions increase their own earnings despite personal cost. This mix implies they are not ideologically cooperative; they weigh private versus group returns and alternate between exploiting and supporting the public good.

They do not show a rigid fairness or reciprocity norm. They are willing to defect even when others are broadly contributing high amounts, and they do not systematically “reward” high-contributing environments by reliably matching them. Instead, they sometimes respond to generous peers with free-riding, sometimes with strong cooperation. This variability suggests that fairness considerations, if present, are secondary to outcome maximization and adaptive testing.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. They are willing to make large contributions under uncertainty about how long high cooperation will last, but they never commit to a sustained period of high giving. They appear comfortable accepting the risk of being exploited in some rounds if the environment looks highly cooperative, but they quickly protect themselves when cooperation appears more fragile or uneven. Overall, they seem to balance exploration of cooperative gains with protection against being the “sucker.”

They adapt rapidly. The alternation between full, partial, and zero contributions over the game indicates ongoing updating rather than a predetermined time path. They seem to use simple reinforcement-style learning: high payoffs in cooperative environments can elicit generous actions, but signs of lower cooperation or reduced returns trigger retreat into more self-regarding behavior. There is no evidence of strong moral or identity-based commitment to cooperation; their type is best described as flexible, opportunistic, and strategically responsive to group contributions.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player displays clear end-game awareness and uses it to tilt further toward self-interest, but without a smooth, monotonic decay in cooperation.

They know how many rounds are left and adjust behavior across the later horizon. In the early and middle segments, they repeatedly cycle between cooperative and non-cooperative actions, indicating ongoing experimentation and conditional cooperation. In the final segment of the game, they still sometimes contribute medium or even high amounts, which shows they are not simply following a strict backward-induction logic of “always defect near the end.” However, they also intersperse these cooperative moves with zero contributions, and the final decision in the last round is to free-ride completely.

This pattern suggests a pragmatic rather than principled approach to the end game: they do not commit to a clean “cooperation collapse,” but they lean increasingly on self-interested choices when future interactions are most limited. They do not appear to invest in building or maintaining a long-run cooperative reputation in the final rounds, consistent with the absence of future-oriented reciprocity concerns once the horizon approaches.

Their late-game strategy remains exploratory: even close to the end, they sometimes test whether cooperative environments can still yield high payoffs by contributing non-trivially, but when in doubt—or when marginal gains from cooperation look less secure—they default to keeping their full endowment. The last-round free-ride fits an expectation that there is no longer any strategic value in signaling cooperation or supporting the public good when no future payoff interactions remain.

Overall, their end-game response is: aware of the horizon, willing to opportunistically cooperate if it still seems profitable, but fundamentally inclined to exit the game in a self-protective, non-cooperative mode once continuation value disappears.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a consistent, moderately high contributor who anchors on a “middle‑to‑high” contribution rather than on extremes. They typically give a substantial portion of their endowment, with occasional moves higher when the group is strongly cooperative and rare moves to the maximum. They rarely exploit low group contributions by cutting back dramatically; instead, they maintain a cooperative baseline even when others free‑ride. This suggests a stable internal norm for “fair” giving that is not tightly tied to the minimum level needed for personal gain.

Their contributions show conditionality, but only in a soft, banded way. When others contribute heavily, they are willing to raise their own contribution into the high range, sometimes close to full cooperation, indicating that they value matching or supporting a cooperative norm. When cooperation in the group weakens, they typically do not retaliate by dropping to very low levels; rather, they revert to their personal default, which remains clearly above minimal or purely selfish giving. This pattern suggests a “pro‑social but not self‑sacrificing at all costs” type.

They appear to understand that in this game structure, any contribution above zero is individually costly relative to free‑riding but jointly beneficial, yet they behave as though sustaining group efficiency and fairness is worth some private cost. They are unlikely to be a pure payoff‑maximizing free‑rider. Instead, they seem to trade off material payoff against a desire for a reasonably cooperative, fair group outcome. Their behavior is compatible with a conditional cooperator who sets their own contribution band fairly high and uses it as a default, rather than micro‑adjusting each period to squeeze maximum advantage out of others’ generosity.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. They are willing to keep contributing robust amounts even when cooperation wobbles, which implies tolerance for the risk of being exploited in the short term. However, they avoid persistently extreme full contributions; they rarely “go all in,” which suggests some concern about downside risk and a preference to hedge: they cooperate significantly but keep a buffer for themselves. Overall, they act like a norm‑driven, conditional cooperator with a stable internal reference point, moderate risk tolerance, and limited opportunism.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the game horizon does not lead this player to sharply reduce cooperation near the end. Their contributions remain within their usual moderate‑to‑high band in late rounds, including the final one, rather than collapsing toward minimal contributions. This indicates that they either do not reason in a strict backward‑induction, end‑game‑defection way, or they choose to override such reasoning in favor of maintaining their fairness or cooperation norm.

There is some mild responsiveness to the evolving cooperation level as the game progresses: when the group is strongly cooperative later in the game, they are comfortable maintaining or slightly increasing their own contributions; when cooperation is more mixed, they fall back to their personal default rather than exiting cooperation entirely. Importantly, there is no evidence of a strategic “cash‑out” phase, where they would sharply reduce giving just because the game is about to end.

This pattern suggests that the player treats the presence of many remaining or few remaining rounds similarly, prioritizing consistency with their internal cooperative standard over horizon‑dependent opportunism. They seem to value maintaining a stable cooperative identity or pattern even when there is no future to reward or punish behavior, implying that their cooperation is at least partly principle‑driven rather than purely based on future reciprocity.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player fits a “strategic free‑rider with opportunistic cooperation” type.

They display a strong baseline tendency to free‑ride: zero contributions are their single most common choice, and they often keep the full endowment even when group contributions are high and stable. This suggests that maximizing own payoff in the short run is a primary incentive.

At the same time, they occasionally make medium or high contributions. These are clustered during periods when the group’s contribution level is clearly high and stable, and when their own previous payoffs from free‑riding are already strong. This pattern indicates conditional cooperation, but in an asymmetric form: they are willing to contribute only intermittently and typically after the group has already demonstrated substantial cooperation. They do not appear to initiate cooperation; rather, they join in selectively once it is “safe” and profitable.

Contribution magnitudes are volatile rather than stable. Choices range from no contribution to the full endowment, with intermediate values also appearing. There is no clear monotonic trend over time; instead, their behavior alternates between exploiting the group and sporadically supporting it. This volatility suggests they experiment with different contribution levels rather than following a fixed rule.

Their reactions imply they track whether the environment is cooperative and adjust accordingly. When peers’ contributions are very high and consistent, they sometimes respond with large contributions. When peers’ cooperation is mixed or declining, they revert quickly to zero or near‑zero contributions. This is consistent with a pattern of “cooperate when others are already highly cooperative and the marginal cost is outweighed by expected return, defect otherwise.”

There is no strong evidence of a fairness norm that requires proportional or reciprocal giving. Even when others contribute much more on average, they frequently continue to free‑ride. Their cooperative episodes do not clearly match others’ exact average; instead, they jump between extremes, suggesting that fairness or equality is not a dominant motive.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. They do at times make large contributions that could be risky if others were to drop their contributions, but they do this mainly once there is repeated evidence that the group is already cooperative. They rarely risk high contributions in periods of weaker group cooperation. This indicates that they are sensitive to payoff risk and prefer to exploit predictable cooperative climates rather than gamble in uncertain ones.

Overall, their contribution persona is: primarily self‑interested and exploitative, but with a pragmatic willingness to contribute substantially when the group already provides strong cooperative guarantees and when such cooperation appears individually profitable.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the finite horizon but does not follow a simple “end‑game defection only” pattern. Instead, their late‑game behavior remains mixed: both high contributions and full free‑riding appear in the final portion of the game.

There is no clear monotonic decay of cooperation toward the end. They sometimes make very large contributions even in late rounds, and then revert to zero in adjacent rounds. This indicates that horizon awareness does not by itself dictate a uniform end‑game strategy; they remain responsive to perceived group behavior and immediate payoff considerations rather than switching permanently to pure defection.

Their late‑game pattern suggests they still condition on the cooperative environment even with few rounds remaining. When others appear highly cooperative, they sometimes continue or even escalate their own contributions, despite the short remaining horizon. When group cooperation is less secure or more uneven, they quickly switch back to free‑riding. This conditionality persists up to the final round.

Because their contribution levels fluctuate throughout and do not converge to a single strategy at the end, it is difficult to infer a sophisticated backward‑induction logic. Instead, they seem to use a relatively myopic, round‑by‑round assessment: continue exploiting a cooperative group most of the time, but occasionally contribute substantially when it seems both safe and profitable, regardless of proximity to the final round.

In new games with a known endpoint, this type is likely to retain the same pattern: they free‑ride frequently throughout, including in late rounds, but may still intersperse occasional high contributions near the end if the group remains strongly cooperative and the immediate expected returns from the public good stay high.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly volatile, opportunistic conditional cooperator who oscillates between full free-riding and substantial giving. Their average contribution level is moderate, but it is composed of many zeros and multiple high or even maximum contributions. This pattern indicates they do not follow a simple fixed rule (always cooperate / always defect / constant amount); instead, they adjust frequently and in large jumps.

They clearly understand that others are often contributing generously and that high group contributions yield high payoffs for everyone, including themselves. They repeatedly free-ride in situations where many others contribute heavily, indicating they are willing to exploit cooperative environments for personal gain. At the same time, they also sometimes match or exceed the group’s cooperative stance with large or maximum contributions, showing they value or at least strategically support high public-good provision when they judge it worthwhile.

The instability in their giving suggests they are experimenting and reacting more than following a rigid fairness norm. They do not anchor on an equal-share or proportional contribution principle; at times they contribute less than most others when the group is generous, and at other times they contribute more than some peers when the group is mixed. This points to a flexible, payoff-sensitive mindset rather than a strong fairness-driven identity.

Their willingness both to contribute the maximum and to contribute nothing, even when the social environment looks broadly similar, indicates relatively high risk tolerance and a readiness to test extreme strategies. They appear comfortable with temporary exploitation but are not locked into pure defection; they seem to treat cooperation as a tool that can be switched on and off depending on perceived returns and perhaps on a desire to sustain or restore group cooperation.

Overall, this type is best characterized as a payoff-oriented, strategically adaptive participant who conditionally cooperates when they believe it will sustain high collective returns, but who also frequently free-rides when the environment looks robust enough to tolerate their defection.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player remains willing to contribute substantial amounts in the final phase and does not converge to pure defection as the horizon approaches. They continue to mix low and higher contributions near the end, including multiple mid-to-high contributions when only a few rounds remain. This indicates clear awareness of the remaining number of rounds (as it is displayed) but no simple end-game collapse strategy.

There is no monotonic downward drift in contributions as the game approaches its final rounds; instead, the same pattern of conditional, volatile behavior persists. The player does not appear to treat the final round as a special opportunity for a last-moment exploit; they still contribute a nontrivial amount at the very end rather than dropping to zero. This suggests that their primary decision rule is not a backward-induction style “defect at the end and work backward,” but an ongoing evaluation of group context and payoffs that continues unchanged through the horizon.

In new environments, this implies that even in finite-horizon settings the player does not automatically defect in late rounds. They are likely to maintain a mixed cooperative strategy until the end, adjusting to perceived group behavior rather than sharply switching to all-out free-riding solely because the interaction is about to conclude.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-conscious conditional cooperator who toggles between free-riding, partial contribution, and full contribution. They do not adopt a fixed strategy; instead, they adjust contributions in response to the perceived cooperativeness of the group and to their own payoff experiences.

Their modal choice is an intermediate contribution rather than extremes. They frequently pick a mid-level amount instead of always giving nothing or everything, suggesting they balance self-interest with sustaining group returns. They occasionally fully free-ride, particularly when others are already contributing heavily and group cooperation appears robust, which indicates exploitation of favorable group behavior rather than principled unconditional cooperation. They also periodically contribute their entire endowment when the group appears highly cooperative or when total cooperation seems to surge, consistent with conditional cooperation and a desire to maintain or join high-contribution states.

The pattern shows responsiveness rather than randomness: when cooperation in the group looks strong, they are more willing to contribute high or full amounts; when they observe more low contributors or erratic behavior, they revert to safer mid-level contributions or even zero. This indicates a belief that their own contribution both benefits from and should track what others do, and that over-contributing when others are less cooperative is not worthwhile.

They appear payoff-aware. They experience high payoffs both when they free-ride amid generous others and when they join a highly cooperative group with substantial contributions. They then stay within a band of contributions that maintains good returns without systematically sacrificing personal earnings. This suggests they understand, at least behaviorally, that the marginal per-coin return from the public fund is attractive, but that exploiting others’ generosity occasionally is individually profitable.

There is no evidence of strong fairness enforcement or willingness to “lead” by consistently contributing high regardless of others. Instead, they seem comfortable benefiting from others’ generosity at times and do not consistently match the highest contributors. Their willingness to vacillate between zero, intermediate, and full contributions suggests moderate risk tolerance: they are willing to deviate from whatever the majority seems to do, but not in a purely selfish or purely altruistic direction. They are not rigidly inequality-averse; they accept scenarios where they gain more than heavy contributors and do not subsequently compensate by over-contributing.

Overall, their persona is that of a flexible, opportunistic conditional cooperator: they prefer cooperative, high-contribution environments and will support them with nontrivial or full contributions, but they also strategically exploit such environments by occasional free-riding or dialing down their own contribution when they judge group cooperation to be sufficiently high or fragile.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a pronounced end-game collapse in cooperation for this player. In the final segment of the game, they continue using the same basic repertoire—mostly intermediate contributions with occasional higher ones—rather than sharply dropping to persistent free-riding once the end is near. There is no clear shift to a purely self-regarding, zero-contribution strategy in the final rounds.

Their behavior instead suggests a stable heuristic: maintain moderate contributions in most periods and adjust upward or downward slightly in response to how cooperative the group seems, independent of proximity to the final round. Near the end, they still invest nontrivially in the public fund, implying that they either do not strategically backward-induct or do not prioritize extracting maximal end-game private payoff at the expense of cooperation.

Any subtle changes are small relative to their established pattern. They do not escalate to reliably maximal contributions as a “last gift,” nor do they systematically unwind cooperation. This indicates that while they know how many rounds remain (as per game rules), that knowledge does not dominate their decision-making. They continue to treat late rounds similarly to mid-game, with the same opportunistic yet partially cooperative stance. Their end-game type is therefore “horizon-aware but not horizon-driven”: they may understand the game is ending, but they do not radically change strategy in response.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits a “high but strategic cooperator” type. Across the game, they tend to contribute well above the group average, often close to the maximum, but they do not lock into blind full cooperation. Instead, they adjust around a high baseline in response to perceived changes in others’ behavior and the group’s contribution level.

They initially experiment with low and medium contributions before quickly moving into a pattern of strong cooperation. Once they see that many peers are regularly giving substantial amounts, they typically match or slightly exceed the prevailing cooperative norm. They are willing to give the full endowment in many rounds and frequently choose contributions in the upper range, indicating strong pro-social inclination combined with acceptance of the individual cost.

Their contributions are not perfectly stable: they occasionally drop to moderate or even zero contributions. These drops coincide with situations where the group’s contributions are more uneven or where some players free-ride more visibly. This suggests conditional cooperation: they are willing to sustain high giving while others also contribute reasonably, but they temporarily reduce their own contribution when they infer that the environment is drifting toward lower cooperation. However, these lower-contribution episodes are short-lived; they typically revert quickly to high contributions if group cooperation recovers, indicating they prioritize restoring a cooperative equilibrium over retaliatory defection.

They display sensitivity to fairness at the group level. When others are broadly contributing high amounts, they appear comfortable matching that level, and they do not systematically undercut the group. The few low-contribution choices seem more like tests or responses to perceived unfairness than a consistent desire to exploit others.

Their risk tolerance is moderate to high. Given that personal returns from contribution depend on others, they repeatedly accept short-term risk in order to support a high-contribution environment, even after episodes where such generosity yields relatively lower payoffs due to weaker group contributions. They do not show systematic payoff maximization via free-riding; instead, they trade off some individual security for the prospect of higher group payoffs, consistent with a cooperative but strategically aware profile.

Overall, this player is best characterized as a conditional high cooperator: generally generous, responsive to the group’s cooperative climate, and willing to bear individual cost to support high-contribution equilibria, but not fully unconditional.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not trigger a collapse of cooperation for this player. In the late game, including the final rounds, they continue to contribute at high or upper-mid levels rather than shifting into systematic free-riding. There is some fluctuation and a slight tendency to lower from full-max contributions to strong but not maximal amounts, but there is no clear end-game defection wave.

This pattern suggests that they either do not heavily apply backward-induction reasoning or they place substantial weight on cooperative norms and consistency over final-round exploitation. They appear more inclined to “finish cooperatively” than to exploit the final opportunity for personal gain.

Their late-game behavior remains conditional: when the group maintains robust contributions, they sustain high giving; when group contributions are more mixed, they adjust slightly downward but still stay cooperative. The final round continues this rule-based pattern rather than exhibiting a unique, one-off deviation.

In short, their end-game strategy is to keep cooperating at a high level with moderate fine-tuning rather than to abandon cooperation, indicating a stable pro-cooperative orientation that persists even when no future rounds remain.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a flexible, payoff-conscious conditional cooperator with intermittent free-riding. They do not commit to a single stable contribution level; instead, they alternate between zero, moderate, and high contributions. Their choices track the overall cooperativeness of the group: they are more willing to contribute when others appear highly cooperative and when the public fund remains strong, and they reduce or drop contributions when they see lower or unstable group contributions.

They clearly recognize the private incentive to free-ride: they repeatedly take the option to contribute nothing while benefiting from substantial group contributions. However, they are not a pure defector; they regularly choose non-minimal contributions, sometimes relatively high ones. This mix suggests they balance personal earnings with some willingness to support group efficiency, rather than following a strict selfish or altruistic rule.

Their contribution pattern is volatile rather than fixed. They move between low and high contributions multiple times, indicating ongoing adjustment rather than a simple early decision. This volatility appears responsive to perceived norms: in phases when many others seem generous, they frequently join in with sizeable contributions; when there is visible heterogeneity or some apparent free-riding by others, they sometimes switch back to low or zero contributions.

They display a weak but present fairness or reciprocity norm. They never systematically match the most cooperative players, but they do seem uncomfortable being purely exploitative for the entire game: after episodes of low giving, they later choose to contribute generously even when they could keep all coins and still benefit from others’ giving. This suggests a limited internal standard of “doing their share,” though that standard is inconsistent.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. The player is willing to “invest” in the public fund in situations where they cannot predict exact future behavior of others but where recent evidence suggests a cooperative environment. At the same time, they often hedge by choosing mid-level contributions rather than always going to the maximum, signaling some caution about overexposure if others defect.

Overall, the player is best described as a strategically adaptive, opportunistic cooperator: they exploit cooperative environments at times but also help sustain them once they trust that others are reliably contributing. Their cooperativeness is conditional, fluctuating with their assessment of the group’s behavior and their own payoff experience.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly aware of the finite horizon and does not follow a simple “cooperate to the end” rule. In the last several rounds, their contributions remain variable rather than monotonically declining or increasing. They sometimes contribute substantial amounts close to the end, but they also intersperse zero contributions, including in the final round.

There is no consistent pattern of escalating generosity or systematic end-game defection. Instead, their late-game behavior looks like a continuation of their earlier conditional style: they respond to the current cooperative climate more than to the abstract fact that the game is ending. When others remain relatively cooperative late in the game, the player is still willing to contribute non-trivially in some of those rounds, despite having no future rounds in which reputation or reciprocation can pay off. At the same time, they seize opportunities to free-ride near the end, including at the very last possible decision.

This combination suggests that horizon awareness is present but not dominant. The player does not appear to run a backward-induction strategy; instead, they treat late rounds largely like earlier ones, with slightly more readiness to defect opportunistically when the payoff from free-riding is salient. Their cooperation does not collapse entirely as the end approaches, but it becomes more selective and interspersed with full defection, consistent with an adaptive type that weighs immediate payoff opportunities more heavily than long-run relational concerns once the horizon is short.

title: Near-unconditional high contributors who consistently maximize contributions while occasionally deviating

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable, near-unconditional high contributor. They overwhelmingly choose the maximum possible contribution and maintain this choice across almost the entire game, with a single, isolated deviation where they keep their full endowment for themselves and then immediately revert to full contributions thereafter. This pattern suggests that their default policy is “always contribute fully,” rather than finely tuning their behavior to momentary payoff changes.

They appear willing to contribute at high levels even when others’ average contributions are relatively low and volatile. They do not systematically match the group’s average, nor do they visibly punish low contributors by reducing their own contribution after seeing free-riding. Instead, they continue to put in the maximum, indicating low sensitivity to short-term exploitation risk and a high tolerance for contributing in mixed groups that include defectors.

Their contributions track more with a social or efficiency norm (“it is good to fully contribute”) than with strict reciprocity to individual others. They do not selectively respond to particular peers’ changes in contributions; when others fluctuate between low and high cooperation, this player’s contribution remains essentially constant. The brief instance of zero contribution does not trigger a lasting strategic shift, which suggests either an experiment with self-interest, a momentary test of what happens if they free-ride, or a short-lived reaction to previous low group contributions. Since they promptly return to maximal giving and then stay there, the most consistent interpretation is that they identify as a cooperator and regard the deviation as an exception rather than a new rule.

They show no sign of gradually decaying contributions as the game progresses. High contributions persist through early, middle, and late phases despite significant variation in the group’s behavior. This indicates strong internal cooperation norms and low volatility: they neither escalate nor withdraw in a tit-for-tat manner, and they do not chase the profit-maximizing individual strategy of persistent low contribution despite having enough opportunities to reconsider.

Their fairness norms appear to favor collective efficiency over strict payoff equality. They continue to invest heavily even in the presence of repeat low contributors, which implies they accept some inequity in individual payoffs if the group output stays reasonably high. Risk tolerance is high in social terms: they accept being exploited by free riders rather than adopting defensive defection. From the perspective of classic PGG typologies, they most closely resemble a “strong altruistic cooperator” or “norm-driven unconditional cooperator” with only very limited and quickly reversed experimentation with defection.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the game horizon does not meaningfully erode this player’s cooperation. Across the late portion of the game, including the final rounds, they continue to contribute the maximum amount. There is no visible “end-game unraveling” where they reduce contributions as the remaining number of rounds shrinks. Instead, their cooperative stance is maintained right through the final decision.

They do not attempt to exploit the group in the final round by dropping their contribution, even though doing so would be individually profitable and cannot be punished or rewarded in future interactions. This suggests that their strategy is not based on backward induction about future payoffs, but on a more time-invariant rule or internal standard (“I contribute fully in this kind of game”). Their behavior is consistent with a player who either does not prioritize horizon-based optimization or who values maintaining a cooperative identity or principle more than capturing the one-shot gain from late defection.

The absence of contribution decay near the end of the game also indicates that they either do not expect others to massively defect in the final rounds, or, if they do, they still choose to cooperate despite that expectation. In either case, the looming end does not shift them into a more self-interested mode. They remain a stable, high contributor from start to finish, with no systematic end-game adjustment beyond ordinary payoff fluctuations caused by others’ changing behavior.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strongly prosocial, high-contribution type who treats “always give the socially efficient amount” as the default strategy. They contribute the maximum almost every round, including early on when cooperation norms are only emerging and later when others begin to free-ride or experiment with low contributions. Their contributions are highly stable, not volatile: they do not react myopically to short-term drops in their own payoff or to others’ opportunism.

They appear to anchor on a simple rule: maximize the group pot because the marginal per-coin return clearly exceeds 1. They persist with this rule even when the group temporarily unravels and when multiple others are openly free-riding, which indicates they prioritize long-run expected gains for the group (and themselves) over punishing defectors by reducing their own contribution. Only once do they deviate from maximum, contributing a mid-level amount while the group temporarily collapses; they immediately return to maximum afterwards. This isolated deviation suggests either a brief test of what happens when they reduce, or a moment of doubt or distraction, not a systematic strategic shift.

They exhibit relatively low sensitivity to unfairness compared to typical conditional cooperators: free-riding around them does not trigger sustained retaliation or decay in their giving. They seem willing to “carry” defectors if that keeps the public good large. Risk tolerance is high: they continue to stake their full endowment into the pot even when group behavior is noisy and future rounds/length are uncertain. They behave as a near “unconditional cooperator with rare experimentation,” driven more by a norm or heuristic than by fine-grained payoff tracking.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player’s tone is group-oriented and casual, with flashes of sarcasm or mild aggression but mostly aligned with cooperative messaging. Early on they actively support the emerging norm of maximum contributions, verbally endorsing full cooperation alongside others. This indicates willingness to coordinate and reinforce group norms, not just silently free-ride on others’ persuasion efforts.

They engage in light teasing and one pointed insult toward an identified low contributor, showing some emotional investment in group fairness and a readiness to socially sanction defectors verbally, even though material punishment is unavailable. Later, when some players consider sabotaging the group outcome, they explicitly declare that they will stick to contributing fully, framing their behavior as principled and somewhat playful. They also make at least one informational claim about the likely length of the game, suggesting they follow instructions but may misremember or extrapolate, and they are comfortable sharing beliefs to shape others’ expectations.

They are responsive enough to the ongoing conversation to answer questions about rounds and to joke with others, but they do not dominate the chat. Their style is engaged but not hyper-talkative: they back cooperation norms, throw in a few comments when norms or expectations are in question, and otherwise let others do most of the coordination talk. Overall they adopt a “supportive cooperator with occasional sharp edges” communication style: encouraging the cooperative equilibrium while expressing some disdain for chronic defectors.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player observes that some others systematically earn more by contributing less, yet they do not shift into sustained low contributions in response. Their behavioral reaction to unequal outcomes is minimal in terms of changing their own giving: they largely ignore the individual payoff advantages of defectors and continue to pursue the socially efficient contribution level. This suggests they place more weight on maintaining a high group return than on closing payoff gaps, and they are not strongly driven by inequity aversion in a retaliatory sense.

Verbally, they do register disapproval when a particular free-rider benefits from others’ cooperation, including a direct insult. This shows that they notice and emotionally react to outcome asymmetries, but they compartmentalize that reaction in chat rather than in their economic choices. When the group’s total contributions temporarily collapse and everyone’s payoffs fall, they experiment once with a lower contribution, then immediately return to max contributions once cooperation recovers. This pattern indicates they are aware that lower group contributions hurt everyone, and they interpret recovery in others’ behavior as a reason to restore their own full cooperation rather than to continue punishing past defectors.

They appear to believe that sustained group cooperation is achievable and self-reinforcing, and they act as if their own steady, high contributions help maintain that state even when others wobble. In short, they emotionally dislike free-riding but do not let that dislike override their main objective of keeping the public good large and the game profitable for the group.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly cooperative “principled maximizer” who nearly always contributes the full endowment. Their default is to treat maximum contribution as the obvious, correct strategy and they maintain this across early, middle, and late phases of the game despite substantial free-riding by others.

They show:
- Strong baseline altruism / efficiency focus: they act as if group payoff maximization is the main objective, not individual short-term gain.
- High stability: their contributions are almost always at the maximum; they do not gradually decay contributions as others defect.
- Very limited volatility: the only clear deviation is a single mid-game contribution drop, after which they immediately revert to full contributions. This suggests either a brief experiment, distraction, or mild frustration rather than a strategic shift.
- Conditionality in rhetoric, not in action: they talk as if contributions are conditional (“if we all max, we all gain”), but behaviorally they continue to contribute fully even when others don’t. This indicates weak negative reciprocity and strong commitment to the cooperative norm.
- Fairness norms that are outcome-focused: they emphasize that everyone is better off when all maximize, rather than focusing on equal shares per se. They appear willing to personally sacrifice to preserve an efficient, high-output state for the group.
- High risk tolerance in payoff terms: they repeatedly expose themselves to exploitation by free-riders and do not hedge by lowering their own contributions when exploitation appears. They accept the risk that others will not reciprocate, seemingly valuing the chance to sustain a cooperative equilibrium over protecting themselves against defectors.

Overall, they play like a near-unconditional cooperator with a strong preference for social efficiency and only minimal, transient experimentation with lower contributions.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is generally pro-social, directive, and focused on coordination. They rarely engage in small talk and use chat primarily to advocate a cooperative strategy and to reinforce group norms.

Key features:
- Coordination attempts: they frequently encourage others to contribute the maximum and restate the cooperative rule in simple, collective terms (e.g., “we all benefit if we all put max” framed as shared interest). They also explicitly flag critical moments when cooperation is at risk, signalling awareness of fragile trust.
- Persuasion style: rather than moralizing about “good” and “bad” people, they argue in terms of consequences and obvious logic (“otherwise we will all get less; it’s obvious how it works”). They appeal to common interest and to the transparency of the payoff structure, not to guilt or obligation.
- Responsiveness to group dynamics: they respond when the group shows signs of unraveling (mentions of doing 0, speculation about stopping contributions) and when someone is clearly free-riding. They step in at those moments to reassert the cooperative norm.
- Mild escalation toward defectors: while mostly constructive, they are willing to use light negative language toward persistent free-riders, likening them to someone taking credit in a group project. This is more shaming than abusive, indicating disapproval but not full-blown hostility.
- Engagement style: they are active but not dominant; they don’t spam the chat, and they don’t participate in off-topic jokes beyond what’s needed to maintain rapport. Their interventions are brief and goal-directed: to stabilize cooperation and keep contributions high.
- Cognitive framing: they show an explicit understanding of the game’s structure (public good multiplier, shared returns) and communicate as if they expect others to be rational and to see the same logic once it is explained.

In sum, they are a norm entrepreneur for full cooperation: engaged, rational-argument focused, occasionally sharp with defectors, but primarily oriented toward group-level coordination rather than personal venting or socializing.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They clearly monitor others’ contributions and implied payoffs and use that information to shape their messages, though not their own contribution level.

Their reactions show:
- Sensitivity to exploitation: they notice when certain players repeatedly contribute very little and implicitly identify them as free-riders. They publicly call out such behavior, framing those players as benefiting unfairly from the group’s effort.
- Limited behavioral retaliation: despite frustration and social criticism of defectors, they do not materially reduce their own contributions in a sustained way to punish them. Their main “sanction” is verbal disapproval and norm-enforcement, not payoff-based retaliation.
- Group-focused framing of outcomes: they repeatedly describe the consequence of reduced contributions as a collective loss (“we will all have less”, “we all get much less”), rather than emphasizing their own relative disadvantage. This suggests a payoff concern at the group level more than concern about personal ranking.
- Hopeful belief in collective learning: they act as if clear explanations and social pressure can bring defectors back in line, even after several exploitative episodes. The continued use of cooperative appeals late in the game indicates they expect at least partial responsiveness to norms, not inevitable collapse.
- Distinction between “mistakes” and “types”: when others suggest misclicks or experiment briefly with lower contributions, they do not fixate on them; but persistently low contributors are likened to low-effort group members taking undeserved credit. This points to an underlying model of stable “free-rider types” versus cooperative types.
- Emotional tone: their responses show irritation but controlled; they do not resort to profanity or personal insults, even when others do. Their frustration manifests in mild sarcasm and analogy rather than aggression.

Overall, they respond to others’ outcomes primarily through social norm enforcement and renewed appeals for cooperation, not through adaptive defection. They continue to act as a consistent cooperator while trying to socially discipline or persuade free-riders, indicating a “high-cooperation, low-punishment” type who values maintaining a cooperative climate over personally equalizing payoffs.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strongly pro-social, near-unconditional high contributor who anchors the group on full cooperation. They almost always give the maximum possible amount, with one notable deviation to a mid-level contribution when the group briefly unravels, after which they immediately revert to max-giving and stay there. Their default heuristic is that contributing fully is obviously optimal because the marginal return on a contributed coin is low if kept privately and high when pooled; they explicitly articulate that there is “no reason not” to give everything. They are not purely altruistic in the sense of sacrificing for fairness: they understand and accept that minimal contributors and free riders earn more in some rounds, but they still keep contributing fully because the absolute payoffs are high and stable when the group cooperates. This shows relatively high risk tolerance with respect to exploitation and a preference for maximizing group surplus and the “easy money” flow over tracking their relative advantage. Their contributions are only weakly conditional on others’ behavior: they complain, scold, and momentarily lower their own contribution at one point, yet they do not adopt a sustained retaliatory or tit-for-tat pattern. They tolerate persistent low contributors, including a repeatedly undergiving peer, without systematically lowering their own giving in response. They hold and promote an efficiency norm: the correct “game-theoretic” move, in their mind, is to keep everyone at the maximum to maximize the per-round surplus, even when some individuals behave “tightly.” Self-interest matters, but in the sense of maximizing expected earnings through stable cooperation rather than through exploiting others.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is outspoken, initiative-taking, and uses chat as a primary tool to coordinate high cooperation and to enforce social norms. They greet the group, propose the cooperative strategy early, and continue to reinforce the “always max” norm throughout. Their tone is mostly casual and pragmatic, with some light humor, but periodically escalates into explicit profanity and direct insults toward perceived free riders or “tight” contributors. They use shaming language and moralizing (“acting like a dick,” “cant even think,” “fuck you,” “what a dick”) when frustrated by low contributions or perceived hypocrisy, signaling low tolerance for opportunism once norms are established. At the same time, they engage in side conversation about surveys, earnings, and working from home, indicating comfort with informal social interaction and not being solely focused on the game. They use simple economic reasoning about payoff structure in their persuasion: they stress that the per-coin return is poor privately, that the small private endowment is trivial, and that maximizing contributions generates a large, reliable bonus. They reference “game theory” to frame the behavior normatively, suggesting they see themselves as rational and analytically minded, and they expect others to think in such terms as well. They respond to others’ questions and comments, reinforcing coordination statements from cooperative peers and answering about payment structure and bonuses. Overall, they are engaged, reactive, and often take a leadership/cheerleading role in pushing for maximum cooperation, but they express irritation openly when others deviate.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player tracks others’ contribution behavior and group-level outcomes quite closely and interprets them through a fairness and efficiency lens. They notice when particular individuals contribute less than the group and repeatedly refer to these as “tight” or “fuckers,” indicating a negative moral and emotional reaction to unequal burdens, even though they do not directly adjust their own contributions in a systematic punitive pattern. They understand that low contributors can earn more individually while others keep maxing and call this out explicitly, showing that they are not naïve about free riding. Yet their primary concern appears to be the erosion of trust and the risk that others will stop contributing, which would collapse the high-bonus regime; they warn that if “trust is lost,” payoffs will drop towards the trivial baseline. They thus interpret outcome trends (declining average returns when contributions fall) as evidence of harmful greed and use those observations to scold deviants and to re-motivate cooperators. They do not have access to direct punishment or reward tools in this game, so their main “sanction” response is verbal: shaming, labeling, and trying to reframe defection as short-sighted or stupid. They are aware that non-contributors or minimal contributors sometimes end up with higher round payoffs and they sarcastically frame such players as thinking they are “clever,” but rather than imitating them, they double down on the call for everyone to keep giving. Their adaptation is thus primarily in rhetoric, not in their own contribution strategy: they continue to give highly even in the presence of exploitation, with only a brief, isolated drop, and focus on steering the social narrative back toward “easy money for all” through mutual cooperation.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is best described as a “principled high-contributor with one experiment in free-riding.” They almost always contribute the full endowment, showing a strong and persistent preference for group-efficient outcomes over individual short-term gain. Their contributions are highly stable across the game: they continue to give the maximum even when others start lowering their contributions, and even when the group briefly coordinates around cynical or retaliatory strategies. There is a single clear deviation where they sharply reduce their contribution while many others also experiment with lower amounts; this looks more like a one-off test or momentary alignment with the group mood than a shift in their basic strategy, because they immediately revert to maximal giving and then maintain it.

Their behavior is conditional only in a very weak sense: they do not appear to condition their contributions strongly on observed defection by others. Instead, they act as if contributing the maximum is “the right play” almost regardless of others’ behavior. They repeatedly frame the small private endowment as nearly worthless compared to the redistributed payoff, indicating an internal fairness/efficiency heuristic: maximizing the public good is seen as obviously rational for everyone, and keeping coins is treated as both irrational and self-defeating in the long run.

They seem relatively risk-tolerant in a social sense: they continue to cooperate even as some players lower contributions, accepting the risk of being exploited in order to preserve a high-payoff norm. They do not hedge by giving intermediate amounts; their pattern is essentially “all-in cooperation” with one brief low-contribution outlier. They also appear focused on expected monetary value rather than narrow fairness of shares: they tolerate that low contributors sometimes earn more in a given round if they believe that maintaining high contributions keeps absolute payoffs large for themselves as well.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is concise, pragmatic, and generally cooperative, with occasional light informality. They participate in early social bonding but quickly shift toward commenting on payoffs, effective hourly earnings, and the benefit of sustained cooperation. They explicitly encourage others to maintain high contributions, using simple cost–benefit arguments: the per-round bonus is framed as “easy money,” the private endowment as trivial. They repeatedly remind the group that reducing contributions will sharply reduce everyone’s income, and they emphasize that the value of the shared pot far exceeds the small, forgone 20-coin endowment.

They attempt mild persuasion rather than confrontation. When criticized by others (who misattribute low contributions to “green bird”), they do not retaliate or argue about blame; instead, they restate the efficiency logic and urge continued max contributions. Their arguments focus on long-run group outcomes rather than moral condemnation. They also give meta-comments about the game’s duration and earnings, which signals attention to the experimental context and incentive structure.

They engage playfully at times (joining in on joking or off-topic chat), which suggests they are socially comfortable and not purely instrumental. However, their core use of communication is to reinforce a cooperative norm and reorient others away from short-term free-riding. They explicitly advise ignoring those proposing zero-contribution strategies, signaling an intent to stabilize expectations around full cooperation.

Responsiveness is moderate: they react to the group’s strategic discussions (about donating zero, about round length, about survey payment structure) and tailor their comments to these concerns. They do not individually call out specific low contributors by name, which fits a preference for system-level persuasion rather than interpersonal conflict.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They clearly track group outcomes: they reference pay per round in real-money terms and explicitly note how lower contributions reduce everyone’s payoff. They interpret others’ defections primarily through an efficiency lens: low contributors are not just opportunistic; their behavior is described as self-harming in the long run because it undermines the high-earning equilibrium. Their repeated insistence that the private coins are nearly worthless relative to the redistributed pot shows that they benchmark behavior against aggregate earnings, not just relative standing.

They do not express direct anger or resentment toward low contributors, even when others in chat become insulting or adversarial. Instead, they use these moments as opportunities to restate that under-contributing “hurts them in the end” and that the rational response is to keep maxing out. This indicates a low inclination toward punitive or spiteful responses and a higher inclination toward didactic, efficiency-based reassurance.

They appear relatively insensitive to being personally misattributed as a low contributor (the “green bird” comments): there is no observable attempt to defend their reputation or correct the record. From their behavior, their primary response to others’ outcomes is to preserve the cooperative norm that sustains high payoffs, rather than to seek fairness in the distribution of gains or to protect their own image. They do not suggest reciprocal punishment strategies (e.g., “if others give 0, we should all give 0 back”); instead, they warn that such retaliation only collapses the pot and leaves everyone with minimal returns.

Overall, they respond to others’ outcomes as a payoff-maximizing cooperators’ advocate: they see the public good level and per-round earnings as the key signals, and use communication and their own consistent contributions to nudge the group back toward the high-contribution equilibrium whenever it starts to wobble.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional high contributor. They always give the maximum possible amount in every round, without deviation, even when many others free‑ride or experiment with low or zero contributions and even when this clearly reduces their own relative payoff. Their strategy follows the public-goods efficiency logic: they repeatedly emphasize that contributing fully benefits everyone and that withholding contributions will eventually collapse the gains. They do not condition their contribution on others’ behavior in the short term; instead, they pursue a long‑horizon, group‑optimal strategy regardless of temporary defections. This indicates a strong internal norm for full cooperation, low inclination to retaliate, and a willingness to accept exploitation risk in order to preserve the social optimum. They appear to understand the payoff structure and use it to justify continuous max contributions rather than to search for individually profitable deviations.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player communicates frequently, with a calm, positive, and explanatory tone. They repeatedly encourage others to contribute fully, framing cooperation as “easy money” and stressing that the endowment is small compared to the bonus generated by full participation. They consistently try to maintain group morale, using inclusive language (“we,” “my friends,” “the rest of us”) and supportive slogans. Their persuasion style is rational and forward‑looking: they appeal to long‑run consequences (loss of trust, collapse to minimal payoffs) rather than shaming specific individuals. They engage directly with emerging norms and debates (e.g., whether to drop to zero or to act out of spite) and attempt to steer the group back to full cooperation, sometimes explicitly asking others to “ignore the noise.” They respond to others but rarely change topic toward themselves, and they avoid insults or hostility even when others do. Overall, they are a cooperative coordinator who combines informal leadership with a non‑confrontational, prosocial style.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player is highly attuned to the relationship between others’ contributions and everyone’s payoffs, and they repeatedly comment on how lower contributions from some reduce the payoff level for all. They interpret free‑riding and low giving as short‑sighted “greed” that will ultimately hurt the defectors themselves by undermining trust and driving the game toward minimal returns. However, their reaction stays constructive: they do not propose punishment or retaliation and explicitly warn that responding with zero or very low contributions would only make everyone worse off. When others gain more by contributing less, the player highlights the systemic risk rather than dwelling on their own disadvantage. They appear to see the group’s total earnings and continuity of cooperation as more important than relative fairness in any single round. They also show no sign of updating toward defection even after multiple instances of others getting higher payoffs by contributing less, suggesting a strong, stable preference for sustaining high cooperation over adjusting to exploit or mirror others’ behavior.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable high contributor who almost always gives the full endowment. Their default is to contribute the maximum available amount, and they maintain this pattern from the beginning through the end of the game. There is a single clear deviation to a lower (but still positive) contribution; it coincides with an explicit statement about intending to contribute nothing in a subsequent round and with a moment of visible group frustration and experimentation. Despite that declaration, they immediately revert back to full contributions in all following rounds, including when others around them reduce their own giving.

Their strategy appears primarily efficiency‑oriented rather than narrowly self‑interested: they consistently choose the option that, under this multiplier, maximizes joint returns. They do not seem to condition their contributions on the exact degree of cooperation of others; even when several group members start free‑riding or partially defecting, this player keeps giving the maximum instead of punishing by cutting their own contribution. This suggests weak conditional cooperation and a tendency toward “unconditional cooperator” behavior in practice.

They show some willingness to experiment strategically at one point when trust momentarily declines, but the experiment is minimal, very short‑lived, and they promptly return to the cooperative norm. They tolerate the risk of being exploited by low contributors in order to preserve high group earnings, indicating low aversion to being the “sucker” and relatively high risk tolerance in service of collective gains. Fairness concerns, if present, are subordinated to maintaining the high‑contribution equilibrium.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is light, somewhat ironic, and socially engaged rather than moralizing or confrontational. They join the initial social greetings, participate in off‑topic banter about bank switches and the meta‑nature of the experiment, and occasionally joke about another player likely being a bot. They do not attempt to lead or organize the group around contribution norms: they never lecture about the payoff structure, never scold low contributors, and do not push explicit coordination instructions.

They respond to others’ topics rather than initiating new strategic discussions themselves. When the chat drifts into non‑game topics (banks, surveys, PhDs), they chime in with brief, humorous, or acknowledging comments. When they talk about contribution strategy, they do so in a casually provocative way (e.g., announcing an intention to contribute nothing next round during a tense moment), which reads more like playing with the social dynamics than mounting a serious revolt. Their subsequent behavior contradicts that declaration, implying it is not a firm commitment but more of a performative or joking threat.

They are attentive to the game’s structure and practicalities: they ask about the number of rounds, publicly report their current cumulative payoff when others discuss totals, and acknowledge the conversion rule for the bonus. They answer direct informational prompts (e.g., confirming the bonus rate) but do not try to persuade others through detailed argument. Overall, they engage socially, maintain a playful tone, and avoid direct conflict or moral condemnation.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes others’ outcomes and contribution patterns but does not visibly retaliate or reward through their own contributions. When some group members free‑ride or give less, they continue to fully contribute, even though this reduces their relative advantage and makes them vulnerable to exploitation. They do not publicly complain about making less than low contributors, nor do they express resentment when those players earn higher round payoffs as a result of under‑contributing.

Their one noticeable behavioral deviation to a lower contribution aligns with a moment of collective frustration and talk of withholding contributions, but there is no sustained pattern of conditional response to specific individuals’ outcomes. After that brief dip, they remain cooperative even as fluctuations in others’ contributions continue. This suggests they place substantial weight on maintaining a cooperative environment and high total pot, and relatively little on punishing defectors via their own actions.

In chat, they occasionally frame others’ behavior jokingly (such as calling a persistently under‑contributing player a bot) but not in a way that escalates conflict or tries to enforce norms. They neither join the more aggressive name‑calling nor defend the low contributor. Their main visible response to seeing group earnings rise and fall is to keep doing what they know yields high payoffs collectively and to share their own cumulative payoff when asked. Overall, they behave as a robust cooperator who monitors outcomes but does not let inequities or short‑term exploitation strongly alter their own cooperative strategy.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strongly pro‑cooperative, near-constant high contributor who treats “maxing” as the default strategy. They contribute the full endowment in essentially every round, with one clear deviation when they sharply reduce their contribution once, then immediately revert to full contributions afterward. That deviation appears as an experimental or emotional blip rather than a new long‑run strategy, given its singular nature and the immediate return to full giving.

Their baseline norm is: everyone should contribute the maximum, and they personally abide by it even when others free‑ride. They do not condition their contributions tightly on others’ recent behavior; they keep contributing fully through periods with noticeable under‑contributors and only once momentarily drop below full contribution despite repeated opportunities to defect profitably. This points to a “conditional in principle, but stubbornly cooperative in practice” type: they understand the exploitation risk but still prioritize maintaining the cooperative equilibrium.

They appear payoff‑aware and accept that high contribution is individually profitable in this parameter setting, yet their persistence when others under‑contribute indicates they are willing to sacrifice short‑term advantage to sustain group cooperation. Risk tolerance seems moderate: they tolerate the risk of being exploited by a few low contributors as long as the majority keeps cooperating, and they do not pre‑emptively defect when some defection shows up.

They show a nascent willingness to rethink the “always max” rule late in the game, discouraging maximal contributions once after repeated exploitation and mixed behavior from others. However, they do not act on this in their own choices beyond the single low‑contribution round, suggesting that their internal threshold for abandoning cooperation is high. Fairness norms are clearly strong: they want everyone to contribute equally and visibly dislike inequitable sharing, but they respond mainly through talk and social pressure rather than by systematically cutting their own contribution.

Overall type: “Stubborn high cooperator with a brief, non‑sustained flirtation with defection.”

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is verbally sparse but strategically active when they do speak. Their tone is concise, cooperative, and mildly corrective rather than angry. Early on, they explicitly align themselves with the group’s “max contribution” norm, endorsing the consensus when others promote it. As the game progresses, they occasionally step in to steer group norms: they oppose a suggestion that everyone contribute nothing, instead urging others to keep contributing maximally, and later they briefly reverse that stance, advising against continued maxing when exploitation and inconsistency have become salient.

They rarely initiate new topics; instead they respond to existing coordination discourse. Their messages focus almost entirely on contribution norms rather than off‑topic chatting or personal small talk. This indicates a task‑oriented, efficiency‑focused communication style: they speak when they think it affects group strategy, not to socialize.

They sometimes echo or reinforce pro‑cooperation messages from other high contributors, positioning themselves as part of the “responsible cooperators” subgroup that tries to keep the group on track. When they briefly advise against maxing, they do not justify it explicitly in words, but the timing coincides with increased free‑riding; their communications then reflect a more cautious or disillusioned stance, suggesting they are responsive to perceived norm erosion.

They do not join in personal attacks on low contributors and do not use insults; their one direct challenge (“or not”) to a proposal to all defect is minimal and dry rather than emotional. Altogether, they are a low‑volume, norm‑focused communicator who engages selectively for coordination and mild persuasion, avoids hostility, and adjusts their verbal advice as their assessment of the situation changes.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player clearly attends to others’ contributions and resulting outcomes and uses them to update their beliefs and recommendations, though they do not make large or sustained changes to their own contribution pattern. They see that some players consistently under‑contribute and still receive the same redistributed payoff, and they recognize the classical free‑rider problem: their comments and endorsements of “max” norms are attempts to protect the high‑payoff cooperative equilibrium despite visible exploitation.

When chat participants complain about the “green bird” or other low contributors effectively earning more per coin by giving less, the focal player does not echo the hostility but does take it into account strategically: they oppose nihilistic suggestions to make everyone drop to zero, arguing implicitly that maintaining high contributions is still better, then later express the opposite norm (“no don’t put max”) once continued exploitation and inconsistency have accumulated. This sequence suggests they update their stance in light of the group’s observed behavior and aggregate payoffs, but do so cautiously and without consistent follow‑through in their own choices.

They show no evidence of envy over individuals temporarily earning more by contributing little; instead, their concern is about the stability of group cooperation and the overall payoff level. They do not celebrate or punish specific individuals, nor do they single out particular players by name. Their reactions are at the level of group norms rather than interpersonal scorekeeping.

In sum, they watch others’ contribution/payoff patterns, understand the incentive structure, and adjust their verbal recommendations to the group when they think the cooperative arrangement is at risk, but personally remain mostly locked into a high‑contribution pattern even in the face of exploitation.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly cooperative, near-unconditional high contributor. Their baseline is to give the full endowment to the public fund and they maintain this for the vast majority of the game. Occasional downward deviations are rare, moderate, and short-lived rather than part of a trend.

They show awareness of incentives: the public multiplier makes group cooperation very profitable, and their behavior aligns with prioritizing maximizing total group returns over individual free-riding. They repeatedly continue to contribute fully even when others’ average contributions fall and when free-riding would be individually advantageous in the short run, indicating strong pro-social preferences and/or a rule-based “always cooperate” strategy rather than narrow payoff maximization.

Their contribution pattern is very stable overall. Brief reductions in contribution occur only a few times and never reach full defection; they seem more like small, exploratory or “hedging” adjustments than a shift to a selfish strategy. After such deviations, they quickly return to full contributions, suggesting a robust cooperative identity and low volatility.

They appear to be only weakly conditional on others’ behavior. They certainly observe fluctuations in group cooperation, including periods of lower average contributions, but they do not systematically match those lows or retaliate by cutting back. When the group is highly cooperative, they remain so; when the group is more mixed, they mostly still contribute fully. This implies they act more like a strong cooperator or “moral contributor” than a typical conditional cooperator who proportionally matches the group.

Fairness norms seem present but not dominant. They tolerate substantial heterogeneity in peers’ contributions, including clear free-riding, without sharply reducing their own giving. The absence of strong downward adjustment suggests they accept some unfairness in order to sustain a high-contribution environment, or they prioritize efficiency over strict reciprocity. At the same time, the rare partial reductions could reflect mild sensitivity to perceived inequity or a test of whether full cooperation from others is stable.

Risk tolerance appears relatively high in a social sense. They are repeatedly willing to “risk” being exploited by low contributors, banking on the benefits of maintaining a cooperative norm. Their occasional partial withholdings show they are not blind to risk, but their dominant pattern is to accept downside variance in personal payoff in order to keep contributing at a high level.

Overall, this player is best described as a stable, principled high contributor with limited conditionality and a strong inclination toward cooperative efficiency rather than self-protection.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player shows little to no classic end-game decay in cooperation. Despite full knowledge of the finite horizon, they maintain high contributions through to the final round, including the very last decision. There is no shift into exploitative free-riding at the end, nor a systematic tapering as the remaining rounds dwindle.

Any mid-to-late-game deviations from full contribution are small and do not form a downward trajectory toward the end; instead, high giving persists or even reasserts itself. This indicates that their cooperative rule or preference does not weaken as the horizon shortens. They do not appear to follow backward-induction reasoning that would justify last-round defection, at least in terms of actual behavior.

Their end-game behavior suggests either that they value consistency with a cooperative self-image, have internalized a norm of contributing regardless of stage, or continue to prioritize group efficiency right up to the final decision. Strategic exploitation of others’ continued cooperation at the end of the game is absent in their pattern.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is predominantly a high, near-max contributor who quickly settles into a norm of contributing the full endowment and maintains it almost every round. They begin with a moderate contribution and then shift to full contributions once a “max” norm is discussed, suggesting they are conditionally cooperative but willing to lead with high contributions once they believe the group will follow. Their contributions are very stable: they give the maximum in all but one round, where they explicitly announce and execute a deviation to zero as a retaliatory or experimental response to another player’s persistent free-riding.

Their behavior shows a clear understanding of the payoff structure: they explicitly assert that contributing more yields a larger overall return and that holding back “doesn’t make sense” or leaves people worse off, and they reinforce the idea that one should end each decision with nothing kept. They exhibit relatively low risk aversion regarding others’ cooperation: they continue to fully contribute even while a known defector persists in low or zero contributions for many rounds. Only after extended frustration do they briefly abandon the cooperative norm, then immediately return to full contributions.

They strongly endorse a fairness norm that everyone should contribute the maximum each time; they judge deviators harshly, label them as greedy or bad at math, and at one point encourage a coordinated zero-contribution response as a form of social sanction. Their one-zero deviation appears strategic and expressive (to punish or test the suspected exploiter and/or see if others will follow) rather than a shift in long-term strategy. Overall, their type is a “principled cooperator with retaliatory impulse”: they default to collective efficiency and high giving, but are willing to momentarily defect to punish perceived exploitation or to demonstrate a point.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is highly engaged in chat, reactive to others, and comfortable using humor and mild insults. Their tone mixes sarcasm and irritation with informational content. They align themselves with the cooperative majority and repeatedly reinforce the norm of maximal contributions, sometimes in very succinct, directive messages. They participate in coordination efforts by declaring their own intended contribution, echoing group norms, and endorsing simple rules of thumb (“max,” “0 once,” “you should be holding 0 when you’re done”).

They are particularly focused on the under-contributing “chicken” player. Early on, they join others in calling out that player’s low contributions, directly stating that the numbers observed contradict the claimed behavior, and they explicitly attribute the pattern to poor understanding, trolling, or being a plant/bot. Over time, their language toward this player becomes more openly negative (calling them greedy, bad at math, a troll) and they even ask the “researchers” to remove that player. They do, however, also provide concrete instructions on how to interact with the interface, indicating that they are not purely hostile; they are willing to help but quickly lose patience when the pattern persists.

They show responsiveness to group queries and information: they correct mistaken beliefs about the number of rounds, reference the stated time range for the session, and repeat or clarify the payoff logic for others. Their persuasion style is blunt rather than diplomatic: they use socially charged labels (e.g., greedy, trolling) as part of normative enforcement, and they explicitly lobby for a coordinated zero-contribution move as a collective punishment tactic when they feel exploited. They remain actively conversational until the end, continuing to comment on others’ behavior and to restate negative judgments about the persistent low contributor.

Personality-wise, they present as confident, norm-enforcing, and somewhat confrontational. They are socially engaged, prefer explicit coordination, and care about both efficiency and fairness, but they are quick to express contempt for those they perceive as knowingly exploiting the group. They do not withdraw from interaction; instead, they lean into engagement, using communication as a tool to enforce norms, signal their own strategy, and shape group behavior.

title: Unwavering full cooperators who always contribute maximum amounts without adjusting to group dynamics

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unwavering full cooperator. They always contribute the maximum available amount, never deviating, regardless of others’ behavior, conflict in the group, or stage of the game. Their contributions are not conditional on others’ fairness or civility; they continue to contribute fully even when some others free ride or when inter-player hostility escalates.
