They do not overtly react to how much reward others spend or receive, even when some players invest very heavily in rewards. There is no evidence of envy or frustration about payoff differences; their strategy remains focused on supporting contributors and preserving mutual cooperation, rather than reacting strongly to every distributional detail.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, mostly unconditional contributor who occasionally experiments with self-serving deviations. For most of the game, they give either the full endowment or very close to it, even when one group member persistently contributes very little. Their behavior shows a strong cooperative baseline that is not tightly conditioned on exact fairness or full reciprocity from all group members.

They are not perfectly rigid: they reduce their contribution a few times, including at least one sharp drop. These deviations do not become a new stable pattern; they return to high contributions afterwards. This suggests opportunistic testing or short-run self-interest rather than a committed switch to defection.

They tolerate inequality: they keep contributing a lot despite one clear low contributor and without any visible coordination to punish or isolate that player. They appear more focused on sustaining group provision with the reliable high contributors than on enforcing strict fairness norms on everyone.

Risk tolerance is moderate-to-high in social terms. They consistently expose themselves to the risk that others might reduce contributions later, yet they keep cooperating. Economically, they do not exploit the individually rational strategy of free-riding for most of the game. This implies a cooperative orientation or prosocial preference rather than pure payoff maximization.

Overall, their contribution profile fits a “cooperative but occasionally opportunistic” type: they default to strong cooperation, are robust to some free-riding, but are not entirely immune to short-term temptation as the game unfolds.

<COMMUNICATION>
They never send any chat messages and never respond directly to others’ comments, despite sustained attempts by others to coordinate and express appreciation. This indicates a silent, non-engaging communication style: they observe others’ talk but do not participate.

The lack of verbal coordination, combined with consistently high contribution levels, suggests they treat the game as an individual decision problem rather than as a social negotiation. They allow others to set the cooperative norm in chat but follow or adjust based on observed actions, not on conversation.

Their silence is not clearly hostile or supportive; it is more neutral/withdrawn. They do not publicly endorse the cooperative norm, do not complain about free-riders, and do not express gratitude when rewarded. This makes them socially opaque to others: they contribute like a strong cooperator but do not signal intentions or emotions verbally.

Responsiveness to others’ communication is unknown in content terms; however, their behavior loosely tracks the group pattern (staying mostly aligned with the high contributors), which suggests they are at least paying attention to outcomes and possibly inferring norms indirectly from others’ talk.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They are aware of the game horizon, as the interface displays remaining rounds, but they do not show a steady cooperation decay as the end approaches. They continue to contribute at or near full even when very close to the final round, including in the last round itself.

There is one marked low contribution late in the game, but it does not trigger a sustained shift to defection in subsequent rounds. Instead, they quickly revert to high contributions, including at the end. This pattern does not match a classic end-game unraveling strategy; it is more consistent with a one-off deviation or exploration.

They do not appear to condition their last-round behavior on reciprocal expectations or “last chance” exploitation. Their final-round choice aligns with their early-game cooperative mode, indicating either a stable internal norm of contribution or low salience of finite-horizon strategic thinking.

In summary, their strategy is only weakly shaped by end-game incentives; they maintain substantial cooperation rather than exploiting the final period.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins on rewarding others, even when others contribute maximally and express appreciation in chat. This shows a strong reluctance to incur personal costs for positive sanctions in this institutional setting.

Given the cost-benefit structure of reward (costly and efficiency-reducing from an individual standpoint), their behavior is consistent with self-interested evaluation of the reward mechanism: they are willing to cooperate via contributions but not willing to spend additional resources to reinforce others’ cooperation.

They receive rewards multiple times but do not reciprocate with reward spending, even toward those who likely rewarded them or consistently contributed highly. This absence of observable rewarding suggests they do not use reward as a strategic tool for alliance-building, reciprocity, or norm enforcement.

They rely entirely on their own contribution choices to influence outcomes and never attempt to shape others’ behavior via the reward mechanism. Their incentives appear to prioritize preserving their payoff over actively supporting or thanking others financially.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They are rewarded on several occasions, but their subsequent behavior shows no clear change in contribution pattern that can be directly linked to being rewarded, and they never reward anyone in return. There is no observable direct reciprocity in the use of the reward mechanism.

Their contributions remain generally high before and after receiving rewards, so it is unclear whether reward has any motivational effect beyond what their baseline cooperative preference already dictates. Any internal feeling of gratitude is behaviorally invisible: they do not respond in chat and do not repay via rewards.

If they recognize specific rewarders, this recognition does not manifest as targeted behavioral changes (either extra contributions or reward-giving). Their response to being rewarded is thus best characterized as neutral in terms of observable strategy—no retaliation, no alliance formation, no signaling.

Overall, they behave as a cooperative contributor who is largely indifferent, at least behaviorally, to the reward system and does not engage in explicit reciprocal rewarding.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor with one clear deviation. They usually give the full endowment, even when others start defecting, suggesting a baseline cooperative or efficiency-oriented inclination. Their contributions are not mechanically unconditional, however: after making a costly cooperative move that is not reciprocated via reward, they temporarily switch to free-riding. This indicates conditional cooperation influenced by perceived social reciprocity, not just contribution levels. They explicitly reference the payoff logic later, recognizing that defectors can earn more when others continue to contribute, so they understand the strategic incentives and are not simply naïve. Despite this awareness and explicit peer pressure to defect at the end, they continue to contribute fully, implying some combination of fairness concern, mild social anxiety about defecting, and a tendency toward “doing the proper thing” even when others suggest otherwise. Their behavior is somewhat volatile early on (switching once to zero), but then stabilizes to full contributions, showing fast adaptation and then commitment to a cooperative pattern.

<COMMUNICATION>
They are active and engaged in chat, with a mix of emotional expression, mild sarcasm, and playful humor. They openly share their frustration when their initial generosity via reward is not reciprocated, using a somewhat dramatic, self-pitying tone that signals hurt feelings and a desire for mutual recognition. They participate in norm-enforcement talk, aligning with others who criticize non-contributors, including a brief call to “get” a perceived free-rider, hinting at a punitive or at least sanctioning attitude despite the absence of formal punishment. They also use humor and light teasing to maintain social rapport, and they engage in meta-commentary on the game (noticing player exits, referencing the game horizon, and joking about other avatars). When facing a coordination dilemma at the end, they explicitly voice “decision paralysis” and attempt to negotiate a side deal (offering to cooperate in exchange for being rewarded), suggesting both social dependence and strategic bargaining. Overall, they are socially engaged, responsive to others’ comments, and comfortable using chat both for coordination and emotional venting.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They are clearly aware of the finite horizon and explicitly acknowledge when the last round arrives. Unlike the classic end-game defection pattern, they do not shift to non-contribution at the end; instead, they experience genuine internal conflict about whether to defect when others urge everyone to stop contributing. They express this conflict directly and try to resolve it socially by tying their decision to potential rewards. Ultimately, they continue to contribute fully in the final round even though prominent others advocate zero contributions, suggesting that end-game awareness does not fully override their cooperative or norm-following tendencies. Their final-round behavior looks like a mix of conditionality (they seek assurance or reward) and an underlying reluctance to join a collective defection even when it is strategically justifiable.

<REWARD>
They exhibit a strong initial willingness to reward, to the point of making a very large and personally costly reward investment early on. This is done before having any evidence of reciprocal rewarding from others, suggesting a hopeful attempt to create or signal a cooperative reward norm rather than a purely reactive strategy. When no one rewards them back, they immediately conclude that rewarding is “pointless” and stop entirely for the rest of the game. From that point on, they never spend on reward again, even when later rewarded by others. This pattern indicates that their reward behavior is driven by expectations of mutual reciprocity and social recognition: once those expectations are violated, they withdraw from the reward system completely. They also later try to use reward strategically as a bargaining chip (“you reward me and I will…”), showing that they treat rewards as a possible tool for contingent cooperation, not just as moral praise.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They are rewarded by others in at least one round but do not respond with reciprocal reward. There is no evidence of them acknowledging specific rewarders in chat, thanking them, or building an explicit alliance based on rewards. Given their earlier verbalization that rewarding is useless because no one rewarded them back, it appears that once they form this negative belief, they generalize it and ignore subsequent positive signals. Thus, their reciprocity via reward is asymmetric: they are willing to initiate rewarding in hopes of a rewarding norm, but once disappointed, they do not re-engage even when others start to reward them. This implies low propensity to form dyadic, reward-based alliances; instead, they treat the reward environment in a more global, binary way (“worth it” vs “not worth it”), with limited nuance or updating based on individual-level behavior. Emotional acknowledgment of being rewarded is absent or unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They pay attention to who contributes and who does not, and they also track group size and exits. They join in the informal condemnation of low contributors, encouraging others to “get” them and echoing the narrative of certain players being the problem. They comment on the changing composition of the group (noting when someone disappears) and on shifts in contribution patterns, including the rise of free-riding and the resulting payoff advantage for defectors. They explicitly analyze the payoff dynamics, recognizing that those who contribute nothing can get higher payoffs when others continue to contribute, yet they also distinguish between short-run and long-run consequences when discussing the math with others. They adopt a somewhat moralistic, resigned tone toward free-riders (“some people just want to watch the world burn”), blending normative judgment with an understanding of strategic incentives. Overall, they are outcome-aware, sensitive to fairness and reciprocity, and their attitudes toward others are shaped strongly by perceived contribution behavior and the presence or absence of mutual rewarding.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed, somewhat erratic conditional cooperator with occasional free-riding. They are clearly willing to fully cooperate: they repeatedly choose the maximal contribution and continue to do so even after witnessing at least one clear defector gain higher payoffs. At the same time, they also fully defect in some rounds, including when many others defect and when free-riding is especially profitable. Their pattern suggests they are sensitive to group norms and possibly experimenting rather than strictly following a single rule.

They appear comfortable with risk in the sense of not always aligning with the majority: they fully contribute in situations where many peers call for defection, but also defect in situations with both cooperative and uncooperative behavior around them. There is no evidence that they follow a strict fairness norm such as “match the group average” or “never exploit cooperators”; instead they alternate between being a full cooperator and a free-rider.

Overall, they seem responsive to the broad cooperation climate, but not in a strictly monotone way: they sometimes cooperate when others say not to, and sometimes defect when substantial cooperation is present. Their decisions fit a type that weighs both profit and the social environment but does not lock into a stable rule.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is sparse, reactive, and focused on clarification rather than leadership. They greet others, but they do not initiate strategy proposals about contribution or reward. When another player appears to accuse “monkey” of not contributing, they quickly defend their reputation, clarifying that they did contribute everything. This shows concern about how others perceive their contribution, and a desire not to be misclassified as a defector.

Beyond this, they ask for clarification when they are confused about being addressed, indicating they pay attention to chat and care about understanding social references. They do not engage in moralizing, blaming, or directing others’ strategies, and they never join the more heated or sarcastic exchanges. Their tone is neutral to slightly defensive when their behavior is questioned, but not aggressive. They seem socially attentive yet reserved, preferring to correct misunderstandings rather than steer group norms.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They clearly have awareness of the game horizon (the number of rounds) from the shared information and chat context, but there is no direct statement from them about the remaining rounds. Behaviorally, they do not follow a simple end-game defection logic. Even when others explicitly push for universal defection at the very end, they still fully contribute in the last round. This suggests that, at least in this setting, they do not adopt a purely backward-induction or “last-round, always defect” strategy.

Instead, they seem willing to maintain or attempt cooperation even in an environment where many explicitly discuss shutting cooperation down at the end. At the same time, they defect in earlier late-stage play, so it is not that they are consistently principled; their last-round full contribution indicates either a residual cooperative inclination, confusion, or a deliberate choice to keep contributing despite the end-game incentives. Their end-game pattern is thus mixed but notably not purely self-serving.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins on rewarding others in any round, despite having multiple opportunities and clear examples of others using the reward mechanism. This holds even when they personally receive a small amount of reward early on. Their revealed preference is that reward is not worth the cost under these parameters, or at least not worth using given how others behave.

They also never publicly endorse or discuss reward in chat. There is no sign they use reward strategically to encourage cooperation, reciprocate kindness, or punish defectors indirectly by rewarding only cooperators. In terms of type, they act as a non-rewarder: they rely solely on contribution choices rather than secondary mechanisms to influence others.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive a small reward early in the game from another player. After this, there is no observable change in their reward behavior or contributions that clearly reflects gratitude-based reciprocity. They do not start rewarding the rewarder (or anyone) afterward, and they do not comment on the reward in chat. There is no explicit attempt to build an alliance or exchange of favors with the identifiable rewarder.

Their subsequent contribution pattern (alternating between full contribution and defection) does not obviously track whether they have been rewarded or who rewarded them. This suggests that, at least in this context, they do not strongly condition on having been rewarded, either in terms of reciprocity or increased commitment to cooperation. Their response to reward is best characterized as neutral: they accept the payoff but do not change their strategic toolkit or communication because of it.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe all outcome information, including who contributes, who defects, and who spends on reward, but they rarely comment on it. The only clear reaction to outcome-related social information is when they are implicitly accused of not contributing; then they assert that they did contribute fully. This indicates they care about their cooperative image relative to others’ outcomes and do not want to be grouped with defectors.

They do not publicly criticize or praise players who defect or over-reward, nor do they join in group condemnation of perceived free-riders. They also do not publicly engage with others’ questions about the value of reward. Their behavior suggests a player who monitors the environment, adjusts contributions in a way that loosely tracks the group’s cooperation level, but does so quietly and without overt commentary on others’ payoffs or strategic choices. They appear more concerned with their own payoff and reputation than with norm enforcement or moral judgment of others.

title: Moderate contributors who anchor on fixed levels while occasionally responding to group norms and behaviors

samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a “stubborn moderate cooperator.” They almost always contribute the same intermediate amount, with only one brief deviation downward and one brief deviation upward. Their default is to give a consistent, non-maximal share that is below what many others give but still far from free-riding. They do not systematically adjust contributions in response to changes in others’ average behavior, even when they are repeatedly the unique low contributor among mostly high contributors, and even when they are singled out by punishment. This suggests they treat their chosen level as a personal fairness norm or comfortable compromise between self-interest and group benefit, rather than using a flexible, conditional cooperation strategy. They show low reactive volatility: feedback from others (via punishment, rewards to others, or shifts in group contributions) does not produce sustained upward or downward trends in their own giving. Their risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to undercontribute relative to others despite visibility and sanction risk, but they also avoid extreme free-riding that might trigger harsher responses or collapse group cooperation.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment, despite having multiple opportunities and a clear pattern that one specific partner targets them with costly sanctions. This indicates a very high threshold for imposing costs on others and a strong reluctance to spend personal resources for either deterrence or retaliation. Their behavior does not show targeted or proportional sanctions toward lower contributors, nor retaliation against someone who persistently punishes them. From this, it is reasonable to infer that they either (a) view punishment as inefficient or not worth the cost, (b) are conflict-averse and prefer not to escalate, or (c) are focused on maximizing own payoff without engaging in norm enforcement. Because they themselves are consistently under the group’s contribution norm, it is also plausible that they recognize their own vulnerability and avoid a punishment “war”; however, this is uncertain. Overall, they function as a non-enforcer type: they free-ride somewhat on the norm-enforcement efforts of others without joining those efforts.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When another player repeatedly punishes them, they do not retaliate, they do not significantly increase their contribution to align with the punisher’s implicit demand, and they do not shift into a punitive stance toward anyone else. Their contribution pattern remains essentially stable after being sanctioned multiple times, including instances where the sanction is substantial. This indicates that punishment does not successfully coerce them into higher cooperation and does not trigger counter-punishment. They appear to “absorb” the punishment and continue with their own strategy, implying either a strong commitment to their chosen contribution level, indifference to others’ attempts to control their behavior, or uncertainty about how to interpret the sanction. They exhibit behavioral forgiveness or at least non-retaliation: even persistent, costly punishment aimed at them does not change their treatment of the punisher relative to other group members.

<REWARD>
They never use rewards, even though several others actively reward high contributors. They do not reciprocate those prosocial signals, and they do not selectively reinforce any partner’s behavior. This suggests that they either place low value on norm-reinforcement via positive incentives, consider the reward mechanism inefficient for their own payoff, or are generally uninterested in actively shaping others’ behavior. The absence of rewarding despite clear evidence that others employ it implies they do not try to join the “prosocial coalition” that uses rewards to sustain high cooperation. Their stance is thus passive with respect to positive incentives: they benefit from a high-contribution environment that others help sustain, but they do not invest in maintaining it.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They never receive rewards from others in this game, so their direct response to being rewarded is unknown. Because they consistently refrain from using reward on anyone, including players who are frequently rewarding others, it is uncertain whether they would respond with reciprocal reward or higher contributions if they ever were rewarded. There is no behavioral evidence that they attempt to form alliances with rewarders or distinguish rewarders from non-rewarders in their own actions.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe a group where several players often contribute close to the maximum and sometimes spend on rewards, while one player regularly devotes substantial resources to punishing them. Despite this, they do not visibly condition their behavior on others’ payoffs, spending, or treatment of them. High contributors’ relatively strong earnings and prosocial signaling do not induce them to match those contribution levels, and the punisher’s lower payoffs (due to punishment costs) do not induce them to exploit that player further or adjust contributions downward. They appear largely indifferent, behaviorally, to whether others are sacrificing for the group (via high contribution or reward) or sacrificing to enforce norms (via punishment). This points to a type that monitors the environment enough to see that cooperation is stable and beneficial, and then “locks in” a personally satisfactory contribution that exploits some of the surplus generated by others’ generosity while avoiding extreme opportunism. Their social style is quiet and self-contained: they neither coordinate with prosocial players nor escalate conflict with punishers, and they maintain their own rule-of-thumb strategy regardless of others’ detailed outcomes.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable, moderate contributor with a strong internal anchor. They fixate on a single contribution level that sits below typical high cooperators but far above free-riders, and they maintain it with striking consistency across almost the entire game. Their contribution barely reacts to fluctuations in others’ behavior, including periods when many peers contribute very little and periods when peers contribute a lot. This suggests they follow a simple personal rule (e.g., “always put in a certain share”) rather than finely adjusting to the group.

They appear to care about contributing something meaningful but not maximizing social efficiency. They rarely match the highest contributors and are also not the lowest; they sit in the middle, which indicates a moderate fairness norm: they are not comfortable free-riding, but they also do not feel obliged to fully match the most generous players.

Volatility is extremely low. The one clear upward deviation to a higher contribution late in the game is isolated and not sustained, implying either a brief test, a momentary experiment, or a response to a particularly cooperative group state, but not a full strategy shift. They show no evidence of risk-seeking experiments like extremes of 0 or full contribution as a repeated pattern. Overall, their risk tolerance in contributions is low: they prefer a predictable, rule-based input to the public good.

Conditioning on others appears weak at best. When others drop their contributions sharply, this player does not retaliate by reducing their own to very low levels, and when others contribute very highly, they do not significantly increase their own beyond their usual anchor. If any conditionality exists, it is faint and overlaid on a dominant “fixed-rule” tendency. They behave more like a rule-following, mildly prosocial type than a reactive conditional cooperator.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the game’s horizon does not produce a classic end-game unraveling. This player does not progressively reduce contributions as the game approaches the final rounds. Instead, they maintain their usual level almost all the way through, with only a single temporary spike above their norm very near the end and then a quick return to their baseline.

This pattern suggests that they either do not think in terms of backward induction or do not prioritize it. They do not exploit the final rounds by defecting or sharply lowering contributions. If anything, they show a slight late-game willingness to try a higher contribution in one instance, which is quickly abandoned, implying that any end-game adjustment is weak and unsystematic.

Overall, the end-game has minimal impact on their behavior. They behave as if the same simple rule continues to apply regardless of how many rounds remain. This is consistent with either limited strategic reasoning about the horizon, or a deliberate choice to keep a steady “fair” contribution independent of stage of the game.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player never uses the punishment mechanism, despite frequent availability and despite repeated coexistence with clear under-contributors and free-riders. This is robust across cooperative and uncooperative group states. The absence of any punishment even in periods of noticeably low group contributions points to a strong reluctance to spend resources harming others.

They do not appear to engage in norm enforcement through costly punishment, even though they themselves are not free-riding and thus sometimes bear the cost of others’ low contributions. This suggests they prioritize conserving their own payoff or avoiding interpersonal conflict over enforcing contribution norms. They do not use punishment as a signal, a deterrent, or a retaliatory tool.

Their non-use of punishment appears unconditional: there are multiple episodes where targets for norm enforcement are clear (consistent zero or very low contributors), yet this player still refrains. This pattern fits a “non-punishing cooperator” profile: willing to contribute moderately and tolerate some unfairness, but unwilling to incur extra cost to discipline others, even when the punishment technology is relatively effective.

Motivationally, this is consistent with either: (a) a purely payoff-maximizing view that punishment is not worth the personal cost, or (b) a prosocial/peace-keeping stance that avoids harming others even when they contribute less. The transcript does not distinguish these motives clearly, so this inference is low confidence.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player is never punished by others in the observed game. Their deduction field remains at zero throughout, and they therefore receive no direct experience of how it feels to be punished or who their punishers are. As a result, there is no behavioral evidence on how they respond when a specific punisher is identifiable.

We thus cannot observe whether they would react with retaliation, compliance (increased contributions), forgiveness, or indifference. Given their general stability in contribution, and complete non-use of punishment even when provoked by low contributors, a cautious extrapolation is that they are more likely to respond to being punished, if it happened, by either maintaining their rule-based contribution or, at most, making a modest, non-retaliatory adjustment. However, this is speculative and should be treated as low confidence. For practical purposes, their response to punishers is unknown.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a conditional, somewhat volatile contributor who oscillates between full cooperation and full defection rather than settling into a stable pattern. They frequently contribute the entire endowment when they perceive a cooperative or mixed environment, but they also switch to contributing nothing when they feel exploited or when low contributions by others appear prevalent. Their behavior suggests that they value fairness and reciprocity over strict self-interest: they are often willing to contribute fully even when others are not, but this willingness has limits and erodes when free riding seems persistent or when they are personally punished.

They appear sensitive to relative behavior rather than absolute payoffs. When the group is broadly cooperative, they match that level and maintain or resume high contributions, suggesting an internal norm that “everyone should contribute” and that they should personally uphold that norm when others do too. When cooperation looks uneven—with some clear free riders—this norm weakens and they are more willing to free ride themselves. Their own defecting is not purely opportunistic; it frequently follows being punished or observing substantial non-cooperation, indicating a reaction to perceived unfairness rather than a fixed selfish strategy.

Risk tolerance for unilateral cooperation is moderate. They sometimes continue to fully contribute despite several others giving nothing, indicating a willingness to risk exploitation for the possibility of supporting or restoring cooperation. However, once they are repeatedly targeted by punishment while also seeing non-contributors benefitting, they become more defensive and more willing to defect. They do not appear to chase short-term maximum earnings aggressively; they often accept a lower immediate payoff (due to contributing or punishing) when that aligns with their fairness expectations or with sanctioning free riders. Overall, they behave like a conditional cooperator with a relatively quick emotional or norm-based response to perceived mistreatment.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player does not show a strong classic end-game collapse in contribution. In the final segment of the game, they continue to contribute fully in most rounds and end with full cooperation in the very last round. They do not gradually wind down contributions as the end approaches; instead, they maintain or even reassert full contributions, particularly when others also appear cooperative. This suggests that they either do not heavily factor in the finite horizon strategically, or that maintaining fairness and cooperative norms is more salient for them than last-round exploitation.

Their punishment behavior near the end becomes more intense in some late rounds, indicating increased willingness to pay to enforce norms even with few rounds remaining. This is consistent with a player who seeks to “correct” behavior or express disapproval rather than a player who is optimizing long-run payoff continuation. There is no clear evidence that they treat the last round as a special opportunity to defect; instead, they leave on a cooperative note, consistent with an internal preference for norm-consistent behavior over purely backward-induction reasoning. Overall, they appear horizon-aware in the sense of adapting to patterns that have developed, but they do not strategically exploit the final rounds by slashing contributions.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a frequent and sometimes heavy user of costly punishment. They are clearly willing to sacrifice their own earnings to reduce others’ payoffs. The timing and context of their punishment choices indicate that norm enforcement against free riders is a central motive. They tend to punish in situations where there are obvious non-contributors alongside cooperators, and they tend not to punish when the group contributes uniformly. This pattern aligns with a “moralistic punisher” type who targets low contributors to sustain or restore fairness.

Their punishment is not perfectly restrained. There are episodes of substantial punishment expenditure, especially later in the game, suggesting that emotions such as frustration or resentment may amplify their sanctioning. They continue to punish even after experiencing punishment themselves, which implies that they are not primarily using punishment as a tit-for-tat retaliation tool against specific individuals (since punishers are anonymous and cannot be targeted directly). Instead, they appear to direct punishment broadly at visible defectors, accepting that they themselves may also be punished by others. This supports the interpretation that they see punishment as a collective tool to discipline free riding rather than a purely retaliatory device.

Selectivity is moderate. They do not punish in every low-cooperation environment—there are rounds with substantial free riding where they refrain from punishing—so they are not a rigid or mechanical punisher. However, when they do punish, they are willing to commit nontrivial resources, indicating that the perceived severity or persistence of norm violations matters. Deterrence seems to be an intended function: after punishing in contexts with mixed contributions, they often continue or resume cooperating, as if expecting that sanctions will encourage others to contribute. Overall, they present as a conditional cooperator with strong, sometimes costly, norm-enforcing tendencies and relatively high readiness to bear punishment costs to express disapproval of free riding.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high, norm-following contributor who occasionally experiments with defection. Across the game they choose the cooperative option far more often than the selfish one, so their baseline type is “conditional cooperator with principled leanings.” They appear to adopt a simple rule: contribute fully when a substantial core of others also does so, and withhold only sporadically when cooperation levels are low or mixed.

Their contributions are mostly stable and not strongly volatile. Isolated deviations from full contribution do not cascade into a persistent free-riding strategy; after trying non-contribution, they quickly return to full cooperation even if the group does not uniformly improve. This suggests they value maintaining a cooperative standard more than strictly optimizing against short-run incentives.

They display a concern for fairness: they keep contributing even when several others free-ride, and they combine this with selective punishment (discussed below). They seem willing to bear personal cost to support a group norm of high contribution, which is consistent with an internalized fairness or reciprocity norm rather than pure payoff maximization.

Their tolerance for risk is moderate. They continue to contribute fully in an environment where some players regularly give nothing, indicating they are prepared to “risk” being exploited for the possibility of sustaining cooperation. However, the occasional zero contribution shows they are not blindly altruistic; they are willing to test what happens when they themselves free-ride, likely to gauge both income effects and social feedback via punishment.

Conditioning on others’ behavior is present but not extreme. When the environment looks strongly cooperative, they reliably cooperate; when it is mixed or deteriorating, they still usually contribute but occasionally defect. They do not engage in rapid tit-for-tat or fine-grained matching; their reactions are coarse and slow, consistent with a player who tracks the general cooperative climate rather than individual histories (which they cannot fully observe here).

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a sharp unraveling of their cooperation. They continue to contribute fully in late rounds and do not shift into systematic end-game defection. Sporadic non-contribution is not concentrated at the very end, and they finish the final round by fully cooperating despite the absence of future interactions. This pattern suggests either that they discount backward-induction logic, or that they prioritize maintaining a cooperative identity and norm over exploiting the last opportunities for gain.

There is no clear evidence of escalating contributions at the very end; rather, they maintain the same high-cooperation rule they use through most of the game. Their behavior is consistent with a player who treats each round similarly in terms of moral or normative expectations, with only weak sensitivity to the shrinking horizon.

Given they are punished when they defect and that this punishment does not lead to a persistent switch to defection, they may interpret late-game conditions as still worth enforcing norms rather than giving up. Their strategy appears horizon-robust: the end-game does not substantially alter their cooperative stance.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a willing but selective punisher who uses punishment primarily as norm enforcement against clear low contributors rather than for retaliation or random spite. They spend on punishment in several rounds but also forgo it in many others, indicating they are not compulsive punishers. Their use of the institution is measured: they do not try to punish in every period of low cooperation, but when they do, they commit noticeable resources, sometimes at a relatively high personal cost.

The triggers for punishment are strongly associated with visible free-riding: they punish in contexts where several group members contribute nothing while they contribute fully. They never punish when the group is nearly or fully cooperative. There is no evidence they punish high contributors or engage in antisocial punishment; instead, their pattern aligns with a desire to sanction defectors and support a cooperative norm.

They themselves are punished when they defect, but there is no clear sign that they respond by targeting those who punished them, because punisher identities are hidden and their subsequent punishment patterns continue to track free-riders rather than any identifiable subset. This points toward a motive of generalized deterrence of low contribution, not focused retaliation.

Their selectivity varies over time: in some low-cooperation environments they choose not to punish, possibly conserving resources or perceiving that punishment would not be effective. In other low-cooperation environments they escalate punishment intensity, suggesting that when they believe deterrence might work—or when frustration with persistent free-riding peaks—they are willing to incur significant personal cost to discipline defectors.

Overall, they fit the type of a conditional cooperator–norm enforcer: they cooperate by default, accept personal costs to punish obvious free-riders, and aim to sustain a cooperative standard even when the material incentives and end-game logic would support defection. Their use of punishment is instrumental and morally framed (inferred), but the exact beliefs about its effectiveness and about others’ responsiveness remain uncertain (low confidence on their precise beliefs).

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a conditional, mixed-strategy contributor who alternates between full cooperation and full defection rather than sticking to one extreme. They are willing to contribute the entire endowment when they perceive the group as reasonably cooperative, but they also defect repeatedly, especially once it is clear that some others continue to free-ride and that punishment is available and used against them.

Their pattern suggests they anchor on a fairness norm close to “if most others give, I should give; if some persistently give nothing, I am entitled to keep my own endowment.” They do not appear to be purely profit-maximizing: they sometimes contribute fully in environments where average contributions are modest and where free-riding would clearly yield more money. This implies a non-monetary value on cooperation or on “doing their part” when they think the group deserves it.

At the same time, they are opportunistic. They periodically defect even in relatively cooperative environments, especially once they have experienced being punished as a low contributor. This indicates they view defection as acceptable when others are already shouldering the cooperative burden and when they feel personally treated unfairly or targeted. Their contribution behavior is volatile: they switch multiple times between full giving and full keeping, which is consistent with ongoing updating and experimentation rather than a fixed rule.

The player seems moderately risk-tolerant. They freely expose themselves to punishment by defecting despite evidence that low contributions are punished in this group. That suggests either a willingness to gamble that punishers will focus on more blatant free-riders, or a readiness to accept some punishment as a cost of exploiting cooperative periods.

Overall, they fit a “resentful conditional cooperator”: inclined to support cooperation, but quick to withhold contributions when they feel others or the institution are not aligned with their fairness expectations.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly aware of the finite horizon and does not simply drift into full defection near the end. In the final portion of the game, they continue to alternate between defection and full contribution rather than showing a monotonic decay in cooperation. In the very last round, they fully cooperate in a highly cooperative environment and do not use punishment, consistent with a desire to end on a mutually beneficial, high-efficiency outcome rather than to exploit the final opportunity.

Their end-game behavior suggests that they do not apply a strict backward-induction logic (which would dictate defection and possibly no punishment at the end). Instead, they maintain their conditional fairness rule through to the final round: if the group is strongly cooperative, they match that cooperation even when there is no future to influence. This implies that the act of cooperating itself and the immediate fairness of the outcome matter, beyond strategic future-oriented incentives.

There is no evidence of escalating retaliation or of “last-round spite.” If anything, the end-game displays a reversion to cooperative norms when others’ behavior justifies it. This indicates that the player values outcome symmetry and group welfare in the moment, and does not prioritize squeezing out maximal private payoff at the very end.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is an active and persistent punisher who spends substantial resources across many rounds. They are clearly willing to incur personal costs to impose even larger costs on others. Punishment use is not random: it is systematically associated with others’ low contributions. Their pattern fits a norm-enforcing role rather than arbitrary aggression.

They appears to target clear free-riders—those contributing nothing when many others contribute—and they use punishment both when they themselves cooperate and when they defect. This is important: they do not restrict punishment to “moral high ground” situations. Even in rounds where they give nothing, they still pay to sanction others who also give nothing. That behavior is consistent with strong norm enforcement and with a view that defection is acceptable for themselves when they feel wronged but that particularly egregious or repeated free-riding by others still deserves sanctions.

They also continue punishing even after being punished by others, but there is no direct evidence that they identify or target specific individuals in retaliation, since punishers are anonymous. The observed pattern is more consistent with continued enforcement against low contributors than with personal revenge. However, the fact that they keep defecting and keep punishing while being punished themselves suggests a possible layer of frustration: they may believe their own low contributions are more justified than those of others (for example, as a response to perceived unfairness), and therefore they see others’ low contributions as more blameworthy. Confidence in this interpretation is moderate, as motives cannot be directly observed.

The player does not appear to use punishment purely instrumentally to maximize their own monetary payoff. They sometimes punish in contexts where it plainly lowers their own income relative to simply tolerating others’ behavior. This is consistent with strong reciprocity or inequality aversion: they are prepared to sacrifice money to reduce perceived unfair advantages enjoyed by free-riders and to push the group toward higher cooperation.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a “conditional high contributor with intermittent free-riding and sensitivity to norms.” They demonstrate a clear willingness to cooperate: they choose the cooperative option substantially more often than not and repeatedly sustain full contributions even when others do not match them. This suggests they value collective efficiency and are not purely self-interested in the short term.

Their contributions are conditional, not rigid. They occasionally switch to zero when others’ cooperation looks fragile or uneven. These non-contribution choices cluster after exposure to low contributions or punishment aimed at them, indicating that they condition behavior on perceived fairness and on how they are treated. However, they do not adopt a simple tit-for-tat rule; after free-riding, they readily return to full contribution, even while some peers still contribute little. This points to a flexible, exploratory strategy rather than a strict rule-based one.

They appear to hold a fairness norm where full or near-full contribution by most players is the reference point. When the group approximates that norm, they reliably cooperate. When contributions are uneven or declining, they tolerate some level of free-riding by others but sometimes temporarily free-ride themselves, likely balancing payoff and frustration. Their willingness to keep contributing in the presence of multiple low contributors suggests a relatively high tolerance for inequality, provided that overall cooperation remains substantial.

Risk tolerance is moderate to high: they contribute fully many times when the strategic environment is uncertain and they have already experienced being punished themselves. They accept the risk of being exploited in order to support or probe for a cooperative standard, instead of defaulting to self-protection. At the same time, their occasional zero contributions indicate they are not a naïve unconditional cooperator; they do protect their own payoff when norms look unstable or when they have just borne unfair costs.

Overall, their contribution pattern is mixed but biased toward cooperation, with adjustments that appear responsive to perceived group norms and personal treatment rather than purely to immediate monetary incentives.

This indicates that they do not strictly follow backward-induction logic that would dictate universal defection near the end.

Instead, they appear to use the late game to either reinforce or test norms one last time. They continue to contribute fully in multiple late rounds despite mixed cooperation from others and despite prior punishment aimed at them when they free-rode. This persistence suggests that they maintain a preference for achieving or maintaining a cooperative outcome up to the end, not just early on.

Their behavior across the final several rounds alternates between cooperation and free-riding, but they finish the game by cooperating and also spending on punishment in the very last round. This pattern is consistent with a player who remains engaged with norm enforcement and group outcomes until the last opportunity, rather than “cashing out” entirely. It suggests that they derive some utility from upholding a cooperative standard or from sanctioning norm violators, even when there is no future round in which to reap discipline-driven benefits.

They do not show a strong decay in contributions that monotonically accelerates towards the final round. Instead, their contributions fluctuate but repeatedly rebound. This indicates that their strategy in the end game emphasizes expressing or stabilizing norms more than exploiting the final stage.

Overall, they treat the end game as still meaningful for both contribution and punishment decisions, implying horizon awareness but only partial adoption of standard end-game defection logic.

<PUNISHMENT>

Punishment behavior appears primarily linked to deviations from a cooperative norm. The exact targeting is unknown, but their repeated punishment in such contexts is consistent with a desire to deter free-riding and reinforce cooperation.

They also continue to punish later in the game, including in the final round, which cannot influence future behavior. This willingness to punish when no future benefits are available points to motives beyond instrumental deterrence. It is consistent with expressive or retributive motives: they may value enforcing fairness or “doing justice” even absent strategic payoff. At the same time, earlier punishment episodes, when future rounds remain, can plausibly have a deterrence component. Thus their punishment motives appear mixed: partly strategic, partly norm- or emotion-driven.

Their punishment is not tightly coupled to being punished themselves. They are punished in several rounds but do not always respond with punishment immediately afterward, and they also punish in rounds where they are not freshly targeted. This weak link between experienced sanctions and subsequent punishment suggests they are not purely retaliatory or spiteful in a personal sense; they seem more focused on contribution patterns than on revenge. However, because punishers are anonymous, they cannot target specific punishers, which limits our ability to infer responses to specific individuals; any interpretation of retaliatory motives remains low confidence.

They do not appear to combine non-contribution with punishment in a consistent pattern (such as always free-riding while punishing low contributors), which would be characteristic of “selfish punishers.” Instead, they often punish while also contributing fully, a hallmark of “altruistic punishment” types in PGGs. This combination—bearing both contribution and punishment costs—matches a persona that cares about upholding group-beneficial norms even at personal expense.

Overall, they function as a conditional cooperator who is willing to enforce cooperation via costly punishment, with motives that likely blend instrumental norm support with a fairness or reciprocity ethic.
